content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												American Truck Simulator is a strong evolution of SCS's trucking sim formula. The core loop of pickup, drive, and deliver (with a dash of business management) is still there from ETS2. Cruising from the bustling cities in California, trough the barren night desert, and into a small town in Nevada is as satisfying as ever.The map's scale may be smaller than ETS2, but ATS's world is much more dense and interesting. The use of vanilla ETS2's assets was very similar in every city. That is no longer the case with ATS. From the base level, there are straight up more things to see as you cruise from destination to destination. When assets ARE reused, they are done so in such a creative manner that you probably won't notice on first glance.Most notable of the new assets are the new locations where jobs are taken and delivered. Not only are they much more varied than ETS2, but there's an increased level of challenge when parking. Larger trucks and longer trailers combined with tight quarters and required blind-side backing make some of the drop-offs downright difficult. In fact, the difficulty as a whole has increased with ATS. The mobile police cars make avoiding speeding fines more complex than just cheesing speed cameras. Also, the rebalanced economy seems to have made it a little less easy to earn loads of money.However, there are still flaws. Unprotected, at-grade left turns onto freeways are a nightmare. The freeway traffic will never let up, so any AI in front of you will never be able to pull out. Even if you're lucky enough to be first in line at the turn, you'll end up slowly nudging your way into traffic to try and block them long enough to make it through. Then there are the small pockets of the road system where the speed limit rapidly changes from 70 to 30 to 55. God help you if a cop spots you going 31 in the midst of braking. Lastly, some truck customization parts are not present, such as air horns and extra lights.(UPDATE 2016/05/02 - SCS has since added protected left turns to some areas and made the speed limit changes more gradual. There are still a few rough spots, but way less than on release.)Overall, I am really pleased with ATS at the $20 price point, which is the same as the Scandinavian DLC for ETS2 when it came out. There may only be two trucks and two states, but SCS has been good about supporting ETS2 and they are showing no signs of changing. They've already confirmed at LEAST two more trucks, and the state of Arizona as free DLC. It will be interesting to see their plan for paid DLC to cover the rest of the country.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Pretty much ETS2 with American trucks and a smaller, but highly detailed map. You play as a truck driver who has no cash, no truck, nothing. You do quick jobs by driving for other companies till you can afford your own truck. Once you own a truck, you are free to explore and discover cities where you can find pickup and drop off points for trailers, truck dealers, recruitment agencies, and more. Once you've earned a considerable amount of cash, you can upgrade our garage and buy additional trucks and hire drivers for added income. You can buy more garages in different cities to further expand your business.Pros: - Very vibrant and beautiful graphics- Easy to use interface (Carried over from ETS2)- Highly detailed map with excellent attention to detail- Highly detailed trucks with interior- Realistic Driving physics- Realistic Driving laws- Simple to use Sat Nav- Controller, wheel, joystick support- Mods support- Photomode and World of Trucks- Multiplayer mod (Truckers MP)Cons:- Very poor optimization; you may need a good GPU to run smoothly- Small map (Free & Paid Expansions soon to come)- Limited truck selection (More to come within the next few months)- Daft AI (Similar to ETS2)- Police cars spawn too often and are not forgiving when speeding- Spawn rate of certain AI cars are unrealistic- Lack of slip roads on freeway intersections- Horn sounds like a computer making error noises

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I bought this as a fan of ETS2, however, I found myself dissapointed to the point of refunding the game. Why? The main thing that brought me to that conclusion was the scale in the game. A mile in game is equivalent to about 100 feet on the road,which makes a 100+ mile drive take about 10 minutes. Why does that drive of 100 miles (about 2 miles in real scale) take that long? Because the trucks are the most sluggish and poor handling things I've ever seen in a game like this. Having the petal matted to the floor and flat-foot shifting takes about 1 whole minute to get to 50mph. I can't recommend this game in this state.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Congratulations, you have successfully simulated the tedium of motorway driving. This 'game' is suitable only it seems, for budding Eddie Stobart drivers preparing for their first week on the job. Beyond the -repeat- tedium of overzealous police, speed limits that make me want to increase the rate time passes to actually get anywhere, and the god damn lack of any ounce of imagination when it comes to road design (seriously the most inspiring road design appears to be a series of miniature hills near Bakersfield), we see a return of invisible walls to the world of gaming, I thought had been left behind in 2006. I bought this for two reasons, I wanted to use an controller with my computer, and I wanted a nice relaxing game. Well the controller was anything but obvious to configure, and the gameplay was less relaxing, more naeuseatingly dull.Seriously hope this was not the efforts of more than a first year games programming student's pet project. Dont bother with the rest of the states, you appear to have run out of ideas anyway.

Posted: March 23
												Really fun game. Though something that annoyes the hell out of me is the fact that there is no hose connection still, that one little thing has been bugging me so much. Other than that, it's what you can expect from any game, it has it's up and down. The port is okay, I get major drops in my fps, when I hit cities, and when it rains, etc even though I shouldn't. Graphics could honestly have been better, but there alright. There is a difference from ETS2, but I can't really say much about that game, cause I hate driving flat nose trucks, so I stopped playing that game a long time ago. It will probaly never happen but, I would love to have a seperate mode to this game or something in the future, that actually provides realism. Like getting out of the truck to connect the trailer, maybe a simplified version of logs, acually wieghing the truck at a truck stop, also, adding stuff like real life DOT regulations. Like only being able to work 14hrs and driving 11hrs. Maybe actually hit the dock to the location that your delivering to, actually opening the doors to the trailer. And when you sleep at a truck stop, ya actually have to get out of the seat and move to the bed. adding an actual shifter. Anyway, those are just a few things. This of course would be like a whole seperate mode. Like and advanced game mode for like hard core people, and then what it is now is a Simplified mode. But, yea 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												If you like driving to unwind, this is a great game for you.  Some of the sights might distract you from staying on the road, and sometimes you might find yourself behind a typical slow driven hybrid car.  While this game isn't 100% perfect or accurate with the real world roadscape, there are few iconic junctions or landmarks which are close enough to the real thing.  SCS has also done a great job with the map rescale, even though game updates may feel few and far between.  Regardless, with the current price of $20 and the quality of the updates make this game worth the price.  There are also a ton of mods available in the Steam Workshop.  I just hope that SCS can eventually map out most of the United States, but that could take decades at their current pace.***TLDR:  It's worth the $20 if you love to drive around to unwind.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Product received for free
												An addictive game which is a must for any driving enthusiast.I received this game as a gift from a friend just over two weeks ago and in that time, I've put 100 hours and 30000 miles on my truck. It has a healthy modding community, which has made many trucks not available in the base game (4 currently), realism mods with real companies, and more. It is currently in open beta for the 1.5 release which increases the scale of the game.It's hard to put into words what makes this fairly monotonous game so enjoyable as all you do is take a job, hook up a trailer, and then navigate traffic along miles of road to your destination while avoiding fines, damage and being late.So far, all the core DLC has been free, including new trucks, new states and the rescale project to bring the game to 1:20 scale from 1:35 scale. The only paid DLC is cosmetic. Some paint jobs, a steering wheel pack and a rim/hubcap pack.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												American Truck Simulator is a great game with some serious problems.  It's still a classic and loads of fun, but you may find more value in Euro Truck Sim 2.I have a big debate of whether I prefer ATS (American Truck Sim) or ETS2 (Euro Truck Sim 2).  The two games are very similar.  The UI, graphics, and game controls are improved in ATS, but overall the titles are very similar.  ETS2 has a vastly larger world.  As an American, learning and seeing the European countryside is interesting while driving on the California I-5 is objectively not.  ProGood Sim, the trucks feel real and the various options allow you to make the game more arcade or more simThe world is fun, I don't know if I would say accurate, but it feels genuine in many ways.  California looks like California, Nevada back country feels like Nevada back countryGraphics are improved, not great, but acceptableSteam workshop modsThe red light tickets are really bad....unfortunately it's very realistic just like the number of pot dispensaries in Bakersfield.ConsPerformance is really bad.  Even on a Haswell i5 and GTX 980 the game really struggles to push out 60fps - and the hardware isn't maxed.  This isn't helped much by reducing the settings.  The game just doesn't run well.  My understanding is that aside from being poorly optimized it's running an old DirectX version.Without Stam Cloud, all of you saves are stored locally.  It means you either need to risk all your progress or go through the trouble of backing you saves up through a 3rd party solution.  If you decide to come back to the game in the future you may not be able to locate your savesThere are not enough vehicles in the game as of June 2016.  This will likely change.  However, with ETS2 the developers just put in truck-look-a-likes until the licenses were secured.  Why wasn't this done in ATS?

												After nearly 60 hours of playing this game I must admit I've thorougly enjoyed it. The game receives updates very frequently, the developers are always listening to feedback and new suggestions, plus who doesn't want a game where all you do is drive trucks? The game runs smoothly, I haven't ran into any problems, and it's a lot of fun!A lot of people are concerned about the map size, especially since there's only three states right now. In my opinion it doesn't matter! The map size is HUGE, way bigger than any ETS2 map, and SCS Software even announced they were making the map even bigger just recently.Just because there's three states doesn't mean it's no fun. I've been playing this game for so long and haven't discovered all the cities and roads.This game is a lot of fun, I recommend it to anyone interested. It's worth the money even if you only play it for 60 hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I love driving and now that I'm living in China without a car it is very hard to not be able to drive the open roads of sweet home America.  I've always wanted to maybe be a truck driver.  Well, now I can...sort of.This game is pretty gorgeous.  If you want to drive a truck in a game, then this game is for you.  This isn't a racing game.Some drawbacks/gripes: Signage isn't always the clearest and advance warning is rarely given in terms of speed limit change.  You'll be cruising along at 55+ mph and suddenly the vehicles in front of you were slam on their brakes as the speed limit crashes to 25 to 40 mph for city speeds.  No warning signs like are ACTUALLY found on American roads.There are more little things like that for the trained American eye.  Most players outside of America won't notice.There are a ton of mods for this game which also help to bring it closer to real-life (change generic fake logos, billboards, etc. to real things that for licensing reasons couldn't be put in the game.  I wonder if there is a mod to change Ray's Burgers to McDonald's!)Probably the best experience of this game or any driving game in general would be with a good steering wheel and pedals...alas I don't have one, so I'm forced to play with either the keyboard or my gamepad (which always drifts with the steering).Take your time.  Enjoy it.  Try to avoid falling into the rut I recently fell in!  12 or so good deliveries in and then I just started slipping and crashing my truck all the time.Beautiful game.  If you enjoy simulators and driving (not racing) you will probably put in 10 hours the first day or two you have this game and you'll start to feel fatigued like a real driver!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												ATS may be much smaller in scale than ETS2 but its environments are better designed i.e., prettier and more believable. It is also a bit more challenging with harder drop-off points that you can select for bonus in XP. Smaller gas stations would give you problem to navigate your long trailer in requiring you to be mindful when entering them. There are now police and emergency vehicles that roam the streets which are nice additions for better immersion. The Police would sound their sirene should you violate traffic rules and get yourself fined as a result. Towns and cities are bigger, prettier, and believable in ATS. There are also fewer trucks in ATS but with time there may be more trucks coming as SCS resolves their truck license issues.To me since the game has  Kenworth W900 that alone is enough reason to buy it.The downside is that the fps in ATS varies quite a bit. It goes from 60 fps on highways to 40s at towns' intersections and some portions of cities. It's probably due to its reliance on DirectX9. There are some rumors that SCS intends to port both ETS2 and ATS to DirectX11 but until that happens there's little you can do to mitigate this wild variation in fps, unless perhaps you have an older computer. If you love American setting and enjoy ETS2 you should buy this game. If you love American trucks then this is the game for you.SCS is known to set its DLCs and expansions at fair prices. I'd definitely give my support to these people at SCS. I hope they will port the game to DirectX 11 engine. The sooner, the better."There's nothing logical or economical about American trucks. They perhaps best showcase American excess with their oversized body, poor gas mileage, and tacky gangster-style lighting. Everything about them is romanticized. And that's why you probably love them as I love my Kenworth W900"

This of course would be like a whole seperate mode. Like and advanced game mode for like hard core people, and then what it is now is a Simplified mode. But, yea 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I love driving and now that I'm living in China without a car it is very hard to not be able to drive the open roads of sweet home America.  I've always wanted to maybe be a truck driver.  Well, now I can...sort of.This game is pretty gorgeous.  If you want to drive a truck in a game, then this game is for you.  This isn't a racing game.Some drawbacks/gripes: Signage isn't always the clearest and advance warning is rarely given in terms of speed limit change.  You'll be cruising along at 55+ mph and suddenly the vehicles in front of you were slam on their brakes as the speed limit crashes to 25 to 40 mph for city speeds.  No warning signs like are ACTUALLY found on American roads.There are more little things like that for the trained American eye.  Most players outside of America won't notice.There are a ton of mods for this game which also help to bring it closer to real-life (change generic fake logos, billboards, etc. to real things that for licensing reasons couldn't be put in the game.  I wonder if there is a mod to change Ray's Burgers to McDonald's!)Probably the best experience of this game or any driving game in general would be with a good steering wheel and pedals...alas I don't have one, so I'm forced to play with either the keyboard or my gamepad (which always drifts with the steering).Take your time.  Enjoy it.  Try to avoid falling into the rut I recently fell in!  12 or so good deliveries in and then I just started slipping and crashing my truck all the time.Beautiful game.  If you enjoy simulators and driving (not racing) you will probably put in 10 hours the first day or two you have this game and you'll start to feel fatigued like a real driver!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												ATS may be much smaller in scale than ETS2 but its environments are better designed i.e., prettier and more believable. It is also a bit more challenging with harder drop-off points that you can select for bonus in XP. Smaller gas stations would give you problem to navigate your long trailer in requiring you to be mindful when entering them. There are now police and emergency vehicles that roam the streets which are nice additions for better immersion. The Police would sound their sirene should you violate traffic rules and get yourself fined as a result. Towns and cities are bigger, prettier, and believable in ATS. There are also fewer trucks in ATS but with time there may be more trucks coming as SCS resolves their truck license issues.To me since the game has  Kenworth W900 that alone is enough reason to buy it.The downside is that the fps in ATS varies quite a bit. It goes from 60 fps on highways to 40s at towns' intersections and some portions of cities. It's probably due to its reliance on DirectX9. There are some rumors that SCS intends to port both ETS2 and ATS to DirectX11 but until that happens there's little you can do to mitigate this wild variation in fps, unless perhaps you have an older computer. If you love American setting and enjoy ETS2 you should buy this game. If you love American trucks then this is the game for you.SCS is known to set its DLCs and expansions at fair prices. I'd definitely give my support to these people at SCS. I hope they will port the game to DirectX 11 engine. The sooner, the better."There's nothing logical or economical about American trucks. They perhaps best showcase American excess with their oversized body, poor gas mileage, and tacky gangster-style lighting. Everything about them is romanticized. And that's why you probably love them as I love my Kenworth W900"

												Trivia about this game:1. Some locations in the game look like the same location in real life.2. At the release of this game, there were only 2 trucks in the game called the Kenworth T680 and the Peterbilt 579, however in the "American Truck Simulator - Alpha build 0.1.60 gameplay" video, the Kenworth W900 was included in the game even though it wasn't included at release.3. After the game was released, a limited-time DLC called the "Steampunk Paint Jobs Pack" was available if you followed American Truck Simulator on Steam before it was released.4. Originally, the game was supposed to include only California at release but the release date kept delaying until the Nevada DLC was completed.6. In Los Angeles, the famous sign reads "World of Trucks" instead of "Hollywood" due to copyright issues.

In the end though it doesn't feel as much like an adventure since I know America and the map is scaled so small. I'll definitely come back to ATS in a year once more trucks are added and the map gets larger.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Product received for free
												An addictive game which is a must for any driving enthusiast.I received this game as a gift from a friend just over two weeks ago and in that time, I've put 100 hours and 30000 miles on my truck. It has a healthy modding community, which has made many trucks not available in the base game (4 currently), realism mods with real companies, and more. It is currently in open beta for the 1.5 release which increases the scale of the game.It's hard to put into words what makes this fairly monotonous game so enjoyable as all you do is take a job, hook up a trailer, and then navigate traffic along miles of road to your destination while avoiding fines, damage and being late.So far, all the core DLC has been free, including new trucks, new states and the rescale project to bring the game to 1:20 scale from 1:35 scale. The only paid DLC is cosmetic. Some paint jobs, a steering wheel pack and a rim/hubcap pack.

Hopefully this is somewhat helpful.UPDATE (6/22/16):So far there are two DLCs that came out, the free Arizona DLC and the wheel customization DLC. The Arizona DLC came out fairly recently and honestly speaking SCS actually stepped up their game just a bit but it need a bit more work since there are only 3 states, SCS said they will be covering the entire North American continent. The trucks I want in the game are the Volvo VNL (670-780), Peterbilt 389, Freightliner Cascadia, and the International Lonestar. These trucks are, in my opinion, great trucks. I feel that the Peterbilt 579 is a good truck but it needs more work, so does the Kenworth T680. The Kenworth W900 has great power and handling, it'll take some practice to master the truck itself. My friend and I (whom I'm not naming due to privacy) are currently slowly making a map of New York State, since we are from NYC. Aside from that the game does have a multiplayer version, HOWEVER you must have this game, it has to be on steam, and you must download it seperately on "truckersmp''. If you would like to convoy there is actually a page where you can join a convoy and take jobs. So far so good, SCS keep up the good work. Happy trucking guys!!! UPDATE (11/28/16): The Peterbilt 389 is finally here!!! Also the 3 states, California, Nevada, and Arizona, along with furture states to be made will be in a differnt scale (1:20)!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Definitely recommended if you like driving related games.  This is one of those simple games that has a very addictive playstyle.  So what do you do in ATS?  Do you race?  Drift through mud and smoke your tires?  Run over pedestrians?  No.  You transport cargo from point A to B and earn a profit.  Sounds boring, right?  Somehow, it's not.  If you want to get into more of the business side of trucking, then you can start your own company, hire drivers, buy more rigs, upgrade them, and earn a profit.The driving is more on the realistic side of playing, but not so much that casual players would be intimidated by it.  Don't want to shift gears?  Fine, go with an automatic transmission and worry only about accelerating and braking.  Want to spice it up?  Do a manual transmission, 18 speed gearbox and try to stop on a hill, then get it going again without stalling out.  Turn on speed limits so traffic tickets pile up on you, or, turn them off when they get annoying.Graphics....well, the foliage needs work - I think everyone agrees that is a little dated, but everything else looks good.  And the sky....oh wow, the sky - it's fantastic.  It actually feels refreshing to gaze at the sky when the sun is just peaking over the horizon from an all night drive.  The cities are well-built and feel alive.  I could go on and on, but you get my drift...buy it; buy it now.Rated 9.5/10.P.S. This game caused me to shell out $350+ for a steering wheel + shifter.  I had zero intentions of ever buying one before this game...especially one that expensive.  That has to mean something.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I will try not to be too critical in this review. This game is great, but there are a lot of things that I absolutely cannot stand about it.1. AI Drivers/PoliceThis topic is widely discussed by many players. To me, it feels like SCS was very lazy in creating the AI drivers, which is, in my opinion, one of the most important aspects of the game. The AI drivers are all over the place, and they will take turns when they want to, not when it is safe. I have found this very frustrating when I have lost thousands of dollars because an AI driver took a left turn right into my trailer or when merging onto the highway and that mustang comes and smashes right into the back of you. The police are another big problem in this game. They totally do not care about how fast they are going, but will give you a ticket for going 3 over the limit. I've seen a police car go whizzing by me at 65-70mph in a 55mph speed zone.2. Barriers/Railroad CrossingsThis is another topic that I feel SCS has not taken into account correctly and were very lazy when creating. When coming up on a railroad crossing, if the lights are flashing (but the barriers have not yet dropped down) an invisible barrier is placed where the barriers of the crossing that drop down would go. This makes it very frustrating when I'm going the speed limit of 55-80 mph along the road and the lights start flashing. I know that I don't have enough time to break, so my truck, trailer, and I are all screwed. I usually just pause the game and cancel the delivery because there's nothing I can do about it. Super frustrating driving hundreds of miles just to have it ruined because the creators of the game were lazy.3. Speed Limits/SignsFor one, some of the speed limits are SUPER unrealistic, and wouldn't be considered safe in the real world. But the main thing is the speed limit signs. I try to play this game super realistically and not look at the GPS at all (even though I still have to every couple of minutes), but it just isn't possible. Some speed limit signs read "70mph" when the real speed limit is 55. I usually only go by these signs but I am starting to have to use the GPS more because I am getting unnecessary tickets for going "over the limit". Another problem I have is the change of speed limits. When pulling into a weight station, the speed limit is 15 mph, but you could be traveling on a 55mph highway. Going from 55 to 15 in the small amount of seconds it gives you to do so is nearly impossible, thus me receiving more unnecessary tickets. I find this ridiculous and really think that SCS was very lazy on, again, one of the most important aspects of the game.4. DamageThe damage of the trailers is VERY unrealistic. I made a turn once and the very back tire of the trailer that I was hauling touched the dirt on the side of the road while making the turn. I was INSTANTLY hit with 5% damage on the trailer, all because Wal-Mart had to keep their precious tire all clean. Hitting signs by accident is the same story, except you get about 15% damage instead of 5%, which is super ridiculous. Side swiping a barrier or car will give you a whopping 20-35% damage on your truck and trailer, and don't even get me started about hitting barriers by accident at high speeds...Like I said in the beginning, this is a great game. I just feel that SCS were very lazy with the development and did not take enough time (if any at all) to go over some of the key aspects of the game. I hope you found this review helpful.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												TLDR; I never thought I would buy this game but I am in love now that I have.A note before my review: I laughed out loud when I saw this game on Steam. I hadn't heard of ETS and haven't played simulator games in years. I saw a truck sim game and thought "who the hell wants to drive around and make deliveries in a truck?" Well, apparently I do!I've spent about 4 hours in this game (played the demo for some time before purchasing) and I am hooked. The scenery is gorgeous, controls are great (I recommend using a gamepad), and the game as a whole is so simple that it is amazing. It doesn't waste time overcomplicating things, the game is what it is, drive a truck around and listen to music, make more money and buy more trucks. The map is already large and they are expanding it right now and in a few months it will be much larger. With the potential to add new states down the road you are looking at a gorgeous new game that will continue to expand, grow and improve for years to come.This game is the perfect end to a long day at work. I can go home and just drive around viewing beautiful sunsets and sunrises across some of the best roads in America for cruising. The added ability to listen to internet radio makes it so much better. I personally like driving around jamming to some 80s rock, it's a perfect compliment to life on the road.If you aren't sure if this game will suit you try out the demo, you can get quite a bit of time in it and it's a great way to get used to the controls and decide if it's a game you will enjoy. I recognize that simulators like this might not be for everybody, but if you enjoy sims or driving you will probably love this game.I just can't wait for work to end so I can go home and play some more!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												I love driving and now that I'm living in China without a car it is very hard to not be able to drive the open roads of sweet home America.  I've always wanted to maybe be a truck driver.  Well, now I can...sort of.This game is pretty gorgeous.  If you want to drive a truck in a game, then this game is for you.  This isn't a racing game.Some drawbacks/gripes: Signage isn't always the clearest and advance warning is rarely given in terms of speed limit change.  You'll be cruising along at 55+ mph and suddenly the vehicles in front of you were slam on their brakes as the speed limit crashes to 25 to 40 mph for city speeds.  No warning signs like are ACTUALLY found on American roads.There are more little things like that for the trained American eye.  Most players outside of America won't notice.There are a ton of mods for this game which also help to bring it closer to real-life (change generic fake logos, billboards, etc. to real things that for licensing reasons couldn't be put in the game.  I wonder if there is a mod to change Ray's Burgers to McDonald's!)Probably the best experience of this game or any driving game in general would be with a good steering wheel and pedals...alas I don't have one, so I'm forced to play with either the keyboard or my gamepad (which always drifts with the steering).Take your time.  Enjoy it.  Try to avoid falling into the rut I recently fell in!  12 or so good deliveries in and then I just started slipping and crashing my truck all the time.Beautiful game.  If you enjoy simulators and driving (not racing) you will probably put in 10 hours the first day or two you have this game and you'll start to feel fatigued like a real driver!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												ATS may be much smaller in scale than ETS2 but its environments are better designed i.e., prettier and more believable. It is also a bit more challenging with harder drop-off points that you can select for bonus in XP. Smaller gas stations would give you problem to navigate your long trailer in requiring you to be mindful when entering them. There are now police and emergency vehicles that roam the streets which are nice additions for better immersion. The Police would sound their sirene should you violate traffic rules and get yourself fined as a result. Towns and cities are bigger, prettier, and believable in ATS. There are also fewer trucks in ATS but with time there may be more trucks coming as SCS resolves their truck license issues.To me since the game has  Kenworth W900 that alone is enough reason to buy it.The downside is that the fps in ATS varies quite a bit. It goes from 60 fps on highways to 40s at towns' intersections and some portions of cities. It's probably due to its reliance on DirectX9. There are some rumors that SCS intends to port both ETS2 and ATS to DirectX11 but until that happens there's little you can do to mitigate this wild variation in fps, unless perhaps you have an older computer. If you love American setting and enjoy ETS2 you should buy this game. If you love American trucks then this is the game for you.SCS is known to set its DLCs and expansions at fair prices. I'd definitely give my support to these people at SCS. I hope they will port the game to DirectX 11 engine. The sooner, the better."There's nothing logical or economical about American trucks. They perhaps best showcase American excess with their oversized body, poor gas mileage, and tacky gangster-style lighting. Everything about them is romanticized. And that's why you probably love them as I love my Kenworth W900"

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Trivia about this game:1. Some locations in the game look like the same location in real life.2. At the release of this game, there were only 2 trucks in the game called the Kenworth T680 and the Peterbilt 579, however in the "American Truck Simulator - Alpha build 0.1.60 gameplay" video, the Kenworth W900 was included in the game even though it wasn't included at release.3. After the game was released, a limited-time DLC called the "Steampunk Paint Jobs Pack" was available if you followed American Truck Simulator on Steam before it was released.4. Originally, the game was supposed to include only California at release but the release date kept delaying until the Nevada DLC was completed.6. In Los Angeles, the famous sign reads "World of Trucks" instead of "Hollywood" due to copyright issues.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
												As a man who still is qualified to operate T/T and various lengths, capacities and the like; I must say, I CAN'T STOP PLAYING THIS GAME and I DON'T WANT TO!!!!I've been out of the truck driving world for over 8 years; but since purchasing this game and all the others in the bundle, my desire to return to the real world of trucking is ever increasing.  WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOT!!!  Okay, now to the P&C of the game:PROS:- Physics are almost perfect.- Internet radio makes this even more amazing. Classic Country is my favorite to drive to.- The weather, scenic environment...just gorgous.  I have everything on ULTRA. CONS:- The railing on the weigh stations are difficult to drive over when I arrive to drop a cargo load off.- The traffic AI, could do with some improvement; but still not that bad. Sometimes, the drivers in California, are like those in the game: Lunatics.- Crossing the line as you stop on red, ever so slightly can cause you to get a ticket.  Sometimes.........the "CONS" actually aren't bad, but I just wanted to write minor things.  The game is great.Personal CONS (problems with the game, because of my driving; not the devs):- Writing about the scenic environment, it's easy to almost get into an accident.- The ticket fees are astronomical.  Then again, maybe I should be more careful.**UPDATE: 23 April, 2017**Still playing the game after the new update.  Still not as smooth, although my rig is top notch.  Will skip every now and then, but doesn't crash; then again, I do have a number of MODS.  Mostly real company names, trailers, paint jobs, etc.  Overall, I'm enjoying this game a lot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												I am going to go ahead and give this my recommendation, however this is with a bit of an asterisk Platform of the game has every bit of potential as ETS2, however it almost feels as if the game has started more "gimped" than ETS2 did, in regards to interesting locations to discover and landscape variety. Another issue is that there is very few trucks to choose from. And finally, multiplayer needs a lot more love from the community as it is a relative ghost town, this has made me go back to ETS2 for the moment. Relatively small gripes, since the rest of the gameplay is every bit as enjoyable as ETS2. And once more of the states and a significant amount of trucks are added (hopefully for free, since the amount we have now is unsatisfactory, thus game is not ready for much justified DLC) things should get a lot better. There is one challenge with getting people in America to play.... they need to aggressively advertise this game to people who are in the field of trucking. It's not going to be like ETS2 where even just general gamers were interesting. American crowd is much more of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥in regards to getting them to play simulations. You need to take advantage of the niche crowd more. So hopefully ATS adapts to the new territory with their marketing strategies.***THIS GAME HAS MANY MORE POSITIVES THAN NEGATIVES, IT IS JUST A BIT UNDERWELMING RIGHT NOW***Finally I will say that I would still be playing ATS if the multiplayer crowd was larger, since I like having interaction while I truck. If this is not the kind of thing that will turn you off, then you can subtract that from the negatives.You definitely want to add this, if you are a fan of the series, as soon as financially possible.... since there is a strong chance of great things to come, if ETS2 is any indication. I would not want to be caught out when the game is improved without being able to play it when that day comes. I'll probably come back to this review in 6 to 12 months and update it. If a lot of content is added I will talk about that. If no or little content is added I will change to thumbs down. But these devs have never really let me down yet, so.... there's that. :)  Have a great new year.

												Really fun game. Though something that annoyes the hell out of me is the fact that there is no hose connection still, that one little thing has been bugging me so much. Other than that, it's what you can expect from any game, it has it's up and down. The port is okay, I get major drops in my fps, when I hit cities, and when it rains, etc even though I shouldn't. There is a difference from ETS2, but I can't really say much about that game, cause I hate driving flat nose trucks, so I stopped playing that game a long time ago. It will probaly never happen but, I would love to have a seperate mode to this game or something in the future, that actually provides realism. Like getting out of the truck to connect the trailer, maybe a simplified version of logs, acually wieghing the truck at a truck stop, also, adding stuff like real life DOT regulations. Like only being able to work 14hrs and driving 11hrs. Maybe actually hit the dock to the location that your delivering to, actually opening the doors to the trailer. And when you sleep at a truck stop, ya actually have to get out of the seat and move to the bed. adding an actual shifter. Anyway, those are just a few things. This of course would be like a whole seperate mode. Like and advanced game mode for like hard core people, and then what it is now is a Simplified mode. But, yea 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Probably the best thing I can say about ATS is it's one of the most relaxing games I've played in a long time.  You can just work as a driver for hire, with no worries at all other than arriving on time (which isn't difficult) but even if you start your own company, the economy is such that you won't run into too many problems keeping it going.  Or you can just buy a truck for yourself, not hire anyone and cruise the USA (well...CA, NV and AZ) as an independent owner-operator.  Works best with a wheel of course, but perfectly manageable with a gamepad.  There's a ton of options to set so you can make the game as realistic as you wish.  Can't manage or don't want bothered backing a 53' trailer into a tight spot?  Turn it off.  Realistic air brakes to real?  Turn it off, you get the idea.If you enjoy driving games this is worth the $20 easily.  If you don't enjoy driving games this still might be worth the $20, could get you hooked.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												UPDATED FOR RESCALE UPDATE I wanted to review this game and give it a good one because I like ETS2 and I wanted to support the devs. But, I thought it would not be right to do as (too) many people do and post a review (good or bad) without even taking time to try the game. So I played close to 5h and made at least 5 deliveries with and without owned truck before writing this./!\ I will compare alot with ETS2 so if you are not familiar with this game, probably this review wont be the best so feel free to ask anything in comments below /!\Let's start with short review for those who don't want to read a novel and then I'll give more in depth of my thoughts for those who want to know more (keep in mind those "facts" are my own appreciation of the game and could differ for others):PROS- Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia)- Map- Muuuuurica!- Maneuverability different from ETS2 ---> parking trailer is so much more fun and challenging- Weight stations- Cops- Higher amount of car models- Stop signs (not only red lights anymore)- Can turn right on red light as long as you do a stop before (as in real life eh eh)CONS- Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia)- Map- Cops- Lower amount of truck models- No World of trucks deliveries.. not yet... it's probably coming ;)- no multiplayer --> i hope they'll consider it as the map will grow..Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia) : It is good and bad at same time. Good because this mean you dont need an asskicking new gen high end PC to run this game, which is awesome for those who were running ETS2 on a lower spec computer and wanted badly to put their hands on ATS. For some people, it is a bad thing because they'll say devs didnt made too much work keeping the same game engine. I could agree with this and at same time I would say it's not fair to think they were lazy on this one. Scandinavia is a recent release (may 2015) and they worked hard to improve the engine. In Scandinavia (compared to basic ETS2), the roads are more sophisticated (less boring same looking linear roads), graphics are better, landscapes have way more details and stuff to look at while driving.. Well, overall, Scandinavia was really superior to the basic ETS2 in term of looking and, at least for me, I had a better time driving this part of the Europe. ATS is as detailed and good looking than Scandinavia. In fact, I believe it's even more detailed than Scandinavia. So I dont feel like devs were lazy taking the same engine. In fact, I think they work hard to improve it countinuously. Every update of the engine brings better graphics and more detailed environment. It's just awesome considering that most part of time, you drive straight forward and that your main entertainment is all about admiring landscapes.Map: It is not big right now. Only 2 states. A third is coming for free really soon. And for the rest? who knows. A bad thing for some people because they think the map is too small for the price of the game (and they are afraid SCS asks lot money to unlock the future states and countries)... and at same time, it's a good thing because the scale will be more interesting than ETS2 if they manage to make the whole US + Canada (maybe more if people keep supporting them). It's a huge project. It's a choice to do: will you support them and give money sometime or not? No matter what your choice is, I believe people giving a bad review to this game for the reason it'll cost money in the future, it is just stupid. The base game is pretty cheap. And this project is a big one. People working at SCS need to pay bills, to eat, to pay rent too... you can't expect to get all for free and for a cheap price on top of that. You can decide it's too expensive for you and ok, just don't buy it. But if you buy this game just to complain that it will be probably too much money for you to afford the new DLCs in the future, then you lost me on this one. Think about it before buying because tons of review warns players about this fact. It's nothing new and if you dont like their business model, just don't buy the game. That's it! UPDATE: I was incredibly surprised by this announcement!  They decided, for free, to spend few weeks to rescale all 3 states to have the same scale as ETS2. Wow, just WOW. People have no reasons to complain anymore. They do ask us or money someone but they also know to work without asking more from us. They are damn fair. I cannot consider they are abusing and overpricing anything. Well done SCS. I'm more willing to pay team ever before. Muuuuurica! : A matter of taste.. I prefer american trucks.. and north american landscapes too.. maybe be cause I live here... it feels more like home to me.. maybe.. ;)Cops : It's good to have cops on the road... it gives a reason behind those tickets you were getting randomly. This is the good part of the story, it's more realisitc. Bad part now? The fine is abusively high and you get fined every time you do a mistake. Like I got a fine because I did a "stop" but the game didnt registered it or something so I got a fine. I got a fine for high speed because I was driving downhill at 25mph instead of 15mph (it's hard to break with a full loaded truck in San Fransisco hills lol) and I got fined by an invisible cop... it sucks.. seriously.. it's good to have it but crap.. 1000$ for every mistake and being fined every time you are not perfectly fiting in the square... they could be a bit more nice on this one. Some people said you can turn off fine. I don't agree. I'll try harder to watch speed and do stop as close as what I think the game expect from me... and hope I'll lose less cash in future. LOLHigher amount of car models: They really improved that. You'll see more different cars on the road, small trucks like UPS, Fedex, school bus... no really, way more enjoyable to drive with this higher variety of cars on the roads!Lower amount of truck models: Only 2 models for now... but... they are awaiting authorizations to unlock all models that are ready. They said we would not pay for this, we just need to wait. So for those who are not patient enough and think 2 truck models is not enough, don't purchase now. Just wait a bit longer they got all legal stuff ok so they can add more models (cuz they have already tons of models ready).UPDATE: another truck added. They have several models close to be finished by have to wait for truck companies to approve them. :)Wolrd of trucks UPDATE: Finally here and we had a Christmas event through it again. Thanks SCS :)ConclusionOverall, it's another upgrade of the SCS trucking simulator engine. Is it worth the price? Well if you are a fan of that kind of games, I think it worths it. I paid my 28$CA on release day and I dont regret it. I love ATS way more than ETS2. Sure, devs will have to work to improve and fix many things, but I have trust in them. I know I will get enough stuff for my money. And I know that in the future, they could release map expansions as paid DLC. It is something to consider when you buy it. You know it'll work like this so if you buy, keep it in mind and don't complain they are greedy dlcs ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. They aren't. This is a big project, you have the choice to be an "investor" or not. Personnally, I chose to be one because I like this game, I like the work they do and I want to give them the tools to lead this project to another success.If you decide to join SCS in this epic journey, then I wish you countless hours of happy trucking.

												Now that the American Truck Simulator has been expanded somewhat I feel I can give it a more comprehensive review. The game has stunning views and graphics especially during sunrise and sunset as the light plays across the American landscape. At the current price I recommend picking up the game even though it is incomplete there is more content coming from the developers and they are rescaling the game which should help in the areas where roads feel too tight and small scale for an 18 wheeler to properly drive down. I do wish there were more trucks to select from but the community is pretty great at filling any modders needs. The map also could be bigger but as said at the current price it's appropriate although unfinished. The other thing I wish there was an option for rest and trip planning, whats the purpose of having a cab with sleeper if you can only sleep in designated parking places?. These minor complaints and by far I have spent hours growing my company and managing finances, and most of all rollin' coal on the open roads.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												First things first, I personally enjoy this game and will continue to enjoy this game. Something about being alone with the open road, taking jobs across long distances and sightseeing really relaxes me.So let's get into the game!Profile Creation:It's simple, it's quick, there's not a lot of messing around with it. Give you driver a name, choose a picture from hundres both male & female, Pick a logo and name your company and that's pretty much it.Playing the game:So you've made your profile and are ready to get going. You're going to have to take jobs from the job list as you don't have your own truck yet, meaning you're driving somebody else's truck and taking cargo from point A to point B. Once you get your own truck, you'll be taking jobs from the freight market and picking them up yourself and you will earn a bit more for it. There's a bit of a grind and messing with skills but you'll get there eventually.Vehicles:At the time of this review, there are only 4 different types of trucks to purchase: The Kenworth T680, Kenworth W900, Peterbilt 579 and the Peterbilt 389. Though there are only 4 trucks, the customization on them is fairly good, but parts are locked and you have to unlock them with ranking up.Skills & Ranking:Every job you complete, you gain experience and money. The experience goes towards a level progress bar and new parts and paints will unlock as you level higher into the game. Every level you progress through will give you a point to use in skills, which can be used for Long Distance Cargo, Fragile Cargo, On Time Delivery, High Value Cargo, Dangerous Cargo(ie: flammable, corrosive or explosive) and Fuel Economy. Driving & Parking:Driving with a trailer can be difficult, parking one can be even harder. That's why SCS put in an option to choose between skilled and simple, or if you're truly lazy, skip it entirely(You will lose the added bonus for parking the trailer yourself though)! During your drives, you'll probably find yourself breaking a few laws like Speed Offenses, Traffic Light Offenses, Collision Offenses, Wrong Way Offenses and a few others.Overall Pros and ConsPros-Accurate vehicle recreation-Accurate Simulation-Good amount of customization-Lots of roads to travel and places to goCons-AI Traffic can bug out and create traffic jams(that's really all I can think of)First in depth review I've done of a game so hopefully it wasn't too bad. I hope it helped!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												American Truck Simulator (ATS)This game is a 'must have' for any simulator lover. Forget the 'boring driving sim' attitude of some reviewers as they simply don't get it and seem to compare these games with the action games that they’re used too.The game:Firstly, I must admit that I was very sceptical about this game when I first watched videos and read reviews because the scale was wrong and the game was released with only ONE truck manufacturer and TWO states of America. Simply put, it was not worth the money as a stand- alone game and instead should’ve been a Kickstarter campaign where we all acknowledge that ‘we’ are the backers and testers.But that has changed with the introduction of a third state, and another truck brand (still not enough but much better – and free). But the grand change of the entire game was a recent complete rescale and road fix update that has now opened the gates for constant updating of the game world, including the new states to be added. This was SCS’s plan all along as they could not add more states without this rescale. Also, I must add that this new scaling changed everything, with the time taken on a job tripled in some cases.Graphics:The graphics in general are stunning, with animations everywhere. I particularly like the crop dusters and Raptor jet flyovers, also there are some interesting places like a trailer park dispute with builders, complete with professional ‘hired’ protesters and that crazy dancing guy on a roof. The roads are beautifully textured as well as the fencing, barriers, signage and all bridge structures. The new scale brought with it, much richer textured terrain, and distant objects – the Grand Canyon is stunning.Physics: Are better than anything I have played before in a driving simulator (same as ETS2), although there are some ‘quirks’ here and there but not worth any complaints – watch out for traffic and I am damn sure that they are programmed to be bad divers (pulling out in front of your very heavy rig, or running stop signs ETC). The tyres need to wear out faster as they become ‘nasty’ after 50% and you will lose grip, unfortunately they get repaired with the rest of the truck in service, I think they should have different repairs and effect the game much more. Also the cabs need to move and bounce around, there are mods for this though but the dev’s should fix it.Content: As stated previously, the scale was a big issue and turned many players away, or just kept them glued to European Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) for their main driving game. I won’t go into details about the scale and what was involved (that’s been covered by others in much detail) but I can say that they matched ATS with ETS2 with the amount of actual driving you need to do to arrive at your destination and that was a game changer. Now you must ‘count your gallons’ and watch your driver for signs of fatigue and more than once per trip. Everything else seems to be perfect for my driving style and simulator gameplay. I now wait for the rest of the USA and more trucks. There are more than 1000 mods available and in only one year, plus double that in paint jobs. Many are top quality and worth a try but remember to back up your game save folder, and regularly! Some mods can corrupt your save when removed and that can be painful.Gripes:The damage model for the trailer is way too much of a penalty since rubbing on a curb can cause over $1000 penalty and that needs to change. ETS2 has a nice no-damage mod for your trailer – which works for me as I still pay big money for damage to the rig, so I’m hoping that gets ported over to ATS asap. I also think that people should cause massive damage to your rig when hit, maybe even a fine for endangering life ETC.The game has many mod trucks and many are free, as they should ALL be – I recommend the Volvo VNL670 by Arradeth and try out the triple rear axle option. My best advice for anyone that likes to use mods that are ‘pay-ware’ is to firstly check to see if they are legal and registered mods like all pay-ware must be – EG. With full permission from the manufacturer. If they are not, then just look for those mods for FREE on many sites that also agree with my views about content rules. Pay-ware mods ‘pee’ me off if they are not properly registered and approved. And for those raised eyebrows, I have hundreds of dollars’ worth of pay-ware content that is officially endorsed.Which leads me to my last ‘gripe’ The lack of trucks because of licensing agreements or the lack there of. See my statement above about why I am so angry with some people and the profits they’re making while the game dev’s struggle to get more ‘legal’ content! But I’m sure they will move the ball along faster now that the main reason for the stalling is now sorted (rescale).Conclusion:Go out and buy this game, just do it. For the price, it sits nicely with any other mid-range game and you get a game that can last for years. After buying it, you get free updates to the game world and can try all sorts of community mods to enhance the game play. Remember that there are many negative reviews because they have not been retracted since the rescale released just before Xmas 2016 and probably never will be deleted as many critics tend to like reading their own rants.Enjoy this game for what it is, a simulator. And don’t forget that you will enjoy it better with a steering wheel, I chose the Logitech G920 plus 6 gate shifter and it changed up the game playing style 10 fold.Cheers,Aussie Lee

												I already liked this game a lot (slightly more than Euro Truck Simulator 2, though they're largely the same), but was giving it a bit of a break, waiting for more states to arrive. But then on Black Friday, I upgraded to a force-feedback wheel (the Thrustmaster T150, which I recommend highly), and it was a huge boost to this game. On top of that, now they've changed the scale of the game to make things much larger, and it's wonderful.If you're looking for a relaxing driving game, this is probably the best out there right now. I highly recommend not just a FF wheel, but also TrackIR, and Eyefinity if you can. TrackIR is more important in this game than most driving games, because you'll be checking your mirrors quite a bit.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												So, as a follower of pretty much all of SCS' games, I've pretty much owned all of their games. And I have to say, this game is awesome! So let's go over somethings. First, if you don't like Euro Truck Simulator 2, don't buy this. The GUI's are the exact same and ther only real difference is that this is American. Another thing, if you are impatient and cant do nothing for ten minutes while moving cargo, don't buy this. So, let's get into performance. I own top of the line gaming computers and they have no trouble playing this with every graphics option on high. I own multiple AMD AND NVIDIA gaming computers and they both work perfectly. So AMD Users, don't be afraid. If you have a computer that might not be a gaming computer, I personally don't think I would take the risk. However, you can always get a refund. The graphics (If turned up) are really amazing. And one thing that will make you really impressed is the hills. If you have a solid FPS and I do, going over hills at the same time while turning looks truly amazing. It demonstrates the physics of the game and how much their games have improved. -Pros --Great graphics--Great physics --Realistic--Does not get boring for me--Trucks are awesome--The ability to use pedals,steering wheel, clutch, etc.-Cons--I think that the whole "Damage" thing could be better. For example, I think that car accidents could be taken to another level. If a car pulls out in front of me and I hit it and it ruins my load and I don't get paid and then have to pay for my truck, I don't believe that is fair. --Speed limits should be a little less strictHOWEVER, this is beta and for what they have right now, the game is amazing and I definitely would recommend this.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												A great game. It takes all the pros of ETS 2, like the great physics and realism, and packs them into an American Environment. It even fixes one major con in ETS 2, the detail in the scenery. I own both games, and can definitely say that the detail is miles ahead (pun intended) of its European counterpart. If you like ETS 2, this is a definite buyand my comment to those who say that ATS is a copy of ETS 2, it isn't. Only the UI is the same, and I have a question for them. "Why change something that's already good?" In my opinion, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it!", and that's definitely the approach that SCS Software took towards American Truck Simulator, and it seems to have worked. Being critical towards the game, I dislike the fact that till now, there are only three trucks, and the map is still quite relatively small. However, the developers have said that they will expand the map and add more trucks as time goes by. In fact, they have a free Arizona DLC on the way, which should expand the map quite a bit. Overall, I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												Why did i get this game???Well.. Mainly because i've always liked seeing those big trucks driving by me, So i wondered what it would feel like driving a big tractor trailer, And so i got this!Honestly, I can't say if it's anything like a real truck, But this game does get very very complicating when it comes to parking with your 53' container, And it makes me wonder, Wow! Those guys must really have some good practice! Because if i can't do it here, I for sure wont be able to do it in real life! xDMultiplayer is super fun as well, Driving next to other truck drivers and then honking at them, or meeting new friends, SOME actually truck drivers, and then traveling with them, Stopping to weight your freight, getting gas and such, It's a very fun experience.Honest Rating: 10/10 As of right now, Because I feel like i haven't played enough to experience any problems or bugs, But the game is very fun!! ***ONLY IF YOU LOVE SIMULATOR GAMES, If you don't, Then maybe think twice, But I enjoy simulator games.*** And if you want to give this game a try as your first Simulator game, Then i would recommend it!Recommendable? Yes, I recommend it to people who want to give Simulator games a try, This is a perfect one. (Or Euro Truck Simulator) Although if you're from the USA i recommend this one, Because Euro Truck Simulator has different driving rules than US, So you might get tickets for some things you don't know lol..

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I seriously and highly recommend this simulator to anyone who loves to drive. Graphics are awesome. Game play is quite customizable.  It's fully Modable. (There are already literaly thousands of mods available.) And, at the price they're asking, you really aren't going to find another trucking simulator, (with the exception of ETS2), that will even come close to this. I tend to avoid workshop mods due to the fact that they update while you're in game, and freeze the game. There are a few modding sites that are better, so far, and I hope that SCS corrects the problems with workshop mods, soon. They are more convenient, and, if the problem of them updating while you're in game is addressed, may even become a much better source of mods, eventually. Through mods, you have the ability to drive coast to coast, (with the exception of Hawaii, not, as yet, covered), through Canada, and even down into Baja California. (Mexico) True that the terrain graphics leave a lot to be desired, but, they are only mods, and modders seem to lack the resources to fully do the graphics up to the same quality as SCS does. I have about 6,400 hours on ETS2, and bought this game the day it was released. With nearly 1,400 hours on this "game", (since it's release), it should be obvious that it has overshadowed ETS2 as my favorite "game". (I think I've opened ETS2 twice since purchasing ATS). With future updates, and possible rescaling of the maps, this game will become a force to be reconned with, on the "driving/trucking sim" front. I hope I've been of some help here, in your decision as to whether or not to purchase this title. :) (Not to be rude, but, if you're going to write a review of a game, simulator, or program, you should at least have used it for a lengthy time. I see a lot of people that write reviews with 6 or 7 hours on a program. You've barely scratched the surface, and you seem to think that you know what the program is about. Personally, I wouldn't even think about writing a review before having a minimum of 500 hours on it. Just saying.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												American Truck Simulator (ATS)This game is a 'must have' for any simulator lover. Forget the 'boring driving sim' attitude of some reviewers as they simply don't get it and seem to compare these games with the action games that they’re used too.The game:Firstly, I must admit that I was very sceptical about this game when I first watched videos and read reviews because the scale was wrong and the game was released with only ONE truck manufacturer and TWO states of America. Simply put, it was not worth the money as a stand- alone game and instead should’ve been a Kickstarter campaign where we all acknowledge that ‘we’ are the backers and testers.But that has changed with the introduction of a third state, and another truck brand (still not enough but much better – and free). But the grand change of the entire game was a recent complete rescale and road fix update that has now opened the gates for constant updating of the game world, including the new states to be added. This was SCS’s plan all along as they could not add more states without this rescale. Also, I must add that this new scaling changed everything, with the time taken on a job tripled in some cases.Graphics:The graphics in general are stunning, with animations everywhere. I particularly like the crop dusters and Raptor jet flyovers, also there are some interesting places like a trailer park dispute with builders, complete with professional ‘hired’ protesters and that crazy dancing guy on a roof. The roads are beautifully textured as well as the fencing, barriers, signage and all bridge structures. The new scale brought with it, much richer textured terrain, and distant objects – the Grand Canyon is stunning.Physics: Are better than anything I have played before in a driving simulator (same as ETS2), although there are some ‘quirks’ here and there but not worth any complaints – watch out for traffic and I am damn sure that they are programmed to be bad divers (pulling out in front of your very heavy rig, or running stop signs ETC). The tyres need to wear out faster as they become ‘nasty’ after 50% and you will lose grip, unfortunately they get repaired with the rest of the truck in service, I think they should have different repairs and effect the game much more. Also the cabs need to move and bounce around, there are mods for this though but the dev’s should fix it.Content: As stated previously, the scale was a big issue and turned many players away, or just kept them glued to European Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) for their main driving game. I won’t go into details about the scale and what was involved (that’s been covered by others in much detail) but I can say that they matched ATS with ETS2 with the amount of actual driving you need to do to arrive at your destination and that was a game changer. Now you must ‘count your gallons’ and watch your driver for signs of fatigue and more than once per trip. Everything else seems to be perfect for my driving style and simulator gameplay. I now wait for the rest of the USA and more trucks. There are more than 1000 mods available and in only one year, plus double that in paint jobs. Many are top quality and worth a try but remember to back up your game save folder, and regularly! Some mods can corrupt your save when removed and that can be painful.Gripes:The damage model for the trailer is way too much of a penalty since rubbing on a curb can cause over $1000 penalty and that needs to change. ETS2 has a nice no-damage mod for your trailer – which works for me as I still pay big money for damage to the rig, so I’m hoping that gets ported over to ATS asap. I also think that people should cause massive damage to your rig when hit, maybe even a fine for endangering life ETC.The game has many mod trucks and many are free, as they should ALL be – I recommend the Volvo VNL670 by Arradeth and try out the triple rear axle option. My best advice for anyone that likes to use mods that are ‘pay-ware’ is to firstly check to see if they are legal and registered mods like all pay-ware must be – EG. With full permission from the manufacturer. If they are not, then just look for those mods for FREE on many sites that also agree with my views about content rules. Pay-ware mods ‘pee’ me off if they are not properly registered and approved. And for those raised eyebrows, I have hundreds of dollars’ worth of pay-ware content that is officially endorsed.Which leads me to my last ‘gripe’ The lack of trucks because of licensing agreements or the lack there of. See my statement above about why I am so angry with some people and the profits they’re making while the game dev’s struggle to get more ‘legal’ content! But I’m sure they will move the ball along faster now that the main reason for the stalling is now sorted (rescale).Conclusion:Go out and buy this game, just do it. For the price, it sits nicely with any other mid-range game and you get a game that can last for years. After buying it, you get free updates to the game world and can try all sorts of community mods to enhance the game play. Remember that there are many negative reviews because they have not been retracted since the rescale released just before Xmas 2016 and probably never will be deleted as many critics tend to like reading their own rants.Enjoy this game for what it is, a simulator. And don’t forget that you will enjoy it better with a steering wheel, I chose the Logitech G920 plus 6 gate shifter and it changed up the game playing style 10 fold.Cheers,Aussie Lee

												As a fan of simulation games, ATS really brought the fun of driving a truck into reality! I've spent countless hours getting all the achievements and discovering 100% of the map. content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												A nice relaxing game if you want to chill, and it is very easy to play even if you do not have a lot of "sim game" experience. Suggest using some sort of analog controls like an xbox controller, but have a mouse an kb close by as the interface is not 100% compatible with just a controller. For example, some menus require you moving a mouse cursor with the controller if you do not have a mouse handy.  Only real gripe is the AA; the only choice is "MLAA".  It's awful as far as smoothing goes. I'm running it at 4434 x 2494 DSR on a 2560x1440 panel (still 60fps on gtx 1080 at max settings) and I can still see modest jaggies. Not a deal breaker, but more advanced AA options would be nice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												First things first, I personally enjoy this game and will continue to enjoy this game. Something about being alone with the open road, taking jobs across long distances and sightseeing really relaxes me.So let's get into the game!Profile Creation:It's simple, it's quick, there's not a lot of messing around with it. Give you driver a name, choose a picture from hundres both male & female, Pick a logo and name your company and that's pretty much it.Playing the game:So you've made your profile and are ready to get going. You're going to have to take jobs from the job list as you don't have your own truck yet, meaning you're driving somebody else's truck and taking cargo from point A to point B. Once you get your own truck, you'll be taking jobs from the freight market and picking them up yourself and you will earn a bit more for it. There's a bit of a grind and messing with skills but you'll get there eventually.Vehicles:At the time of this review, there are only 4 different types of trucks to purchase: The Kenworth T680, Kenworth W900, Peterbilt 579 and the Peterbilt 389. Though there are only 4 trucks, the customization on them is fairly good, but parts are locked and you have to unlock them with ranking up.Skills & Ranking:Every job you complete, you gain experience and money. The experience goes towards a level progress bar and new parts and paints will unlock as you level higher into the game. Every level you progress through will give you a point to use in skills, which can be used for Long Distance Cargo, Fragile Cargo, On Time Delivery, High Value Cargo, Dangerous Cargo(ie: flammable, corrosive or explosive) and Fuel Economy. Driving & Parking:Driving with a trailer can be difficult, parking one can be even harder. That's why SCS put in an option to choose between skilled and simple, or if you're truly lazy, skip it entirely(You will lose the added bonus for parking the trailer yourself though)! During your drives, you'll probably find yourself breaking a few laws like Speed Offenses, Traffic Light Offenses, Collision Offenses, Wrong Way Offenses and a few others.Overall Pros and ConsPros-Accurate vehicle recreation-Accurate Simulation-Good amount of customization-Lots of roads to travel and places to goCons-AI Traffic can bug out and create traffic jams(that's really all I can think of)First in depth review I've done of a game so hopefully it wasn't too bad. I hope it helped!

Every level you progress through will give you a point to use in skills, which can be used for Long Distance Cargo, Fragile Cargo, On Time Delivery, High Value Cargo, Dangerous Cargo(ie: flammable, corrosive or explosive) and Fuel Economy. Driving & Parking:Driving with a trailer can be difficult, parking one can be even harder.
