number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												American Truck Simulator (ATS)This game is a 'must have' for any simulator lover. Forget the 'boring driving sim' attitude of some reviewers as they simply don't get it and seem to compare these games with the action games that they’re used too.The game:Firstly, I must admit that I was very sceptical about this game when I first watched videos and read reviews because the scale was wrong and the game was released with only ONE truck manufacturer and TWO states of America. Simply put, it was not worth the money as a stand- alone game and instead should’ve been a Kickstarter campaign where we all acknowledge that ‘we’ are the backers and testers.But that has changed with the introduction of a third state, and another truck brand (still not enough but much better – and free). But the grand change of the entire game was a recent complete rescale and road fix update that has now opened the gates for constant updating of the game world, including the new states to be added. This was SCS’s plan all along as they could not add more states without this rescale. Also, I must add that this new scaling changed everything, with the time taken on a job tripled in some cases.Graphics:The graphics in general are stunning, with animations everywhere. I particularly like the crop dusters and Raptor jet flyovers, also there are some interesting places like a trailer park dispute with builders, complete with professional ‘hired’ protesters and that crazy dancing guy on a roof. The roads are beautifully textured as well as the fencing, barriers, signage and all bridge structures. The new scale brought with it, much richer textured terrain, and distant objects – the Grand Canyon is stunning.Physics: Are better than anything I have played before in a driving simulator (same as ETS2), although there are some ‘quirks’ here and there but not worth any complaints – watch out for traffic and I am damn sure that they are programmed to be bad divers (pulling out in front of your very heavy rig, or running stop signs ETC). The tyres need to wear out faster as they become ‘nasty’ after 50% and you will lose grip, unfortunately they get repaired with the rest of the truck in service, I think they should have different repairs and effect the game much more. Also the cabs need to move and bounce around, there are mods for this though but the dev’s should fix it.Content: As stated previously, the scale was a big issue and turned many players away, or just kept them glued to European Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) for their main driving game. I won’t go into details about the scale and what was involved (that’s been covered by others in much detail) but I can say that they matched ATS with ETS2 with the amount of actual driving you need to do to arrive at your destination and that was a game changer. Now you must ‘count your gallons’ and watch your driver for signs of fatigue and more than once per trip. Everything else seems to be perfect for my driving style and simulator gameplay. I now wait for the rest of the USA and more trucks. There are more than 1000 mods available and in only one year, plus double that in paint jobs. Many are top quality and worth a try but remember to back up your game save folder, and regularly! Some mods can corrupt your save when removed and that can be painful.Gripes:The damage model for the trailer is way too much of a penalty since rubbing on a curb can cause over $1000 penalty and that needs to change. ETS2 has a nice no-damage mod for your trailer – which works for me as I still pay big money for damage to the rig, so I’m hoping that gets ported over to ATS asap. I also think that people should cause massive damage to your rig when hit, maybe even a fine for endangering life ETC.The game has many mod trucks and many are free, as they should ALL be – I recommend the Volvo VNL670 by Arradeth and try out the triple rear axle option. My best advice for anyone that likes to use mods that are ‘pay-ware’ is to firstly check to see if they are legal and registered mods like all pay-ware must be – EG. With full permission from the manufacturer. If they are not, then just look for those mods for FREE on many sites that also agree with my views about content rules. Pay-ware mods ‘pee’ me off if they are not properly registered and approved. And for those raised eyebrows, I have hundreds of dollars’ worth of pay-ware content that is officially endorsed.Which leads me to my last ‘gripe’ The lack of trucks because of licensing agreements or the lack there of. See my statement above about why I am so angry with some people and the profits they’re making while the game dev’s struggle to get more ‘legal’ content! But I’m sure they will move the ball along faster now that the main reason for the stalling is now sorted (rescale).Conclusion:Go out and buy this game, just do it. For the price, it sits nicely with any other mid-range game and you get a game that can last for years. After buying it, you get free updates to the game world and can try all sorts of community mods to enhance the game play. Remember that there are many negative reviews because they have not been retracted since the rescale released just before Xmas 2016 and probably never will be deleted as many critics tend to like reading their own rants.Enjoy this game for what it is, a simulator. And don’t forget that you will enjoy it better with a steering wheel, I chose the Logitech G920 plus 6 gate shifter and it changed up the game playing style 10 fold.Cheers,Aussie Lee

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I guess it's time for my review!Stability / Polishing / Performance:The game is not crazily polished, but it works well and has no major bugs as far as I was able to tell.It's performance is compared to other games rather underwhelming, but it should work on most systems.Graphics:The graphics aren't all that great.The texture resolution is good, the overall quality of the textures is also fine.But when it comes to complex lighting effects the game doesn't necessarily match today's industry standards.However it doesn't look "ugly".Gameplay:The game is very detailed when it comes to the controls.The physics aren't so bad given it's not aiming for damage models or any fancy stuff.It shows it's muscles when it comes to simulating a lively AI driven traffic world.Eventhough the AI sometimes acts outrageously stupid, there are few games one could compare this game with, but I'd dare to say the AI here is still the smartest, given that (nearly) no other game tries to accurately simulate normal every-day traffic! (even GTA with a much higher budget has NPCs blowing each other up just by accident - this doen't happen here)The game also has a little background simulation going on for the player's company, which I'd like to recommend to focus on in later titles, since it shows some potential in my opinion.Models / Game World:The truck models are very detailed and look nicely, if you don't look too closely at the big headlights you can mount at the bumper and the roof of your truck (those have just a plain texture).The AI cars don't look too shabby either.The game world itself is a little lack-luster.Eventhough they made great improvements compared to the previous title, it's still partially in medieval-ages of game development with sprite-based distant flora and some simplistic general design.Cities don't consist of much more than a few steets.However I believe the game has something to it.You could consider it to be one of those "zen" games that you can just use to relax while playing.It has a progress system, a (downloadable) multiplayer and steam workshop support, which already addresses a whole bunch of the previous critique and if you feel adventurous, you should look around on the internet, there are plenty more other mods that address even more things of the game - I believe there's even one or two complete game world replacers   and add-ons out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												I seriously and highly recommend this simulator to anyone who loves to drive. Graphics are awesome. Game play is quite customizable.  It's fully Modable. (There are already literaly thousands of mods available.) And, at the price they're asking, you really aren't going to find another trucking simulator, (with the exception of ETS2), that will even come close to this. I tend to avoid workshop mods due to the fact that they update while you're in game, and freeze the game. There are a few modding sites that are better, so far, and I hope that SCS corrects the problems with workshop mods, soon. They are more convenient, and, if the problem of them updating while you're in game is addressed, may even become a much better source of mods, eventually. Through mods, you have the ability to drive coast to coast, (with the exception of Hawaii, not, as yet, covered), through Canada, and even down into Baja California. (Mexico) True that the terrain graphics leave a lot to be desired, but, they are only mods, and modders seem to lack the resources to fully do the graphics up to the same quality as SCS does. I have about 6,400 hours on ETS2, and bought this game the day it was released. With nearly 1,400 hours on this "game", (since it's release), it should be obvious that it has overshadowed ETS2 as my favorite "game". (I think I've opened ETS2 twice since purchasing ATS). With future updates, and possible rescaling of the maps, this game will become a force to be reconned with, on the "driving/trucking sim" front. I hope I've been of some help here, in your decision as to whether or not to purchase this title. :) (Not to be rude, but, if you're going to write a review of a game, simulator, or program, you should at least have used it for a lengthy time. I see a lot of people that write reviews with 6 or 7 hours on a program. You've barely scratched the surface, and you seem to think that you know what the program is about. Personally, I wouldn't even think about writing a review before having a minimum of 500 hours on it. Just saying.)

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												As a fan of simulation games, ATS really brought the fun of driving a truck into reality! I've spent countless hours getting all the achievements and discovering 100% of the map. In the end though, I did it! One thing though, the constant truck driving is REALLY boring after a while. You can fix that problem though by buying your own truck and go on sightseeing! Also, you can go to the Steam workshop for this and download a few mods, one such mod being no damage, and another being advanced transmissions! So I can drive around going 163mph and not get damaged! This game is truly worth your buck though, that is though if you make the best out of it! I can't wait until the next one! Maybe it will be Canadian Truck Simulator, or Asian Truck Simulator! We can only guess the possiblities!                          12 out of 10, one of the best games I've ever played!

content:
Posted: January 9
												I am going to go ahead and give this my recommendation, however this is with a bit of an asterisk Platform of the game has every bit of potential as ETS2, however it almost feels as if the game has started more "gimped" than ETS2 did, in regards to interesting locations to discover and landscape variety. Another issue is that there is very few trucks to choose from. And finally, multiplayer needs a lot more love from the community as it is a relative ghost town, this has made me go back to ETS2 for the moment. Relatively small gripes, since the rest of the gameplay is every bit as enjoyable as ETS2. And once more of the states and a significant amount of trucks are added (hopefully for free, since the amount we have now is unsatisfactory, thus game is not ready for much justified DLC) things should get a lot better. There is one challenge with getting people in America to play.... they need to aggressively advertise this game to people who are in the field of trucking. It's not going to be like ETS2 where even just general gamers were interesting. American crowd is much more of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥in regards to getting them to play simulations. You need to take advantage of the niche crowd more. So hopefully ATS adapts to the new territory with their marketing strategies.***THIS GAME HAS MANY MORE POSITIVES THAN NEGATIVES, IT IS JUST A BIT UNDERWELMING RIGHT NOW***Finally I will say that I would still be playing ATS if the multiplayer crowd was larger, since I like having interaction while I truck. If this is not the kind of thing that will turn you off, then you can subtract that from the negatives.You definitely want to add this, if you are a fan of the series, as soon as financially possible.... since there is a strong chance of great things to come, if ETS2 is any indication. I would not want to be caught out when the game is improved without being able to play it when that day comes. I'll probably come back to this review in 6 to 12 months and update it. If a lot of content is added I will talk about that. If no or little content is added I will change to thumbs down. But these devs have never really let me down yet, so.... there's that. :)  Have a great new year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Pros-Realistic Highway numbers-Realistic speed limits-Fun-Same graphics engine at ETS2, so it is an easy transition.-Mods are part of Steam Workshop, so they are guaranteed virus-free.Cons-Same graphics engine as ETS2, so a bit disappointing.-Scaled WAY the f**k down, so it is not really a big map. Much smaller than ETS2. -Only Peterbuilt and Kenworth, and only 1 Peterbuilt truck. Limited options of 3 total trucks to choose from. -The cops are total Nazis, and totally unrealistic. 1 over is a 500 fine. WTFYes, the game is still in early stages. Yes, I expected more of a map. It is called American Truck Simulator, yet it only has 3 of the 50 states. A bit of a drawback. There will be updates, so there is that to look forward to. All in all, I would say it is a solid game and I would recommend it to anybody who likes ETS2.

Posted: April 22
												I have played all of the other SCS American based Truck Simulators. And I've been dying for something updated like this for quite some time.Glad it finally made it to Steam too. The mods are easier to find and install than the previous games were. And you get updates automatically from the developer instead of having to go to the website to download a patch.It does need more trucks; like Freightliner, Western Star, Caterpillar, Mack, and others. And not the ones that are from the workshop either. I'd like to see actual classics from the 70's to the 90's too.Even if you do or don't like trucks. This is a simulator that really does well and isn't some cheap rip off. I have my CDL and this helps me when I am not driving because here I can make mistakes that you can't in real life.I think this would also make a great VR game too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												What has the gaming world come to when a Truck Simulator becomes fun?It sounds negative doesn't it? But that was my first thought when I saw this game.I played it, then I asked myself the same question.Well, it seems the gaming world is exactly where it needs to be. On the cutting edge of brilliant minds and pushing the limits of incredible technology!This game hooked me from the start. It's not just a bunch of poorly rendered boxes on wheels floating through an open-world, demolition derby scenario.I come at this game from two different points-of-view. I am a life-long artist and graphic designer, so visuals are very important to me in a game, but I also have my CDL and spent many years over-the-road in these trucks. After getting in a truck and driving a few blocks, the first thing I noticed was an incredibly detailed world around me! Turns out, this is what is actually keeping me coming back for more. All of the vehicles in-game look incredible, which is what I expected, it's a Truck Driving Simulation game after all! However, the world generated around me, positively blew me away!  I found myself going off the road a few times because I was trying to look over at some of the scenes happening out my window as I'm driving by!I won't go into any depth about the looks of the game, you just need to see it for yourself. Simply put, visually it's an incredible game and you'll have plenty to look at as the world goes by.The handling of the trucks seems to be truly accurate, with truck-specific mechanics, right down to the horrible turning radius of the W900! This is truly a simulator, I find myself driving the trucks in-game, the same way I would in real life!The AI drivers in-game are a little crazy, they randomly ruin your day in a hurry. Stopping on a 80 MPH freeway for no reason or turning right  smack into you at an intersection. I think this is just an AI system in need of  a few minor tweaks, but I found it actually adds to the realism of driving giant trucks around total idiots all day!Really the only con I have found in the game are the speeding penalties. There's not much room for error, if you are near a police officer when the speed limits lowers, you need to be at the correct speed before you pass that sign! I have paid about $20,000 in fines so far just from not seeing the speed limit change soon enough.The devs seem to be VERY involved in rolling out updates and fixes, and also appear regularly in the forums answering peoples questions and concerns. This is one of the most important details of a game for me, if the devs don't care, then why should I? They sure seem to care in this case.I would most certainly recommend this game to others. I can't get enough of it! My 12 year-old son was even quickly addicted to this game, after making fun of me for playing a "Truck Simulator" of course!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												My initial impression with the game so far is very positive. It might be *too* close to ETS2, but I see that in a good way. They kept all the good stuff from ETS2 and improved a bit on top of it and then fed back that to ETS2. I would totally recommend the purchase if you like ETS2, but I would tell you to lower the expectations of a "new game" altogether.The game has a lot of potential. The US of A is a great place to truck (as proven from 18WOS-Haulin' and the original 18WOS-PTTM) and you can start thinking on expanding to Canada and Mexico (Haulin' had both IIRC). California and Nevada are good places to start, but it feels like the game needs more and soon. And when the DLCs come forth, I hope they are like ETS2: a decent chunk of map and places for ~$5 USD. For me, Cali and Nevada are $5USD.In terms of mechanics, the game is basically the same as ETS2. I did not notice any differences in how the truck feels using the same settings (disabling helps, basically). I do appreciate the new "select your parking" and some are pretty darn hard, but they become repetitive. If they could implement something more "random" to each location, would be amazing. Also, I am expecting them to put the Online Job Offerings component in ATS soon as well. I found it really interesting in ETS2 and I have come to like it a lot.The only disappointment I have with the game, is graphics/art wise. I expected an improved map render, but it looks and feels the same as ETS2; they both feel dated as you see the images in front of you, but still keep being surpised with stunning landscapes and detailed locations with what the engine lets them do. Now that they have the game out and put a DLC or two, I hope their new north is improving the Simulation part first and Graphics component second. Bonus points to SCS for making it a native 64bit client as well!8.5/10!Update: 5th of April 2016After playing it for a long long time now (less than ETS2 though), and adding a few mods, the game improved quite a bit. The cops are still ruthless, ticketing left and right. The AI is still a bit dorky at times and there are a few things to still be improved, but I back up my original statement that this is a worthy buy. Just like wine, with time this game will just get better and better.Plus, I have been playing it with my G27 using the range H shifter and clutch. Just amazing.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Ok, the game is not bad, it's pretty good. I enjoy the ATS trucks a lot comparing to ETS but this game just like ETS2 has some very common issues.  Hopefully SCS can address these and hire some people who can write/script better.  I say the game is not bad but that's because I've invested a lot of hours into ETS2. I also have a review up for that game.Please fix the following.1) Resting for 10 hours? really? Who sleeps for 10 hours? Allow us to rest as many hours as we want please and wherever we want. What's the truck cabin for if not to rest?2) Allow purchasing trucks online right from the start3) Need better traffic AI in intersections especially. Many times I need to restart the game so the intersection is empty otherwise I'd be standing there for hours or I simply have to stick myself out into traffic like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and make them stop so I can enter.4) Better support for graphics. I run a brand new skylake build with a 980ti (2k res, 1 screen, 60fps) and I often get massive drops in FPS during weather or while in a city.I do recommend this game and I also love and recommend ETS2 but this game can be so much better if some minor tweaks were implemented to offer more realism for the player.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												For $20 bucks this game far exceeds any expectations. ATS provides a uniqe view into the world of a truck driver from just getting your CDL and driving loaner or company trucks to buying your first truck and becoming an Owner/ Operator. This game doesnt exactly scream excitement and if your coming from a FPS you may be initialy disapointed, but the steady hum of the diesel engine and the whine of the tires on the highway will suck you in, and if that doesnt do it for ya, take a cruise up high way 1 and take a look at the STUNNING scenery they've put into this game. The only addition I would like to see to this game would be to add buyable trailers so you can haul loads with your own truck and trailer and make more mola!!  18 WOS had this and Id really like to see it in this evolution.All that said if your into driving sims, or want to try it out and see if its in your interest I absolutly recommend this game as it is a fine example of quality content and involved developers.I strongly recomend using a decent quality racing wheel or at a minimum a game pad (I currently use an xbox one controller) to get the most out of this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												I had anticipated this title for some time .... just like many others in the community.I bought the game at the first opportunity to do so and was nicely surprised to see the game load into my steam account a day earlier than I expected.Now there is a case of the older sibling casting a shadow on the new family member and I feel ATS still has to come out from under the shadow ETS2 casts and stand on it's own two feet.That said, I won't sugar-coat my first impressions .... I was a bit deflated personally. I'd run 450 hrs+ in ETS2 and created over 260 YouTube videos .... I really enjoyed ETS2 and expected to take up from a similar position with ATS from the start. I found that ATS ticked the boxes well initially but seems to lack something that made it a 'standing on it's own feet' title. It really felt very much like an add-on to ETS2 to be honest. The thing is, it's not an addon ... and with a little more time and support from SCS which is already coming ... it'll surely mature into another AAA title for SCS. But it's not quite there yet for two main reasons ...1) The map currently is 3 states (actually 2 but Arizona is but a week or two away from release). I don't clearly understand what to expect for the remainder of USA and then what the plans may be for Canada and Mexico. 2) Truck makes and models. We've got Peterbilt and Kenworth today and no clear indications on the roadmap for all the other brands.On a positive note, SCS have upped the communication with the community. It was always best in class and in recent weeks, they seem to upped their standards again. Maybe I had too much in terms of expectation but I feel that community has generally communicated a similar message back to SCS based on the size of the map and range of trucks available.It's mid May 2016 as I write this review and I'm ~60 hrs into ATS.  All signs are pointing firmly towards 100's of hrs in this title.  I've enjoyed the Kenworth W900 truck I'm driving and I've explored a lot of the California and Nevada map that SCS opened with. Arizona will help immensely and I'm looking forward impatiently to being able to drive to the East coast.Now SCS have always been modder friendly and it's this community that enhances a players experience so often in games today. ATS is no exception and kudos to SCS again for their support.If I recall the release days of ETS2, way back when ..... and look today at what ETS2 developed into today, I would say that ATS is on a similar track ... so the future looks pretty good. The community wants faster updates and is impatient as ever which in my opinion highlight two things .... a. a call to action for SCS on ATSb. confirmation to SCS of the passion and energy the community has for ATSSo if you're looking at ATS reviews and trying to decide if it makes sense for you to buy it, my recommendation is Yes, buy it ... it's another great title in the SCS stable and it really does give the player a sense of driving an 'American' truck in an American landscape. ATS is the only place that offers this truly American trucking experience and the future is full of potential.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I was a bit hesitant to buy this game after reading the reviews about the map scaling being wonky compared to ETS2. I actually waited a week or so after release, then decided to go ahead and buy it. I have zero regrets. This game is absolutely enjoyable, as it is an entirely different experience driving in ATS than it is ETS2. I still play ETS2, and will always have a fond love for that game. The graphics are gorgeous, the trucks are even more so, and if you're new to ETS/ETS2/ATS, then I highly recommend you buy this (even ETS2, while you're at it). I have few gripes about the game, including the map scaling which really doesn't bother me all that much; the on-ramps on freeways are extremely short and not at all realistic, but again it doesn't detract from the game as a whole. Perhaps my biggest gripe would be the lack of states out of the gate. I understand there is a lot behind this game already, however, Arizona is the last free DLC that will be added to the game, which is still a few months away from release. It would have been nice if SCS would have done the entire Western United States as free DLC, maybe Arizona, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Wyoming, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon. Then had gone from there, just so there is quite a lot of distance to cover while they work on cranking out the paid DLC. Regardless, I love this game. While I have low hours played on it, don't let that deter you any. I play a variety of other games and love to give them equal attention. If you're able to, I suggest getting a steering wheel with pedals to add to that realistic touch. I play on a gaming laptop, so I have to use the keyboard which if you don't have the option of getting a steering wheel, still get this. Keyboard is still fun and the only thing you may have trouble with is backing the trailer up into position. I know this review is a bit scatter brained, and I apologize if it is a hard read. I hope with the paid DLC that they do it in regions, such as Mid-West, Eastern, etc., and not state-by-state. The game itself is $20, so I am hoping that the paid DLC stays under that price range. Get this game. You'll enjoy it, and have a blast.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												This game is just amazing! I play this game just to relax and take my mind off of stuff.If you enjoy simulators then this game is a great game to add to your list. It is pretty realistic and very detailed graphics wise. It has mod support (one of which is a multiplayer mod that I'll decribe as well). Regarding mods: Say you don't like the slim choices of trucks (which keep in mind they are adding more trucks and even more states soon), but you can just download a different truck design or even a car if you don't want to drive a truck. In regards to the Mp mod: I will say that it doesnt have ai which is good and bad because no ai driving around means less lag with other players and not having to deal with stupid ai (which you still have to deal with some stupid player not understanding the physics or how its a simulator or whatever the reason is). What's bad about not having ai is that in this game the only way of getting fined for speeding is by cops (there are very little speed cameras), so people just decide to break all the laws because they can't get punished (or they don't care). And it's not like admin aren't there moderating it because they are. All in all I would say to get this game but if simulators aren't your thing then just go play your shooters or whatever you find joy out of because this game needs more serious people especially in Mp. 9/10

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												I had anticipated this title for some time .... just like many others in the community.I bought the game at the first opportunity to do so and was nicely surprised to see the game load into my steam account a day earlier than I expected.Now there is a case of the older sibling casting a shadow on the new family member and I feel ATS still has to come out from under the shadow ETS2 casts and stand on it's own two feet.That said, I won't sugar-coat my first impressions .... I was a bit deflated personally. I'd run 450 hrs+ in ETS2 and created over 260 YouTube videos .... I really enjoyed ETS2 and expected to take up from a similar position with ATS from the start. I found that ATS ticked the boxes well initially but seems to lack something that made it a 'standing on it's own feet' title. It really felt very much like an add-on to ETS2 to be honest. The thing is, it's not an addon ... and with a little more time and support from SCS which is already coming ... it'll surely mature into another AAA title for SCS. But it's not quite there yet for two main reasons ...1) The map currently is 3 states (actually 2 but Arizona is but a week or two away from release). I don't clearly understand what to expect for the remainder of USA and then what the plans may be for Canada and Mexico. 2) Truck makes and models. We've got Peterbilt and Kenworth today and no clear indications on the roadmap for all the other brands.On a positive note, SCS have upped the communication with the community. It was always best in class and in recent weeks, they seem to upped their standards again. Maybe I had too much in terms of expectation but I feel that community has generally communicated a similar message back to SCS based on the size of the map and range of trucks available.It's mid May 2016 as I write this review and I'm ~60 hrs into ATS.  All signs are pointing firmly towards 100's of hrs in this title.  I've enjoyed the Kenworth W900 truck I'm driving and I've explored a lot of the California and Nevada map that SCS opened with. Arizona will help immensely and I'm looking forward impatiently to being able to drive to the East coast.Now SCS have always been modder friendly and it's this community that enhances a players experience so often in games today. ATS is no exception and kudos to SCS again for their support.If I recall the release days of ETS2, way back when ..... and look today at what ETS2 developed into today, I would say that ATS is on a similar track ... so the future looks pretty good. The community wants faster updates and is impatient as ever which in my opinion highlight two things .... a. a call to action for SCS on ATSb. confirmation to SCS of the passion and energy the community has for ATSSo if you're looking at ATS reviews and trying to decide if it makes sense for you to buy it, my recommendation is Yes, buy it ... it's another great title in the SCS stable and it really does give the player a sense of driving an 'American' truck in an American landscape. ATS is the only place that offers this truly American trucking experience and the future is full of potential.

content:
Posted: March 30
												I have been a lifelong fan of SCS' 18 Wheels of Steel series and their subsequent "simulators" franchise. Overall, I think this game is pretty solid. The graphics are fantastic if you can handle them, and include a great deal of realistic aspects carried over from ETS2 which I appreciate as well as the eventual reference or item from the 18 WoS series. While the game itself runs pretty smoothly with a decent gaming computer and the gameplay aspects are the quality we expect from SCS, the expansion (in other words, the map) and the amount of time the game is taking to expand north and west is well, unexcusable. While the game's graphics are indubitably fantastic, I cannot help but feel short changed by the time its taking to expand the map and the fact expansion DLC costs. I can only help but hearken back to the days of old SCS, when despite their team's only slight exposure and small size milked out flawed, but memorable, and well formatted games from my childhood like Convoy and PTTM etc that came out with a host of (despite not having licenses) realistic trucks and a fantastic fully completed map. Now, with the immense success both monetarily from ETS2 and the huge team they have gotten in the process ATS not only took longer than first imagined to release... but it was released with 2 states... Despite the fact they are both immensely detailed and their are few to no kinks in the gameplay, they have since released ONE new state, Arizona, that was thankfully free that was promised to be out "soon" at original release which ended up taking months. Not to mention, they are currently still months into the process of expanding into New Mexico... In my opinion, with a team as great as theirs they need to be less focused on lackluster "paint job" DLCs (maybe not the free ones...) and start going all systems go into expansion that should be free in compensation or do something like the "Going East!" DLC from ETS2 in which they just release a whole region at one low cost. But other that, I recommend for being good quality SCS gaming and pretty relaxing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												So after 35 hours in the game, I think I can finally review it properly. At first you might see this and think it's just a mod for Euro Truck Simulator 2, it has the same UI, the same idea, and the same feel as ETS2. However, it is so much more. There is not a ton of content at the moment (three states, and a few trucks with several different layout to choose from), but like ETS2 there are tons of mods. Even though there's not much content right now what is there is solid, the map design has improved massively since ETS2 due to the fact that the devs have gotten better at making them. It is a ton of fun to drive around the US and if you don't think it's worth the money now, just wait a while until they have completed more states. Something also to note is they just announced a map rescale, so all of you people who think the map is to small right now, you will soon be satisfied. I hope this review helped!

If you're new to the series then give the demo a try.If you're coming from Euro Truck Simulator 2, youll love this one too!The game is still a work-in-progress though so expect more cities, states & other content to be coming out in the near furture.TL:DRAbsolutely Fantastic, worth every penny, buy it NOW!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												2nd day playing this game. I played the heck out of ETS2 and was looking forward to this for a very long time. I actually took a day off work on the release date. Yes, this is the same game as ETS2. But it is a different world to explore and build a company in and very well done from what i have seen so far. I have explored probably about 30% of the map i'd guess, and continue to smile checking out this new world! There is tons to see. The cities are bigger and more interesting. there are more small details like tumbleweed and events in the sky (no spoilers). The built in radio stations are fantastic and only add to the immersion and adventure. I suspect many of those complaining about size of the map went straight for the "Level 100 unlimited cash" mod, because playing the game as intended i'm having a blast and still have tons on my "to-do" list. Even then, the replay factor is huge, especially with mods.There are, in-fact,  improvements over ETS2 as well. The new parking system is a nice addition. Optimization is better - I can run triples on higher settings with much less slow down. Quick saves no longer pause the action briefly. Police now roam the streets. I see more animations about the world.It would be nice to see a shiny new graphics engine for this game, but given the end goal of SCS to create a massive online virtual world representing real geography the likes of which gamers have never seen at this level of detail, I support the decision to continue to use this engine. If you have the PC to run shiny new games, chances are you can run this on high settings where it looks great anyway. Triples + TrackIR + cup of coffee = casual driving heaven.At $20, it's also a great value i'd say. I highly recommend this if you enjoy open world driving. Also, with a manual clutch FFB wheel and trackIR the game really gets immersive.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Driving the roads, blasting the radio, hauling A$$! Well thats the point of this game, Its a driving sim at its finest. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a semi (get it? lol) relaxing driving game. I said semi though because if you do not follow the traffic laws (which can be turned off) and avoid the other drivers (that are seemingly soccer moms) the game can be a real challenge. The scenery going down the road is nice as well. Would love to see a few more in depth things added such as current market trends (Right now it seems you haul the same thing over and over if you just want to make the big bucks). Also, other than being able to customize your truck its actually better to just drive for a company. Much easier to make the cash. Adding in Multiplayer (which is currently only available in MOD form) would have made this game even better. So what are you waiting for? Get out on that Road now!7 out of 10 Overall a solid game but could be fleshed out a bit more as well as some multiplayer support, Also future maps will be DLC so the game has potential to become a moneygrab.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
												What made me buy this game in the first place is that I was playing GTA 5 and really enjoyed playing taxi, but really wanted a game that was more realistic in terms of actually driving around. Having never played a simulator ever before (as I usually stick with games that are not so realistic) I decided to try this one, because I'm always up for new things. First thing I am going to say is that if you're a graphic ♥♥♥♥♥ who only wants the best graphics, this is not the game for you. Also the traffic AI and citations are not the best either. However, if you can look past those flaws, the game is really great. Having experienced a little bit of the real thing, I can say it is fairly accurate to what being a truck driver is actually like. It's especially impressive considering that this is an indie game. My only real big complaint is the size. I would have actually liked all of America to be in it, instead of just Nevada and California. Also changing seasons and in game events based on in game dates would be a great way to expand the game. As it is, it's still worth the time and money and I think this was a great introductory into the simulation genre for me and for anyone else looking to get into simulation games.

												Awesome simulator, relaxing before you go to bed. Drive across the states with different types of cargo wether it be a long trip or a short trip it doesn't really matter, It's so god damn relaxing! I'm getting older so fast paced fps and other games is time consuming and you need alot of focus which i dont have after a long day taking care of my child and what not so thats where "ATS" comes to play!Before you take care of your own company you gotta do frilance jobs, as you do that you'll save up money for your first truck, Then you take care of your own company; hire drivers & assign routes for them (dont forget to buy trucks for them)Upgrade your trucks; engines, tires, mirrors and a whole lot more can be upgraded.Oh, and drive safe! Don't forget to follow the traffic rules or you'll be fined! Last but not least, dont forget to rest or you'll be dozing on the road and keep your truck with sufficient gas!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I have held of saying something but it IS necessary! You will see only two hours here but I have 126hrs on ETS2! The games are the same in mechanics! Should I buy ATS? Of course you should, its a must have! BUT, at this stage its a HUGE dissapointment. If the devs had all the ground work in game production already done for them, why have we waited so long for a game so thin in content. The trucks are beefy and American which is awesome and the landscape is real, but really, you want me to drive in such a short hop all the way to Redding??? NO NO NO, people - ATS makes Cally look the size of Luxemborg!!! All said and done, I love the titles and I love the concept and ethos start of ATS but if you are going to make ATS work as well as ETS2 you better get some real content fast and you better get some mileage scaling sorted out. Lastly and Im not just harping at you guys but devs are supposed to be wizz kids and for all the simplicity behind the actual coding of a project like this, it is REALLY DISSAPOINTING that the two games dont talk to each other! It isnt rocket science to do that! To sum up, I undertsand that thousands of hours and more go into the graphics of designing maps, but hey, you have a following here so lets get busy, we dont mind paying for good dlc's for more content but we cannot have ATS representing USA as smaller than Europe????Please take this as a positive gripe, we love the series, we want more?Again, should you buy it, how could you live without it? But if you have clocked the miles on ETS2 - AT THIS STAGE, you WILL be left a little dissapointed with ATS!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Clearly the negitive review people did not read anything about this game before purchasing it. Those complaining about lack of map: They stated that the states will be released as future DLC. Seeing as how California alone is twice the size of the U.K I can see how it would take a bit of time to develop. As for the lack of trucks they ran into licensing issues with the truck companies BUT they did say after a few weeks they should have the go ahead to put more trucks into the game, which will be free updates. The only issue I really have with the game is the ridiculous amount of police around so just starting out you loose money quick from speeding tickets. Also to those complaining about the 55 mph limit on some highways: In California the law is trucks with trailers statewide cannot go over 55 mph. When you get into Nevada and eventually elsewhere the speed limit goes up to a decent speed. Overall I rate this high as the future of this game will be rather well once they get more states and trucks up.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
Updated 2/26/016If you are a hardcore fan of ETS2, then I highly recommend getting this game. It's the same engine, concept, layout, and core mechanics so you'll feel right at home. Despite the game not being listed as Early Access, you might as well consider it as being so. The amount of content is a little on the light side as of now, but more content (both free and paid) is definitely on the way. The content that is in the game is much higher quality than that in ETS2. The world is very detailed and feels rather lived in.Compared to ETS2, the difficulty and amount of grinding has been bumped up a tad. Speeding fines have since been toned down and the Police are a bit less insane in the recent update thanks to SCS. I definitely find this game requires a lot more of my attention while playing. I personally play with a Logitech G27 and a TrackIR; I wouldn't recommend trying to play with a keyboard and mouse, but if you're determined, feel free to give it a go.The game now has three trucks, with a fourth potentially coming soon, and two states with a third in development. Modders have already rolled out a decent amount of content already, including a multiplayer mod. I find the combination of official and unofficial content to definitely be worth the $20, but that's just me.

number of helpful: 21 of 41 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												As far as the actual game is concerned, it is a good game.  I played Euro Truck for a few years and this "American" version is the same great quality of its "Euro" version.  I give it a negative review because it's been a year without any added content.  They released the game with California and Nevada and quickly released Arizona.  Since Arizona there has been nothing other than some "addons" like paint jobs and parts.  Euro Truck is a fully developed game where they added new content (new countries) on a regular basis.  It seems like American Truck is just an after thought with no real desire to develop it into a full blown game.  3 states in a year isn't development.  I was bored of the game in 20 hrs.  There is a ton of content they could add (not to mention 47 more states) but doesn't seem like it's going to happen.  If this the extent of American truck, then I give it a zero until they become serious with the game and start adding real content.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Awesome, just awesome game.  SCS outdid themselves so far.EDIT: I posted the review above with around 1 hour of gameplay.  After 24 hours, here is what I have come up with:Pros: -Inexpensive -Very well modeled trucks, including the AI traffic. -SCS nailed North American scenery. -Realistic Traffic Lights-Hotels, Gas Stations, and Miscellaneous Buildings are awesome, I just want to keep looking around to admire the level of detail. -Same menu layout and settings as ETS2, that makes everything so much simpler. -Ocean Spray/Dust Storms-Highways/Freeways are fairly straight.  That is one thing I hated about ETS2, you felt like a NASCAR driver pulling 1G lateral acceleration around a highway corner at 62MPH/100KPH.  -Realistic Sounds -AI traffic acts just like the idiots I see every day on the way to work. -Weigh Stations, that makes the game right there. -Realistic Gas prices -Options to park your delivery. -Insurance for repairs on your truck. -Transmission options. Now you can miss gears and it will keep grinding too! Amazing. -Tolls, even with the "I-Pass", that is just too cool. Cons (I know, it was just released....but hopefully they fix these things)-FPS fluctuation.  I play on Ultra settings and get 60 FPS on the highway, but as soon as I get in the city, it drops to an average of 35 FPS.-Exit/Entrance ramps are not realistic.  Needs to be longer.-Too many Cops.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												First off let me start by saying that I love the concept and I really liked Euro Trucker 2.. I've been waiting a long time for the American version because.. well I live in America.  The game its self is basically the same thing as Euro Trucker 2 which is perfectly fine (read reviews about the Euro version for in-depth info) but there are 2 things that cause me to down vote the American version of the game:1.  Why start on the west coast for the first release?  That's about as far as you can get from what real trucking is like in the US.  California is a bunch of tree hugging hippies, massive conjestion, liberal regulations that making trucking there a joke.  You can't even drive classic trucks in that state because of their insane laws so why choose that to start off in?  I would have much rather have seen the midwest, south, even the east coast for the first version.  I've driven all over the US and California is about the last state I would have stated with.2.  The 1st one was more of me ♥♥♥♥♥ing, this one though is really why I downvote the game.  The developer made the decision to change the scale of the game in the American version which blows my mind.  I can't understand why they would do this as logically it makes no sense.  In the Euro version when you drive from country to country it feels like you are long hauling.. I'm not saying that I spend hours in front of the computer for 1 route but you do get the experience that you really are trucking.  In the American version when you drive from LA to San Deigo you can barley get the truck up to speed before you arrive at your destination.. to be honest it's really bizzare.It seems to me that the developers think that the 'fun' in this game is backing up the truck to unload and going from stop light to stop light when you arrive at a town.. and that's not the case at all.  The real fun in this game is being on the open road, having your radio tuned to some red neck station and chilling out drinking a beer trucking down the high way... that's what it's all about.  The Euro version had this, the American version doesn't come close.The scale change for America was a big let down, yes I know that if they kept the same scale that they had in the Euro version that it may have taken a few hours to drive from the west coast to the coast.. but honestly that's not a bad thing.    People who are crazy enough to do that, more power to them... that's long hauling in America and trust me there is plenty to see that would have justified the content being created (DLC, more money for them).  As it stands now I think the developer missed a huge oppurtunity to take advantage of the US market but not understanding it's love for driving and the potential revenue that could have been captialized on.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I get the criticism this game receives, e.g. that it looks like a mod / DLC for ETS2 and that it's way too expensive. However, I find this game still very fun and challenging AND worth the money. The scenery is completely different and the challenge is there. You get to choose while delivering if you want to take the easy way out: automatic parking, the easy challenge: parking in an easy spot or to pick the advanced spot. You get more XP for taking a tougher challenge.  I think that this game is no where near done. It lacks diversity  after a while and new things to unlock, but you can't flat out compare Euro truck simulator 2 with American truck simulator. ATS will be greater or equal to ETS2 in the future as SCS has shown in the past with ETS2.7/7

												Here's an old reference. 18 Wheels of Steel. I'm not talking about the Extreme Trucker versions, I'm talking about the originals. Hard Truck, Haulin, Convoy etc. Now this. This game seems to me like an extreme overhaul of the 18WoS games. There's HD graphics, supreme truck customization (except for custom liveries), a wide range of companies and loads, and, a feature used in 18WoS Haulin, hired drivers. One recommendation, better rendered drivers.

												Amerecan truck simulator is better than euro truck simulator 2, mainly because of that it has cop cars, why cop cars you ask? well, at random parts of the map of euro truck simulator 2 the speed limit would say 80 so I'm going 80, speed limit changes to about 50 or something lower than 80, I see it change so I slow it down to the new speed limit but soon as it changes I get a speeding ticket. this doesn't happen everytime but when it does it tends to be at a internsection or when I'm about to go in to a tunnel. this doesn't happen on american truck simulator because if you speed near a cop car than you'll get a speeding ticket, otherwise you're fine. so this gives you more time to slow it down so you don't get a random speeding ticket. I read about speed cams in euro truck simulator 2 but haven't seen em, unless I'm just not seeing em but I'm driving a freaking 18 wheeler, I cant slow down from 80 to 30-50 speed limits in 3 seconds lol. that was so annoying in euro truck simulator 2. and yes I had the truck speed limit shown and not the car speed limit. I also noticed that the throttle control is way more sensitive, this makes it easier to mantain your speed. I cant find anything I dislike about this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I play on a laptop so your experience may be different. Pro's, Con's(or maybe bugs) and opions of ATS IMHO.Pro's:1. Graphics runs smoothly on 'High' Settings. (ETS2 I loose lots of FPS)2. Having the option to choose a backing skill level is great for all players new and old. This allows newer player the ability to start with none or easy backing and learn how to maneuver in reverse. Learning advanced backing maneuver like reverse S and sliping the trailer for more advanced backing.3. Scenery has a great feel for it. Reminds me of what it was like when I drove those highways. However some great locations are missing. I was lookingforward to the challenges like Donner's Pass. They are just missing(this might just be due to the scale of the map). 4. Lots of Rest Areas(but no truck stops).5. Lots of locations to get fuel.6. Trucks look and feel, handle good(however all should come equipt with the hood mirrors, at lease on the drivers side).7. Great looking AI traffic. Athough too many classic cars. Would like to see some emergency traffic going to calls. Car accidents, fires, cars pulled over(just might be to hard to program, not sure).Con's:1. Unrealistic speeds on small roads and in and around some city areas like Tonopha, NV need to slow down. 80 MPH is way to fast. You have to wait hours to make a turn FROM US-95 to US-395/US-6. Slower speeds and some traffic lights is needed in this area. Have seen some roads that are 1.5 lanes with 70 MPH speeds should be set to 35 MPH. Speeds in most US Cities (98%) are 25 not 30, and city bigger road are 35 MPH. 2. Pre-Pass should be Green when Weigh Stations are closed not just not come on. AI trucks should also enter Weigh Stations when Open. Also with Pre-Pass You should not have to enter as many Weigh Stations (reality would be like 1 in 10). A 1 in 5 would also work well for gaming purpose. However California does pull more trucks in than any other state.3. Reduce Speed Ahead signs need to be placed. Giving drivers a chance to slow down before entering a slower speed area. I hit a construction zone with no signage and got 2 tickets from 2 cops that was back to back. 4. No exit ramp speeds. ETS2 has ramp speeds but ATS doesn't. Taking a ramp at 70MPH is sure death.5. Smaller towns missing. No need to place every one of them in but driving down a US Routh or State Route we should seen some kind of small towns along the way with a speed reduction zone. Not really needed for Interstate as they don't drive through the towns.6. Interstates don't drive through cities. Ex: I-80 doesn't drop in Reno and pick up on the other side. A interstate almost always have on and off ramps.7. Ticket costs are way to high. Also fines double for construction zones.Would be great to be able to leave the truck and walk around and maybe interact with things. Like go order lunch, or buy a coffee use the rest room. I know it's a Truck Simulator, but we are the drivers and need these things for or lives as driivers. Another improvement would be live loading and unloading. You would buy a trailer(s), and drive to a location for loading and unloading. It opens up lots of new jobs and I don't think it would be to hard to program. However i'm not a programer ;))I love ETS2 and ATS has shown some improvements but yet also has shown some backward progress. I'm sure they where just oversights. And most of these kind of things can be fixed with a patch or two. Finding things like these depend on when someone testing enters a area. Like if you goto Tonopha at 3am it's much different than going there at 3pm. Overall it's a very intertaining game. With some small problems. None that mess with gameplay, but might make you whine a little. Once you pass the effeted complaint you will be happily rolling down the road and forgetting that last mile from h***. At least until you enter it again(but these thing happens in real life to). So if you get to areas you don't like reroute your route. You don't get paid for going around but you're free to do so.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I'll try to keep this short and somewhat readable :If you were an Euro Truck Simulator 2 fan and are intimidated by the seemingly small size of the current content - don't be. SCS has shown more than high aptitude to deliver high quality content with time. It may be less content than you are used to, but it's fresh, and my god is it polished. It's beautiful, the controls are tight and intuitive, as well as incredibly configurable - and it seemingly runs smoother the prettier it looks - don't know what kind of nail polish SCS works with, but it works perfectly on my 2012 war victim. As a final note : remember the devs took several steps to have the world size of Euro Truck Simulator 2 as it is. There was its prequel, and the prequel to that (Scania Truck Simulator). And on top of that, the game got massive expansions, and multiple patches that added cities in Italy, Austria and Hungary. You honestly think SCS didn't or won't deliver? Well if you do, I can't do much to convince you otherwise. But they can. For 20 (local currency) it's worth it. tl;dr : BELIEVE in the developer. Particularly this one.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Surprisingly full of frustrating screw-ups.  Wasn't expecting to be this irritated playing the game.1)  Cops appear out of nowhere and give you $1000 tickets for going five over the limit.2)  Hardly any posted speed limits anywhere.  Have to drive with one eye on your GPS to tell whether you're speeding or not.3)  Speed limits on major roadways are wrong, sometimes fluctuate in a given stretch of road for no reason.  Never any warning.4)  Lots of traffic signs missing for that matter.5)  Even with an automatic transmission truck rolls backwards on hills and stalls.Graphically enhanced version of ETS2 but nowhere near as comfy to drive.  Lack of variety in trucks is balanced by increased diversity of locales to drive in.  Would wait for a sale or for more content/fixes to annoying gameplay elements.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Right, I'll try and be short and sweet. Whilst everyone complains about the slow development from SCS, I give them credit for having this game out so soon. I am shocked at the fanbase's reaction purely because they went betching off about how the Pete 389 or the Mack Superliner or some shet like that wasn't included in the base release. Upon first playing it I admit I was thoroughly impressed just by the way the game felt to me, It hasn't grown old to me yet actually. So let's start simple enough for the children to read shall we? The map: Wow, a whole other continent. What an effing shock, everyone!! It is, to my knowledge of 3d modeling, pretty damn good. The scenery & props (buildings): Okay, this is where I personally believe SCS absolutely outdid themselves, I mean look at it, weigh scales, actual truckstops, random rest areas, all characteristics of... *drumroll* THE USA!!!!! Little motels out there occasionally in the countryside..The graphics: Wow, these are just perfection over my old ETS2 graphics, not to mention it runs better hahahaHonestly, 20/10, I'd drive a Peterbilt 579 for 200000 miles again any day.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Surprisingly full of frustrating screw-ups.  Wasn't expecting to be this irritated playing the game.1)  Cops appear out of nowhere and give you $1000 tickets for going five over the limit.2)  Hardly any posted speed limits anywhere.  Have to drive with one eye on your GPS to tell whether you're speeding or not.3)  Speed limits on major roadways are wrong, sometimes fluctuate in a given stretch of road for no reason.  Never any warning.4)  Lots of traffic signs missing for that matter.5)  Even with an automatic transmission truck rolls backwards on hills and stalls.Graphically enhanced version of ETS2 but nowhere near as comfy to drive.  Lack of variety in trucks is balanced by increased diversity of locales to drive in.  Would wait for a sale or for more content/fixes to annoying gameplay elements.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I'll try to keep this short and somewhat readable :If you were an Euro Truck Simulator 2 fan and are intimidated by the seemingly small size of the current content - don't be. SCS has shown more than high aptitude to deliver high quality content with time. It may be less content than you are used to, but it's fresh, and my god is it polished. It's beautiful, the controls are tight and intuitive, as well as incredibly configurable - and it seemingly runs smoother the prettier it looks - don't know what kind of nail polish SCS works with, but it works perfectly on my 2012 war victim. As a final note : remember the devs took several steps to have the world size of Euro Truck Simulator 2 as it is. There was its prequel, and the prequel to that (Scania Truck Simulator). And on top of that, the game got massive expansions, and multiple patches that added cities in Italy, Austria and Hungary. You honestly think SCS didn't or won't deliver? Well if you do, I can't do much to convince you otherwise. But they can. For 20 (local currency) it's worth it. tl;dr : BELIEVE in the developer. Particularly this one.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I get the criticism this game receives, e.g. that it looks like a mod / DLC for ETS2 and that it's way too expensive. However, I find this game still very fun and challenging AND worth the money. The scenery is completely different and the challenge is there. You get to choose while delivering if you want to take the easy way out: automatic parking, the easy challenge: parking in an easy spot or to pick the advanced spot. You get more XP for taking a tougher challenge.  I think that this game is no where near done. It lacks diversity  after a while and new things to unlock, but you can't flat out compare Euro truck simulator 2 with American truck simulator. ATS will be greater or equal to ETS2 in the future as SCS has shown in the past with ETS2.7/7

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												What can I say about the game, I totally love it!! I loved playing ETS2 because I'm from Europe, but it is fun discovering new parts of the world. To bad that there are only 3 stats so far :( Things I like the most about ATS: - The community is great, you can download trucks, skins and other mods from the workshop. So moding your game is very easy, but I can recommend you to not use to many mods if your computer is not a beast, and the second thing is that if the mod is taken away from the workshop it will no longer exist in the game, which can be problematic if it was your main truck. - The developers do a good job (fix bugs, new updates, map improvments)- Learn some basic stuff about America. - Nice graphics! Things I would like to change in ATS: - The weight stations, I don't really see the point of their existing in the game because as a player you'r not able to change the affect of the weight of the cargo. Maybe add a option so it makes sence to have them. - The bills. As a beginner the bills are a huge gap in your economy, but as a level 30 player with a small company and over 100k dollars in your pocket a 600 dollar bill is not going to make much diffrence. - The trucks don't have much options when it comes to tuning (less than in ETS2).I would suggest this game if you like slow games and listening to music or a podcast perhaps. I often play this game when I am not in the mood for playing a shooter game. (English is not my first language, so if you have some tips about how I can forrmulate myself PLS contact me :))

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I love the game. Yes as stated by the devolpers, there are some licening issues so the game is not fully released quite yet. Which is why the price is 20USD and not a full priced game. Another thing peaple are lacking to see is that The game is still in its birthing stage and you cant expect it to be a huge map. The devs have done a wonderful job recreating California but it seems as if the community isnt appreciating the fact that they did this at all. Most gamers these days expect a game to be perfect, but as a game developer in San Diego I can tell you that game design is not majgic and just to make a simple good menu like ATS has takes weeks, possibly even months! So yes, the game is worth it. Its not that big of a game yet and the developers have responded to that and agree and have lowered the price. Just guys, I leave on this one not, games are not magic and take years to make.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Though I don't reccomend this game, that doesn't mean you won't enjoy this game. Lemme explain my experience:The good:-Yeah, it's a truck game-It's a cool 18-wheels of steel updateThe bad:-The graphics are bad-No scenery-Towns are usually only a few roads long (cities like New Vegas)Overall, it's very plain. Nothing to look at. Even on the highest settings, everything looks pretty bad. Trees will disinigrate in your mirrors. Shadows won't load until you're close. Some grass even won't load til you're closer. I will probably play this game a bit more, just to see what the end-game stuff is like. I know you can hire workers and buy/upgrade your own truck store. But it's taking quite a while and you're on the road with nothing to see. Cars are always getting into stupid wrecks with eachother, making it pretty hard. Usually the crash is a car turning from a stop sign straight into another, sometimes backing straight into me. There is a lot I can say about this game, but overall a 6/10 from me.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												After 10 hours of gameplay, I have enjoyed playing the game. I understand that the game had been in development for roughly 2 years. The main downside of the game is the complete lack of content. For a game which is running off the same engine as ETS2 and also uses nearly identical mechanics and UI's, it is very concerning that their are only 2 states and a very limited amount of vehicles. I do not think the game is worth the price that it is now with the current amount of content. If their was a complete engine overhaul/graphics changes and more vehicles and states then I would agree with the current price. As I said, I have enjoy playing the game but I can see it getting boring very quickly. If you are willing to buy now and wait for more content to come out, then I would say go ahead. However, if you are looking for a game with large amounts of content then you should probably wait a lot longer until more content is released.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Although I have played enough of this game to offer a fair review, I will choose not to and instead offer one of my favorite recipies for my favorite dish, Boeuf Bourguignon Knopf.First prepare the bacon: cut off the rind and reserve.Cut the bacon into lardons about 1/4" thick and 1 1/2" long.Simmer the rind and the lardons for ten minutes in 1 1/2 quarts of water.Drain and dry the lardons and rind and reserve.Pre-heat the oven to 450°F.Put the tablespoon of olive oil in a large (9" - 10" wide, 3" deep) fireproof casserole and warm over moderate heat.Saute the lardons for 2 to 3 minutes to brown lightly.Remove to a side dish with a slotted spoon.Dry off the pieces of beef and saute them, a few at a time in the hot oil/bacon fat until nicely browned on all sides.Once browned, remove to the side plate with the bacon.In the same oil/fat, saute the onion and the carrot until softened.Pour off the fat and return the lardons and the beef to the casserole with the carrots and onion.Toss the contents of the casserole with the salt and pepper and sprinkle with the flour.Set the uncovered casserole in the oven for four minutes.Toss the contents of the casserole again and return to the hot oven for 4 more minutes.Now, lower the heat to 325°F and remove the casserole from the oven.Add the wine and enough stock so that the meat is barely covered.Add the tomato paste, garlic and herbs and the bacon rind.Bring to a simmer on the top of the stove.Cover and place in the oven, adjusting the heat so that the liquid simmers very slowly for three to four hours.The meat is done when a fork pierces it easily.While the meat is cooking, prepare the onions and mushrooms and set them aside till needed.For the onion, if using frozen, make sure they are defrosted and drained.Heat the butter and oil in a large skillet and add the onions to the skillet.Saute over medium heat for about ten minutes, rolling the onions about so they brown as evenly as possible, without breaking apart.Pour in the stock, season to taste, add the herbs, and cover.Simmer over low heat for about 40 to 50 minutes until the onions are perfectly tender but retain their shape and the liquid has mostly evaporated.Remove the herbs and set the onions aside.For the mushrooms, heat the butter and oil over high heat in a large skillet.As soon as the foam begins to subside add the mushrooms and toss and shake the pan for about five minutes.As soon as they have browned lightly, remove from heat.To Finish the Stew:.When the meat is tender, remover the casserole from the oven and empty its contents into a sieve set over a saucepan.Wash out the casserole and return the beef and bacon to it (discarding the bits of carrot and onion and herbs which remain in the sieve).Distribute the mushrooms and onions over the meat.Skim the fat off the sauce and simmer it for a minute or two, skimming off any additional fat which rises to the surface.You should be left with about 2 1/2 cups of sauce thick enough to coat a spoon lightly.If the sauce is too thick, add a few tablespoons of stock.If the sauce is too thin, boil it down to reduce to the right consistency.Taste for seasoning.Pour the sauce over the meat and vegetables.If you are serving immediately, place the covered casserole over medium low heat and simmer 2 to 3 minutes.Serve in the casserole or on a warm platter surrounded by noodles, potatoes or rice and garnished with fresh parsley.If serving later or the next day, allow the casserole to cool and place cold, covered casserole in the refrigerator.20 minutes prior to serving, place over medium low heat and simmer very slowly for ten minutes, occasionally basting the meat and vegetables with the sauce.

content:
Posted: January 21
												This is a great game for Euro Truck Simulator lovers.I have played now for a good while and i can sum alot of good things about the game :So first :Detail - I enjoy the detail in this game, it feels there is alot more detail and different areas to see compare to ETS, there are alot of signs with random things not just town signs it feels authentic ( there are shops, diners, donut places and much more with different lights and showcase...) some lights are pretty drops down on buildings in a special way and the scenary is beautiful, from forests and watery places into barren lands and high speed roads, truck gauges are amazing, there is surely alot to see here.Gameplay - Long straight roads and fun. there are many interesting roads and intersections to drive at specialy hilly areas with a special truck lane or long straight roads with hills that the road goes up and downs i really liked them.Difficulty - From ETS2 to ATS there is a lot of difference, the truck really feels long and sometimes it's challenging to leave a parking area or park your trailer, there is alot more driving to do, high speed roads and dangerous roads.I hope we keep seeing new upcoming content to ATS and ETS, they are both excellent and i think it's important they keep the community and game alive by doing so.I recommend getting ATS, it's a small payment for alot of pleasure,The game is awesome and beautiful for all those who love driving games this is a must and i'll be looking forward for any upcoming expansions for both ATS and ETS2.

content:
Posted: March 13
												Don't want to read the entire review?  Just read this: Yes.American Truck Simulator is an amazing, challenging game designed for a relaxing experience.Now, I know what you're thinking.  "Nate, why the heck would a game about work be fun?  I work enough already!"  It's great.  There's just something about commanding a huge tractor pulling 50k pounds of freight at 90mph that's exciting.Don't want the grind?  I didn't either.  I downloaded a free profile with about 60 million dollars.  "Nate, that defeats the purpose!" No, I paid for a fun, relaxing driving sim.  I didn't want to worry about money issues, I just wanted to make deliveries and run my company.  I have now brought that profile from 60mil to 138mil as of this moment from my work and having my company at the largest possible at this point in the game.  I can afford repairs if I have an accidental crash or if the AI (Artificial UNintelligence) cars ram me.  I can afford any truck with any upgrades I want.  It's great.Pros:-Semi-Realistic driving sim (as long as you don't ram the invisible walls)-Easy-to-use, straight forward interface-Extremely ‘replayable’ (I mean, just look at my hours)-Great customization of truck exteriors with many options (and, according to SCS, many more to come)Cons:-The AI cars need a bit more common sense.  It gets annoying when you lose $3,000 on a job just because a car rammed your trailer when you pull out of a gas station or something.-The game needs more development.  I will give credit to SCS.  They have a small team working on a BIG game.  But, compared to ETS2 (Euro Truck Sim 2), ATS is under-developed.-Interior customization could be expanded.  As a professional truck driver, you are going to be spending lots of time in the cab.  After about 50 hours straight in the exact same cabin, it's going to get a bit boring.  Conclusion:ATS is a great, laid-back pass-time game.  With a large map in a great setting with thick forests, large deserts, and a beautiful coastline, the game has many different environments that make it hard to get tired of.  While the game is somewhat under-developed, SCS Software is quite obviously working hard to update it frequently.  I find this game worth every penny and more.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												It's a clear morning in California. I'm driving my truck down a lonely road, through the empty desert. In the rear view mirror, I see a car approaching. I keep driving, expecting them to pass me, but they don't. I check back in my mirror, and- it's a police car. Okay, this is no situation to panic. I kept driving, slowly and steadily. But I felt myself growing tired. The road stretched on, seemingly endlessly. I finally could take no more and dozed off for anly a few seconds. When I woke up, I was going slightly above the speed limit, and I slammed my brakes. But it was too late. The police car had already called reinforcements. A line of six or seven cop cars was following me down the highway, sirens blaring. I suddenly get a storm of notifications from my GPS- my bank account is being drained, ticket by ticket. Then the shooting started, and they drove the truck off the road. That was the last thing I remembered, until I woke up. The starving, broke, pitiful CEO of a failed trucking company.10/10, quite realistic.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												This is one of those games that similar to ETS2 will having me doing a few jobs a day for months on end.It does not revolutionize the sim genre as its very similar to ETS2. However its improves on most all of it. Scenery is more detailed in cities. Outside of cities its about as detailed as it can be for mostly desert areas. It does feel quite a bit smaller than ETS2 mainly because its 2 states at the moment. Which is disappointing but from what I hear Nevada is in the works and will be free so cannot complain to much about that. The modding scene is in the works as well so I have no doubt in a few months we will have some amazing mods to go along with it. There are already some great mods for the game. I am excited for the maps mods.What impressed me the most was the sounds. I love ETS2 but when you get in one of these Peterbuilt or Kenworth trucks and get your truck moving it gives you chills. I have got 2 other drivers working for me and am well into making my trucking empire. For me this was a no brainer. I loved ETS2 however I prefer the North American setting so I grabbed this.I know this review is kind of all over the place. Moral of the story. If you have and enjoy ETS2 and are looking for something different this is not the game for you there is not enough to recommend switching. However if you prefer the setting by all means grab this game you will not be disappointed.If you have never owned one of the trucking sim games but are interested. Choose which setting you prefer most and pick it up.
