												IGNORE MY LOW AMOUNT OF HOURS, I HAVE PLAYED MORE ON DIFFERENT ACOUNT___________________________________________________________________________I would have to say, this and it's sister, Euro Truck Simulator, are probably the best driving simulators out there. Moddable and avalible to causal to hardcore truck drivers, it has a wide range of content.                                                                                                        Pros:- Moddable- Large map, with expantions coming- Decent amount of trucks to choose from- Many different types of cargo to choose from- Fantastic graphics- Easy to learn - Can use VR- Can use gaming wheels- Can Play for hours on end- Constantly Updated- Customizable TrucksCons:- We all know it's coming, the amount of DLCs the devs will put out- Uhhh, umm... OH, the amount of time it takes to find more cons   - I've been sitting here for 7 minutes thinking of any. Ok... i'll move on."Mehs" (Opinions, Most of these can be solved with mods):- Honestly, there is a lot of customization features but i feel like it needs more- Little more traffic variaty- The time it takes to get moving at the start (Just get a money/xp cheat on the workshop)- Size of the cities, they are kind of big, but i felt like they should have been made biggerThings they should add to the game (Most of this would be DLCs):- More intierior customization, same as wheel tuning DLC, but with the inside of the trucksI had more but they were stupid.All in All, if you like driving simulators get this, if you don't, why are you here?  Personal Rating:9.6/10Have a good day                              -VV

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												After 10 hours of gameplay, I have enjoyed playing the game. I understand that the game had been in development for roughly 2 years. The main downside of the game is the complete lack of content. For a game which is running off the same engine as ETS2 and also uses nearly identical mechanics and UI's, it is very concerning that their are only 2 states and a very limited amount of vehicles. I do not think the game is worth the price that it is now with the current amount of content. If their was a complete engine overhaul/graphics changes and more vehicles and states then I would agree with the current price. As I said, I have enjoy playing the game but I can see it getting boring very quickly. If you are willing to buy now and wait for more content to come out, then I would say go ahead. However, if you are looking for a game with large amounts of content then you should probably wait a lot longer until more content is released.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												As SCS Software mentioned in the description of the game, it currently only has two states, California and Nevada, with a third - Arizona - currently in development. And as of right now, only has two trucks to choose from. So the game is currently lacking content wise, only because this was built from the ground up, and there will be more content released for it in the future, some probably through free updates and others through purchases, it's up to the company for what they do. Even though it's a decent game right now, it cannot be recommened in its current state due to being incomplete content wise (trucks to choose from, states to go to, etc).I may come back to this in the future to change my review, so stay tuned for the *update.*I'd like to point out now that this will be way later on in the future, when there are more states and more vehicles to choose from. My best guess is that it would be at least by late 2017 at best, and early 2019 at the latest, when I believe that a sizeable amount of the game might be completed, meaning more content added to the game. I'd also like to say that I am not trying to make a major 100% guess on a timeframe for a more complete game, but for just a guess, a shot in the dark.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Waited a long time for this one, years and was told  by the developer time after time please be patient. We don't want to release the game before it is ready. A huge hypefest about all the new features and blah blah this and it will be so worth the wait we promise. So it was FINALLY released and what did we get for our money? Two count them on two fingers yes 2 trucks and 2 trucks that have minimum modifications compared to the OLDER  game ETS2.  Now  I'm trying to notice what is really NEW and find mostly really irritating things like a cop on every corner giving me $1000.00 dollar tickets every 10 seconds.. Being ticketed for right turns on red which last time I checked was legal in America. Then started looking closer at the "new details" and find some more really irritating things like concrete barriers that look like some child playing with their toys placed them willy nilly so as to create a potential hazard every 100 yrds.  Light standards with huge concrete bases so close to the lane that you would not dare travel in that lane! Hello SCS people are using keyboards to steer their trucks and you put all this crap right where someone is most likely to run into it and cause huge amounts of damage. Now lets talk about some really dumb stuff that makes me just shake my head in disbelief.  The developer paid someone to put stop signs at the intersections that already have traffic lights. No wonder it took so long to get this thing to market.  Most of the "cities" if you want to call them that are so small that they don't even have a garage or gas station. Talk about sparse. Heck most of its desert country whats so dam hard about putting up a few cactus and some brown vegetation? Now lets talk about sound quality. Let me put it this way, the first time I heard the "horn" on either of the 2 trucks it reminded me of the clowns car at the circus. Thats the best you can do in the three years I waited ? Can I recommend this piece of unfinished stuff?  A BIG thumbs down. I could give a rats patooty about all the new flare and other superfluous nonsense. I want my tuned trucks back, I want the dual trailers that were supposedly going to be part of ATS and some form of LAN connectivity. SCS you have lost sight of what your customers want and have chosen instead to offer a dumbed down unfinished product and sell ridiculous DLC addons such as your accessories DLC and paint job DLC's and heavy loads bs. At this rate it will take another three years just to fix what you just released instead of making any real progress.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Real-life U.S. truck driver here.Having put a ton of hours into ETS2, I was very excited when I learned SCS would be making another game based on trucking in my own country; not so much today. Yes, I do realize the game is very new and WIP.Stuff I do likeControls and plays much the same as ETS2 - hooray for XB360 gamepads!Game is graphically beautiful!The delivery parking options are a very much welcome addition. I've even found myself having to stop, think, and plan how I'm going to get a trailer into a tight spot.Fines for violations are actually a real concern; even crippling!But there's this one thing that's been wrecking it for me...Ask just about anyone from anywhere else in the world what one of his or her major first impressions will be when visiting the United States, and I can all but guarantee one of them will be a sense of awe at how vast and wide open this land feels. That sense of openness is lost in this game.Cities such as Los Angeles and Carlsbad, CA feel practically next door to each other, when it reality, they are over 80 miles apart through an almost entirely urbanized landscape. In game, the trips takes less time than a quick run to the corner store when the real run in a 74' truck lasts the better part of 2 hours. This feels even more pronounced when making the longest in-game trips; the sense of distance simply isn't there.Rather surprisingly, I've recently learned the map scaling is significantly smaller than it was in ETS2. As a result, the game world feels disappointingly truncated. As others have noted, essential elements such as highway on-ramps are very short - gaining enough speed to safely merge with traffic is nigh impossible. What would normally be a challenging decent down Donner Pass, requiring careful planning and concentration, feels like it's over and gone in just a few seconds. As others have said, I feel this effectively breaks the immersion aspect of the game.Other minor quibblesNo, you cannot drive for 14 hours. You get 11 hours in a 14 hour windowWe generally don't fuel our trucks with 53' trailers at a typical gas station. There are truck stops for that.....and speaking of truck stops, we usually don't go about "nosing in" to parking spots!I understand my critique is very harsh, but that's because I've done and do this for a livingIn summary, I feel as though I'm "playing at" trucking with toys as a kid, rather than engaging in any sort of simulation. At this stage, the game feels like a $20.00 demo - speaking of demos; I hear they've released one, so go get it!If you're looking to jump in the cab a well-modeled American truck and go about having some easy fun gallivanting about California and Nevada, then you'll likely enjoy this one. The game has a long way to go, but that also means it's got lots of new content ahead! Also - MODS!!! :DI would not recommend this game to anyone seeking a more immersive simulation-type experience, it simply isn't there.Be safe out there!-Red

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												I really liked Euro Truck Simulator but being American I wished there was an American version where I could drive the types of trucks I am used to seeing every day and on the right side of the road. Well, that's just what this is, and the graphics are a little better too. Usually I don't care for simulation games at all but this one is easy to get into, has great controls that you can set up multiple ways (I use an Xbox controller with button inputs custom set up), you can easily load up your own music for your road hauls, and there are lots of neat mods to tweak the experience even more to your liking. Its an oddly relaxing and enjoyable game with goals that keep me coming back. It takes up surprizingly little space on my HDD, and the price is quite fair for what you get unlike so many games that are early access with barely anything to even do for more money. Plus they are working on Arazona, which will be a free update. Good stuff! Over n out.

												American Truck Simulator, yes it is lacking the Countries and Cities that Euro Truck Simulator 2 offers. However let us not forget how Euro Truck Simulator 2 began, it started as German Truck Simulator. And UK Truck Simulator. Locking you to only Germany and UK (In 2 different releases.)So is the lack of States a problem for American Truck Simulator? I think not. Right now it causes some issues of repetativeness as you will very quickly span the map, however it is just the beginning. The lack of truck veriety however is disapointing, license limitations or not I would rather they took the Euro Truck Simulator approach and released fictional brands for the trucks until they we're able to secure a licenses.At the moment as American Truck Simulator is today I feel Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a better buy, however I see lots of potential for American Truck Simulator to get to the same level in time, and I just hope it doesn't take too much time to get there.

												Though I don't reccomend this game, that doesn't mean you won't enjoy this game. Lemme explain my experience:The good:-Yeah, it's a truck game-It's a cool 18-wheels of steel updateThe bad:-The graphics are bad-No scenery-Towns are usually only a few roads long (cities like New Vegas)Overall, it's very plain. Nothing to look at. Even on the highest settings, everything looks pretty bad. Trees will disinigrate in your mirrors. Shadows won't load until you're close. Some grass even won't load til you're closer. I will probably play this game a bit more, just to see what the end-game stuff is like. I know you can hire workers and buy/upgrade your own truck store. But it's taking quite a while and you're on the road with nothing to see. Cars are always getting into stupid wrecks with eachother, making it pretty hard. Usually the crash is a car turning from a stop sign straight into another, sometimes backing straight into me. There is a lot I can say about this game, but overall a 6/10 from me.

												If you like/ love Euro Truck Simulator, then I am sure you are going to enjoy this too!Right now, at the time of writing this review there is not that much content in the game, but there is a fair amount to keep you entertained for the time being, more content will be added but most likely at a cost.Graphics: The graphics too me seem a little upgraded compared to the original Euro Truck Sim 2, which is nice and the detailing is kinda a little better, it's the only way to explain it.  I had scaling on 400% and max graphics and was super smooth!Audio: The audio is the same as Euro Truck sim, with some added effects coming from the world.  It is truck noises... I turned off the radio and music because I found it annoying!Controls: This is where I got annoyed! I am using an Xbox One controller (X360 works too) but I had some problems setting it up and it took me a while because of the weird issue with the acceleration with the game!Gameplay: The gameplay is the same as Euro Truck Simulator 2, which I did not play much off as I only played the multiplayer mod, which I am thankful to say, this version now has!(I am unsure if ETS2 has these features but I am detailing them from ATS) - The nice fact you can hire drivers, buy trucks for them and a little more, buy a garage, upgrade it and semi customise the trucks and get your drivers to go on missions to earn you some more money is pretty awesome.  The detail in this version I find is a lot more extreme, to the point when driving around the scenery actually has things going on, there are no pedestrians on the streets, but they are in cars and wandering around a complex and outside buidings IN a small area, but there are planes flying over dusting their fields, police following people, helicopters and actual things to look at. There is a multiplayer mod for this game already and it is pure amazing, I love everything about it.  The only problem is, there is there NO traffic at all, not even police cars on the road... The only people on the road are other players, that is it! Kinda sad! Also is the idiots who think this game is GTA and race around, cutting on the pavement, ramming and so much more, but thankfully the Admins are very fast to actually ban them which is awesome, and there is very little of these people and players actually play the game properly mostly.  Again making this enjoyable!The game plays more or less the same as ETS2 and is enjoyable and will be a better version when more content has arrived, so on that basis... Yes, I would recommend this game a a step up from ETS2

I wouldn't care if I was driving Macs or Panchobilt if the dealer had bunch of trucks to choose from.And every time I drive on the 5 up n down from LA I want to fly to whatever commie country devs are located n kick em in the balls since the real thing has like 12 lanes.. Not in game tho. Same lame 2 lanes with few stretches of short 3 lanes..ATS map is way scaled down because it's a ETS2 with a new map.. So devs couldn't lay down roads every where in the game that you can just drive thru instead of being forced to this linear A to B path? content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
Idling in the MorningIdle questions drift through my mind sometimes (normally when I’m at work and supposed to be having more productive, less idle thoughts).There are a few questions that always plague me when I settle at my desk in the morningsQuestions like:“What am I doing here?”“Why isn’t it lunchtime yet?”and the classic“Is there a microscopic black hole under my desk because I think time has slowed down?”(There isn’t by the way, I’ve checked, although if it really is microscopic I might have missed it).I recite these musings to myself like a kind of depressing mantra every morning, but it’s the afternoons when my thoughts really go off on a tangent.Idling in the AfternoonFor example, have you ever wondered why we have two letters in the English alphabet that make the same noise, C and K?I have....And whilst we’re talking about C, why do we use it to make an S sound in some words?(Circle, I’m thinking of you here)We’ve already got a letter that can make "Sssss" Sounds, it’s the letter S, why is C stepping on S’s toes?If C did step on S’s toes, and it turned into a fight, which one would win?Which one would I want to win?Don’t get me wrong, it’s not always that insightful in my mind, that was a good afternoon.Idling my way to RelevanceThankfully a slightly more relevant question occurred to me today, relevant because I was sitting at my desk subtly checking for black holes(I have to be subtle or my colleagues might think I’m weird).Anyway, as I was eyeballing a shady corner of one of my draws for suspicious gravitational anomalies my mind wandered towards thoughts of home (as it often does) and my plans for the evening, plans which included playing American Truck Simulator.Relevant RevelationNow, it’s no secret that I like to zone out with a good long session of European Truck Simulator 2 when time allows so I was looking forward to getting behind the wheel of a “Good Ol’ Big Rig” and trucking in a Zen-like trance across the US of A.It was then that it occurred to me that I didn’t know which was bigger, geographically speaking, Europe or America.As this question was obviously much more important than any actually work I was supposed to be doing, I immediately turned to my friend Google to investigate.Factual FrictionThe problem was Google didn’t seem to know the answer.Keep in mind that whilst at work I have to be just as subtle in my clandestine internet activities as I am in my black hole survey, so I could only really scan the results (whilst the boss wasn’t looking) without opening up any actual web pages.This led to a list of links with snippets of information like “Europe has a slightly larger landmass” and “America is much larger than Europe, France is smaller than Texas”.I decided that as I couldn’t investigate this properly whilst being watched by “the man” (and I was aware that whilst it seemed like a burningly important question when compared the dullness of actual “work” it wouldn’t matter to me in the slightest once I was at home and had more interesting things to do).Fictional FactsAnyway, due to the lack of an immediately accessible answer I decided that they were probably about the same sort of size, a decision which has now become fact in my mind, a fact I’ve made up myself, but a fact none the less.It made sense to me, If SCS had made a trucking game which spanned most of Europe then American Truck Simulator would probably be on the same sort of scale, therefore America must be the same sort of size as Europe, you can’t argue with science like that.These thoughts were still with me when I finally escaped the shackles of work and settled down in front of my PC.Steering wheel and pedals at the ready, I fired up ATS ready for some “Stateside Trucking”Road to RichesFor the uninitiated, American Truck Simulator places you in charge of your own haulage company (as does its sister game Euro-Truck Simulator 2). You start out by choosing where you want to set up your first little base of operations and then you’re master of your own haulage destiny.Unfortunately you don’t start with any money, driving skills or even a truck of your own, you’re going to need to earn, learn and buy these things as you play.Earn and LearnThe “earning and learning” elements initially come from the successful completion of “quick jobs” which you’ll find available to you from the various locales scattered across the map.These jobs vary in length and payment; you’ll find yourself hauling all sorts of cargo across the states.You’re working for the metaphorical “Man” with these jobs though so you won’t earn as much as you would if you were your own boss, but as you haven’t got your own truck when you first start out, running these contracts in the loaner rigs provided is the only way you’re going to earn a buck. When you’ve finished browsing the list of jobs currently available to you, you’ll pick a contract you like the sound of (whether that’s because it pays well, you like the idea of hauling a particular cargo type, or you think it might push some interesting scenery past  your windows).A click of a button later and you’ll find yourself sitting in your borrowed rig; trailer hooked up and destination already set in the sat nav.It’s time to get trucking!Grand Truck AutoNow you’re sitting behind the wheel of a big rig, trundling along the byways and cruising down the highways it’s important to keep in mind that this is a simulation title, not a joy ride in Grand Theft Auto.You’re being paid to complete a delivery job.Running red lights, racing past speed cameras and smashing other vehicles off the asphalt (as tempting as it might be) could result in some hefty fines, if you’re saving up to buy your own rig, this is not a good thing.Does it come with Fluffy Dice?Traffic transgressions aside, you’ll eventually reach a point where you’ve got a tidy sum of money burning a hole in your pocket. Whether this is through the diligent completion of delivery jobs or the quick fix solution of a crippling bank loan is up to you, but sooner or later you’ll find yourself touring the dealerships to pick out a truck of your very own.When you’ve got your heart set on a rig, the dealer is going to tempt you with a wealth of optional extras from the cosmetic to the mechanical and like a kid in a sweetshop; you’re going to want them all.Rig Responsibilities With your chest full of pride and your wallet empty of money, you’ll now be the proud owner of your own truck. It’s time to stop making money for “The Man” and start making it for yourself.You’re no longer tied to the “quick job” market, you can take contracts directly now and cut out the middle man.The downside of this is that now you’re using your own vehicle; you’re going to need to look after it, give it petrol to drink and pay to have it fixed up if it gets “poorly”.You need to look after yourself too, drive for too long without rest and you’re going to get drowsy. Falling asleep at the wheel can really ruin your day (and your truck) so rest stops in lay-bys are a must on long drives.Bigger, Better, Faster, Stronger As well as getting rich from completing all these contracts, there’s also the added bonus of increasing your own driving skills, this is done with an almost RPG like experience levelling system.Complete a contract quickly without smashing up your truck and you’ll gain experience; gain enough and you’ll ... [snip]You can find the full review (and others) HERE[www.review-well.com]

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I will not lie, I do like this game, but as of yet it just doesn't compare with Euro Truck Simulator 2. Ok, I am aware it is in very early stages and was relelased only 3 days ago, but...there is not loads in it. I have played less than an hour and already come across loads of map edges. In fact, possibly just as many as I have in ETS2 and i have played that for over 200 hours (I just didn't activate the CD Key on steam because I didn't know it was a steam game) So, back to American Truck Simulator. It used the same graphics engine as ETS2 which i think held it back. I have it runing on Ultra / high and it could, for it's era, look a bit better. There is a very limited truck selection at the moment which i am hoping will be rectified in time. Hopefully not too long. I look forward to the map expansion DLC's and i must say, they are needed. Though it takes a while to cover, the map is small, and it feels more like a £14.99 demo, than a game. Originally the game didn't run on my screen resolution so i spent a while trying to fix the home streaming thing so i could fix that on my laptop. It was a pain and initially it crashed a few times, but now i have it working, it seems to be alright. I like the diversity of the cars on the roads, it feels authentic and it's a nice touch to the realism. The terrain does look good, as do the roads, but the lorries don't so much. I actually don't like the look of the trucks in the game at the moment, with the massive bonnets (or for the Americans, probably hoods). I do prefer the ones with a flat front, but hey, maybe they will get added in later, or someone will mod one. All in all the game is very much the same as ETS2 with just the truck types, and the map changed. It is satisfying enough to pass for a new game, but i hope they relese these updates soon. I reccomended this game because i saw potential in it, and i only hope that the game designers won't let us down there. As it is currently, i woud not reccoment it, but i know they will update it, and i have hopes for the future of this game.

												First I want to say that American Truck Simulator should have been a thing before Euro Truck. I think everybody agrees that American trucks overall are better than euro trash trucks. content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												After only spending a few hours in ATS, I feel like I've found a game I can just play forever and ever and never get tired of.  I was hesitant about buying it, as I know nothing of trucking, nor did I get into ETS 2 or other similar games, making this my introduction to trucking games.  I took the risk and bought it thanksto a friend, and I can't stop playing.  It is extremely fun and relaxing to just drive and/or listen to the in-game radio.  The game is beautiful!  SCS did an amazing job  with graphic details.I do, however, have a few issues with the game.  These are mostly minor things that don't  take away from the gameplay overall.  I'm thoroughly loving this game.1)  Speeding tickets are 1k each, even if you'ree only going 5 miles over.  That's pretty extreme and not realistic.2) Cops are EVERYWHERE.  I love seeing the cops around, but it gets to be a little too much when every fourth or fifth car you see is a police car.3) I've encountered certain spots in gas stations that the truck simply cannot go over.  I found this out initially when delivering fuel.  My cab could go over the spot, but my trailer wheels would get stuck and force me to skip parking.4) Traffic speeds!  Cars will go much faster than you all the time, even if you're going 55mph, they will fly by you.  If we have a set speed limit, the AI needs one, too.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I would love to recommend this game, but I just can't. I loved playing Hard Truck 2: Kind of the Road as a kid, I love playing ETS2 now. New game by SCS set in USA, what could go wrong? Well, it did.I mean, map and surrounding is nicely detailed, good job, but this is the only plus for the game. Roads blocked for player for no reason - those could get easily connected with different routes, but no, SCS just HAD TO make this annoying virtual barriers. Half of the cities roads are blocked, despite they are there. Map feels cramped, traveling to destination is too quick.The game itself feels like DLC for ETS 2. Whole user interface is literally copied from ETS 2. Like seriously, is it this difficult to change layout and background of main menu along with texture of Route Advisor? It would help a lot.And I thought this game is made by SCS, not EA. If so, why is it shipped unfinished? Only two trucks to choose from? It is riddiculous, they are not even American Classics, but some streamline modernish crap.We were hyped for new game, yet we got just limited standalone DLC for Euro Truck. Not cool. I probably could've been happy with ATS if it was sold as DLC, but well, it didn't.At this moment I would not buy again. And so, when my buddy asked me if should he get ATS my answer was NO. "What about ETS2 then?" he asked. "Well, go for it" I replied. Yet, I hope SCS will finish game as they should before release, so they prove me wrong and ensure my money were well spent.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I just made an urgent delivery of a bulldozer to a road that is under construction. There was another one there, ready to be taken away. This leads me to believe that the one being taken away broke down and they urgently needed a replacement to continue the construction.It's the little things that make this game so great, and make it so much different than ETS 2. Yes, there are only 2 states. Yes, there are only 2 trucks (that can be customized to make it more like 4 or more trucks in my opinion). More of both of those are to come in future updates. What is in the game right now is definitely worth $20. In fact, I think it's underpriced, especially considering that the price includes years of updates (ETS 2 released in 2012 and is still being updated - even after ATS is released!). There will be paid DLC for some of the states, simply because of the amount of work that has to be put into each one. SCS Software has to make money somehow, and they definitely deserve it.Also, if there really is not enough content for you, then there are always mods. The game just released days ago and there are already quite a few free mods to enhance your game.Edit: Let me add something else - The game is supposed to look and play like ETS 2. It is not a successor or sequel. It is the same game in America. Both games will still be updated, and each will benefit from the other. If you bought the game expecting any different, then perhaps you should have done your research first, since this has always been the case since they first announced ATS. What is different, like I said, is the little things. The world feels much more alive, and you do actually feel like you have a purpose other than 'drive from this warehouse to that one.'

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												When viewed as a stand alone game the US$19.99 for a game containing two US states (California and Nevada) and two trucks might seem steep, but there are a few factors to consider. First, SCS has already committed to Arizona and future trucks as free DLC, which is a great long term value. Second, when viewed as a function of the land area open to explore, CA and NV have about 273,000 sq mi of land area, which is about the same as Germany, Austria, Czech Republic, Switzerland, and the UK (and we didn't get all of the UK in ETS2). So while 2 states sounds small, it isn't nearly as small as is seems. Finally, because American Truck Simulator uses the same engine as ETS2 we are getting a game that has many of the bugs already ironed out.Overall, ATS is a great value. Especially when viewed as an expansion of the ETS2 world.

												Hello well, I got a few hours into this game and i"m already rank 5, I gotta say it's a interesting sensation finally being able to read and understand "AMERICAN" Roadways.  City's, Hazard signs, and so on.   I mean in the EU you can understand it once you get a handle on things with your own handbook.  But with stuff that we Americans can read, who's never stepped foot outside of their own state.  It's a good feeling to not be confused.Pro's and Cons to this game.ProsEasy to get into for us Americans who knows not the rules of the road in Europe.Great Graphics Highly customizable.Has a radio setup where you can listen to web radios while you're driving, though it kinda makes me feel like i'm playing "GTA" on safemode ya know? Other than npc vehicals i'm sure they are gathering all proper licenses for each and every individual Trucks available on the US Market.Decent sound quality, Nothing noticable in this than it was in E.T.2.19.99 well, can't really beat that on 1.00 release day.  Especailly when you get two trucks and free skins with it and free Navada map.ConsWell, I have to say, my biggest gripe is MAP SIZE!  I mean come on, they should atleast make it for every 5 hours it takes 30 minutes rl time to drive it.  But KRIPES! I was able to finish a 5 hour drive in less than 10 minutes following speed limet, They aut to extend the map size a litlte further.  or something. I'll probrably find a mod that does that anyway.  I dont' know what else to put down.  It's pretty much the same as in E.T.2. with a twist, That's about it.   My rating for this game is this a solid 7/10 total, B+ for effort, B- for map sizeing.   A+ for USA Settings!

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
TL;DRSCS Software is just milking the cow one more time: ATS is just a copy of the old 18 Wheels of Steel series/European Truck Sim with improved graphics and nothing new or exciting... You just throw money at them playing the same thing until you get bored grinding for in-game money to upgrade yo shi t.The GoodWell, if you're a new guy/lass in the truck simulator world, ATS is a good way to spend your hard earned cash and get bored in about 5 hours. You get nice graphics, a decently sized map, somewhat realistic truck handling and "tons" of work to do.The BadIf you're like me and have gone through all the truck simulator games from the first 18WoS to this crap, I'll let you know this has nothing over previous titles but improved graphics and smarter traffic. The developer is clearly trying to get some cash one more time from enthusiasts pulling the same maneuver all over again.  I mean, after 3 years since European Truck Simulator was released, they come with a copy of that taking place on the East Side of the USA this time, saying it's their biggest s h i t so far and even more good things are about to happen. Well, the cake is a lie...I know there is copyright work to be done before using real trucks in game, but all they managed to get so far are three fkin truck models... THREE ! And two of them sound and feel exactly the same. There's also no visual damage and everything stays nice and shiny forever, you know, like a truck in the real world. And what do you think they did next? They came up with a 3EUR DLC that allows you to chage rims and tires... fkin rims and tires, mate... just like it's the 2000's again and we all want to play NFS Underground but with trucks this time. I hope the next one adds neons and wings...Seriously, how about adding some realistic damage instead of some percentages shown in tiny boxes next to the truck in diagnose mode? Or, how about the trucks getting dirty, oily or dusty depending where you drive them? Or even better, make the game really put you in the driver's skin; get out of the truck to couple/uncouple the tailer, refuel, repair a flat tire to make the game a bit more tricky to play. It just gets so damn boring after about 5 hours of playtime. And also make sure you use the ingame currency a bit more accurate.... who the hell spends 180K to upgrade to a medium garage but only 100k to upgrade to a really big garage?I can only hope that at least the workshop enthusiasts will put out more trucks and dirty/oily/rusty skins. I lost my faith in SCS. Don't buy this recycled garbage if it's not on sale for about 2 bucks....

Don't be a fool like me, buy ATS when they will be finished. Someday. 1/10

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												You are a truck driver. Your goal is to build your trucking empire, one job at a time. Beginning the game, you'll be introduced to a simple delivery job that explains the controls and acts as a tutorial. Afterwards, you'll be dumped at your garage, tasking with saving up enough money to buy your own truck by doing work for other companies. Eventually, you'll be able to buy your own truck, and gain access to the Freight Market, which pays more than the Quick Jobs from contractors. However, you'll have to pay for your own expenses: damages, fuel, fines, and more. The graphical design of American Truck Simulator echoes the games of its past. While it does attempt to stay current with visual effects like lens flares, godrays and more, ultimately the game's graphics won't impress anybody. The truck models are highly-detailed, and leave little to be desired, but the textures throughout the world are often muddy, low resolution, and can be a bit of an eyesore up close. However, once you're out on the open highway, it's easy to find yourself getting lost in the long winding road ahead of you, with only subtle mountains in the background as a backdrop. The sun beats down on the hot tar below your tires, and it shines up in your face, effectively blinding you if you look just the wrong way.  These graphics, however, are a double-edged sword. While the game does by no means look great, this also allows for lower-end hardware to play the game, and play it well to boot. The game is not very demanding, and even lower-end configurations will not struggle to drive the game. On an NVIDIA GTX 970, paired with an Intel i7-5820k, I averaged 110fps throughout my gameplay. This is with everything maxed, and 400% scaling.  The trucks look good, the backdrops hold up well, but the ground textures, building textures, and AI vehicles look lackluster for a game released in 2016. When put alongside another brand new release, like Rise of the Tomb Raider, you can clearly see that SCS Software was not out to achieve the best in graphical capabilities.American Truck Simulator is, at its heart, a simulation game. As such, it does this very, very well. Bar-none, it is the most realistic driving game available on PC, and likely available, period. That being said, the engine used in this game is the exact same engine in SCS Software's previous installment, Euro Truck Simulator 2.This means that while the simulation in this game is excellent, it's no better than the game before it. Granted, there's little room for improvement in the game, so I see no reason to fix what isn't broken here.  Immediately starting the game, you'll find yourself dropped into a truck. On-screen prompts will walk you through the basics of the interface, and then you'll be on your way. This game has excellent gamepad and wheel support, and they should be a breeze to set up if you prefer it over kb+m. Once you're all set up, it's time to hit the road. You'll immediately notice how much weight you feel in your truck. The steering is heavy, the acceleration is a game of patience, and the laws of the road are ever-present, adding another layer of pressure while you're getting accustomed to your new big rig.  Jobs will require you to take a trailer of contents from one location to the next, and your SatNav will indicate your route. This will be your guardian angel as you trek across the land. Below your SatNav, your miles-to-go is displayed, letting you know how much longer you have left in your drive. You'll need to be particularly mindful of your fuel, and your consciousness. As you drive, these two will drain. If you become too tired, you'll drift in and out of consciousness, and eventually pass out at the wheel, racking up fines as you drive while exhausted. If you run out of fuel, you'll find yourself dead in the water in the middle of the road, with your only option being to pay for a tow truck to the nearest rest stop. The world of American Truck Simulator boasts a plethora of winding roads, hills and dusty back roads to drive across. Each offers a distinct style of gameplay while you head towards your destination. American Truck Simulator™  is a fun game, hindered by a lack of content. While SCS Software plans to release additional trucks and states, in its current state, the game offers little more than a re-skin of its predecessor set in a not-so-interesting location. Fans of the previous game will definitely find many hours of enjoyment, but newcomers are definitely encouraged to look toward the previous title for their first foray into the truck simulation world. Small UI and gameplay improvements are a welcome addition, but it doesn't change enough to make it feel like a new game. With that said, however, it is priced competitively and fairly, and finds itself costing little more than the Scandinavia DLC for the previous game in the series.

												Ok... ATS is a great game, don't get me wrong here but there is still a lot of work to be done to get this game up to standards. The number of police I see on the road is crazy, the fines they give out too are quite harsh but I do like how they put their sirens on when you go over the speed limit. There are lots of great features in this game such as the tumbleweed, which is a great touch.The bugs... wow, don't get me started... The game often crashes on load despite all my drivers being up to date and my PC is perfectly adequate with a GTX 970 and an intel i7 4790kAnother stupidly annoying thing is how all my save games seem to dissappear... They are all clearly in my savegames folder yet don't appear on my game.The scaling of the game is horrible. Why it takes such a short time to get places, I don't even know. ETS2 is much better scaled compared to this.The fact that there are only two states in the game is quite frustrating but I feel that SCS may be planning to add more states as DLC content like ETS2 Going East and Scandinavia.If you are thinking of getting this game, I recommend waiting a month or two for SCS to sort out the many bugs in the game and to add some more content to the game before buying it.Overall I will rate this game 4/10 Mainly because of it's many bugs and issues.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Pros:   - Awesome Scenery   - Same great handling physics from ETS   - Plays nice with Keyboard, Xbox Controller or Wheel   - AI seems to be a bit better   - Playing the Classic Rock Radio while driving down a lone empty highway in Nevada? Amazing!Cons:   - Lack of content.             - Only (2) Trucks on release as well as (2) states; even for 20 bucks that's pushing it.   - Speed limits seem odd, they change to rapidly in / out of cities. Cops are unforgiving and you'll get a fine for going   3MPH over. AI is also unrealistic in this respect, instantly changing speed from 55MPH down to 35.   - Lack of On Ramps. Has anyone from SCS every been on an American Highway? There's a leadup to gain speed! ATS just dumps you directly onto the highway with no merge zone.  Overall, a fun game. If you enjoyed Euro Truck, but wanted the American Trucks and maps, this game is for you! I've had a great time so far besides the above mentioned cons, and looking forward to what SCS and mods will bring!

This is my opinion of the game as it stands.After spending just a few hours in game this is what I think.If you liked ETS2 you will like this, it is exactly the same with a few added updates (apart from truck models).Whats the same?Driving is the same.Business management is the same (none existant).Graphics are the same, (LOD levels need tweeking for longer view distance in LOD 0 (closest on ultra settings)).Menus are the same.EverythingWhats new?New parking selection (skip, easy and slightly harder than easy).Weigh bridge (annoying pull in at weigh bridge, stop and press enter to pass).New locations to drop off at (not many new places to drop off at mind you).Police (basically speed cameras have been taken out and put in mobile cars).What could make the game better for me?More business managementOwn trailers (maybe drop off a trailer in your yard and get AI to complete job, just a suggestion).Change the map scale (takes no time at all to drive 1000 miles).Fix the AI from pulling out of junctions infront of me.Use a better materials for assets (mode detailed and more up to date).Police cars can detect you speeding on the other side of teh carrage way!!.is it worth £15?In my humble opinion YES BUT BUT more work needs doing on the engine itself to make the game more enjoyable to me I would like to see these two things.Owning trailers.More business management (thi is no 1).

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
American Truck Simulator... Is it worth it?Review written on 04/02/16American Truck Simulator is basically Euro Truck Simulator 2, set in the West coast of the USA. So if you didn't like Euro Truck Simulator 2, you're probably not going to enjoy this Sim.General jist of the game (For New Players)So just like ETS2, you start off by creating your new, exciting delivery company and character. You then take on a few quick delivery jobs around California and Nevada (More states coming soon). Eventually, you can get loans which then allow you to purchase your own truck so you can do freight jobs where you use your own equipment. (You get more money for this)You can then upgrade your garage to allow more spaces for employees, buy more trucks and hire employees to make more money. There is a skill tree and as you level and progress through the game, you can unlock delivery jobs such as hauling Dynamite, gassess and whatnot.The ProsThe game is highly addictive if you're the type of person that gets satisfaction from a mundane task; it's the thought of developing your own company and working really hard to get by which is really fun. After quite a few hours on this game already, I can tell I'm quite hooked and I find that driving around isn't as boring as it looks.The driving is just as good as ETS2, the physics are really decent and it's pretty damn realistic. But then again, I'm not a truck driver, so how would I know?More content coming soon! This game only has 2 states so far and only two truck brands, but more is on the way, such as the Arizona state and a few more truck brands.The ConsThis game like every other Simulator, is a massive grind and I can see myself eventually getting bored or tired of repeating myself. But you've got to remember, it is a Simulator and you're supposed to work hard for little reward.The lack of states in this game is slightly dissapointing as you feel like there should be more places to go, however I found that after my current play time, I have seen a lot and there's still a lot to see. There are also only two car brands which is a shame as there's not much choice in what truck to buy at the start. It's 50/50 chance you'll get the same truck as me.Speed Limits! Every country has them, but God damn! I want to scream when I'm in a 55 Mph zone when you could clearly do 70! And don't get me started on the 30 Mph limit, it's so painful!ConclusionIf you fancy giving the game a go, why not? It's really good for the price of £14.99 and I'd reccommend at least trying it. Please remember, it is a Simulator and can be boring; if you're the type of person that just wants to get going immediately and shoot people, this isn't for you.I am enjoying the game a lot and had to force myself to come off so I could make the badge. I'm going to go to bed, wake up, go to college, go home, and play this all evening... Again.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Fun?  Sure.  Simulator?  Not really. While it's a fun game, I have this and Euro Truck 2, there's a lot that needs to be improved to the "American" roads in this game.  To me, it appears that they just re-used assets from Euro.  Which is fine unless you're actually familiar with American roadways...  I always assumed that these strange road designs were how Euro roads are, I've never been there so I don't know.  The fact that the same strange designs are in the American version just IRKS me.  I'm torn because I like the game but the fact that these exist just exudes a level of laziness by the devs.  Google street view exists!Short SHORT interstate on-ramps, at a 10% or better grade and end right at the top?!  Not realistic!  I'm doing (max) 20 mph at the top of the ramp trying to merge into 80mph traffic?  Holy hell batman.There are some ramps I have to cross into oncoming traffic to turn right onto because there's a guard rail right on the white line?  What the actual ♥♥♥♥?!  Who puts a guard rail on the inside of a flat corner people are going 5-10mph around???  Not realistic.Guard rails and Concrete medians/barriers that simply just start without the crumple pads?  Not realistic.Guard rails and Concrete medians/barriers that are literally RIGHT on the yellow line?  Not realistic.The stop lines in some intersections are out WAYYY too far.There are a ton of 80mph roads in American truck simulator and that's not realistic.  The highest limit in Cali is 70, Nevada and Arizona are 75.If you miss your exit, instead of the GPS actuallly re-routing you, it does nothing.  Basically tells you "Hey, go back the other way".  Like you're going to make a U-Turn on an interstate.Why are my brakes not set when I hop into a hired truck?I waffle on my recommendation for this game, I wish there was a sideways thumb for a "maybe".  I'd recommend if you don't care about it's complete disregard of American roadway accuracy...  This is a trucking game.  You'd think accurate roadways would have been top priority.

												I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys an immersive experience.While I am not a car junky, I do enjoy driving across the country with only the sound of police sirens wailing as I breeze past them at a completely reasonable 90 miles per hour.When a fellow American decides to stop moving because there is a red light, I sometimes exercise my rights by pushing said bystander and their vehicle onto the side walk with my 10 tons of freedom.Sometimes people decide to slow down with a semi-truck behind them and you as the driver have to decide whether or not you will teach them a lesson or deal with a concussion as your truck flips 90 degrees and slides a quarter mile down the highway.You'll also experience crippling debt as you work literally 24 hours a day 7 days a week just to pay off the truck you purchased on money lended to you. Expect a greedy police officer around every corner to steal yet another $1,400 just for going a measly 40 mp/h above the speed limit.I love this game. It taught me to never become a truck driver or I would end up overdrafting my bank account 3 times a day 7 days a week, as well as suffer daily concussions due to my truck flipping at least twice a day.

content:
Posted: February 19
												I love European Truck Simulator 2, no doubt - smooth playing, no major glitches, wonderful way to spend time. Still, ATS didn't feel the same as ETS2, just located in USA, which I was expecting at first. Tried the demo earlier, which didn't feel that much different, but the actual game was a refund case on my account - even when bought from sale. There are probably some issues with the Xbox360 controller drivers as I coudln't get it work right out of the box the same as ETS2 and there could be some other details of programming of the game play that differ, something that tells ATS that little different from ETS2 to spoil the first impression. And I'm very sorry to have to say this..About the looks of the game, the American style trucks are rather heavy on  visual details, thus the graphics might need more oomph on the GPU to look real good. More minimalistic European trucks are easier to render and look more "natural" and eye pleasing with less GPU power - which is an important point to consider. Also the cabins of the US trucks are a bit problematic because of their design, don't quite fit on a single HD monitor, thus side mirrors stay out of picture unless you zoom the cabin view to near max, causing the front window to narrow down quite a bit.I will wait if there will  be a major update with some of these issues smoothed out, especially the gamepad compatibility to have another look at ATS, until then will stick with ETS2 and its DLCs, and maybe some independent mods too on top of that.I can still recommend ATS with the above reservations taken into account and if you're not already familiar with ETS2 - or if you for some reason just don't like Europe particularly, or just prefer "America first" in general (joke) - otherwise, think of ETS2 as the game to go to first.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												OK where to begin, This game is awesome. I have come over from ETS 2 so i knew what to expect and what not to expect. There is not alot of difference in the games, but then again is there truely alot of difference in driving big rigs in Europe and North America? You move cargo from this city to that city for a transportation fee. On the flip side youve promised to transport it and delieve it as youve picked it up or you face penalties. Now as ive seen people complain a little bit about lack of content. You are very much right, there isn't alot here.. YET.. i think if we can expect half of the love the SCS has put into ETS 2 we will be more than pleased. And for those that say they dont want the DLC's and for content to be thrown in for free, Realize that SCS has released this in knowing there wasnt alot and have adjusted the price accordingly. $20 is not a bad price and i was more than happy to pay. i believe as the game is, it is worth $20.  I personally will be willing to pay for Reigons (the mountain states, the midwestern states, the east coast) and different trucks (although i believe they will be added in free of charge) So as a final verdict, I give this game a solid 7/10 The game is what they say it is, and this score will rise once the rest of the game has fleshed out more in reigons and trucks.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I'm going to say this outright, for those giving it a bad review and otherwise putting the game down, we all need to realize the reason the game is here in this condition is because we where pushing for it, we kept asking for it and nudging SCS for it and really put on the preasure to get this game out. I'm not going to claim its bad, its very good - But i am going to say at this point it should be labeled or treated as a early access game.The game plays and feels very much like ETS2 - which is good, its better to have a familiar feeling game then a game that has entirely new everything and makes it so returning players have to learn everything all over again, its on a very simular engine, i believe slightly updated, so we can expect the same modding community that made ETS2 massive and awesome to do the same for ATS. And for those saying its a EA games style thing, make a complete game, then rip everything out and sell it all back as DLC to milk more money out of it - i feel SCS isnt going to do this, they may charge for future dlc or may not, that is something only time can tell, however the prices are most likely going to be low (as they where for ETS2) and most if not all players can afford 90% of the DLC without issue. Considering the Quality of the game and the quality of the community behind it, i think we should be proud and consider ourself lucky that we get this the way we do. Remember: We asked for this, they had gotten the game to a position they where comfortable in giving us access to it - and now all i can see if people complaining that they didnt get enough or exactly what they expected. I feel we need to cut SCS a break, and we shouldn't make them feel that they've got their foot in a pile either way they go.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												"The Freerider"~ By Robertson Crusoe"Whenever I take a job, may it be heavy load or a simple drive, I feel strange. I would always turn my head and see my bed behind the drivers seat and I know I am already home. Because my home is where I am. I would turn the radio on and listen to classic rock. Than I would turn on the engine and drive my truck through valleys and fields and towns and unknown places. Cars will pass me. Some will vanish in the rearview as the cities fade out when I leave them. And I drive and I am free.But than I wake up. I see the clock and know the alarm clock will go off soon. And I realize that I am caged and that I am just sitting in front of a screen showing me a life that I don't have but that I always desired. And my 9 to 5 job calls me and I work papers I don't understand and I don't connect. And I am a servant to my income. To pay for my home. But when I am back home, I will turn the engine on again and ride freely through a place that only exists in my dream.I am the freerider. And I am already home. Home."

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												So I do like this game quite a bit. It's rather a good time killer but to be honest I don't think that in good conscience recommend this game at this time.Pros:- Real big rigs, not those sorry excuses for rigs in ETS.- A lot of cool things to make your truck your own- Most of the content is free at some point- Good Dev team.Cons:- Drive over train tracks any faster than 20mph and your truck flips and causes 100% damage to tractor and trailer- 4 Tractors- Small map over all even with one of the biggest states in the USA included- Cops give you tickets for anything other than perfection, even if you wipe your♥♥♥♥♥the wrong way- Weigh stations with no other purpose than to annoy you and give you more tickets- Bad sounds that are not close to being real- No shifter when using manual trans- Never dark enough to really make your lights useful at all- Can only sleep in designated areas and not on the side of the road as you would be able to in real life if you had to- AI drivers crash into you constantly even if you are sitting still at a red light- Many things are extremely over priced or under pricedWhile I do rather enjoy this game it is hard to get past some of the stupidness of the way it currently is. Over all it plays more like an Early Access or Alpha/Beta stage game. Buy at your own risk and desire.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Short version - Like Eurotruck Simulator 2, except in America. If you liked ETS2, you'll like ATS.As is, at release, the ATS map is pretty darn small, averaging 600 to 700 miles end-to-end. Yeah if I manually configure the SatNav to go into smaller, undiscovered roads, I might get 900 miles... maybe.Personally, I somehow find that American important locations in towns and cities, as depicted in the game, are spread too far apart. You can drive a couple of minutes to get to the company you want to take a job for, or to get to a service centre to get your truck repaired/upgraded. This eats into you "awake time" in the game, and you start yawning very quickly (to me) while on the road.Plus, rest stops seem to be rather scarce in America when compared to Europe. Good thing is, you don't get fined for not sleeping. Speed limit signs are almost non-existent. Woe be to you if you were in the process of slowing down from 70 to 30 when approaching a city, and a cop car happens to pass you - you get fined.....EVEN WHEN YOU'RE SLOWING DOWN.On the up-side - No speed cameras :)

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												I just barely recommended this game, and my opinion is subject to change as the game progresses; but as of now, my review is as follows.I am an American trucker. I have been for a while now. I own my own rig. I run all 48 states, plus Canada and Alaska. I played ETS2 more than any other game in the past 30 years. (even more than super mario) I loved that game. It was the first simulation game for trucking that came anywhere near the real thing. Now, I do not live in Europe. I cannot say how similar it actually is to true Euro Trucking. Well, this is American Truck Simulator and I am an American trucker, so certain things do stick out to me. For one, no where in the USA, will you have an interstate with a state road just turning into it. You'll never find that. You will have a long on ramp and off ramp for these. Every single time. There are no splits in the interstate. Also, the layout of the truck stops is way too similar to ETS2, and nowhere near similar to true American truck stops. Yeah, I see that there are some legal issues dealing with naming the big truck stops (Loves, Petro, Pilot, Flying J, TA), but don't take something that is never a truck stop (Chevron) and turn it into one. Also, you'll never find a truck stop that just turns off of the interstate. You'll always take an exit, go a few blocks down and then it will be all by itself or surrounded by other buildings. I was really hoping that this would be more accurate. Some truckstops are challenging, while others are a cake walk. However, you will never find a truck stop that pulls off of the interstate like a rest area, and you will never find a truck stop with parallel parking. It will always be back in parking.Now onto the trucks. I get it, the game is new. But why only 2 trucks to start out with? Maybe I'm playing it wrong, but maybe not. I'm not going to touch too much on this; but I will say I hope to see more trucks appear very soon. (Not just models, but other makes also)My biggest beef, besides the interstate shortcomings, is the fact that the game devs decided to put this in California. (Or as some truckers call it, Commiefornia) This is the single worst state to drive a truck in. It is far from the "American spirit" in regards to trucking. It has the slowest speed limit, the highest emissions laws, and the most corrupt state Department of Transportation in the country. If this game were to really see the heart of American trucking, they should have started it off in the Midwest or the South. Anywhere from Kansas to Texas would have been best. Something with a high agriculture outport, high manufacturing, and even high livestock. But no, we had to go with California, who imports most of what they ship from China. Oh well, I can only hope that more states will be added, and soon. I see that Arizona is next on the list to be released, and I am just curious as to what cities they are planning on introducing, and what they believe actually ships out of Arizona. Should be interesting to see. I really also wish that the backing in the game was harder. I see that it has gotten more difficult from ETS2, but it is FAR from being accurate with some of the shippers and receivers around this country. How about some 90 degree blind side alley backs? Or how about some blindside parallel parks for flatbeds? These are what truckers have to deal with daily here; so why not throw a few, or a ton, of them into the game? It would add more of a challenge while, at the same time, becoming a bit more realistic.Now, I did give this a "yes I would recommend" vote. It is a fun simulation, and for what it's worth, the simulation is fairly accurate. You won't find a better trucking simulator out there. Hell, even trucking schools have worse software to teach people how to drive a truck. This is a cheap game, at only $20, but it has amazing potential. I hope to see this game live up to my expectations, especially after having waited so long to get it. If you are not a trucker, this game will be great for you. If you are a trucker, you'll find the same gripes about it as I did; but you'll still play it.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I have played many of the trucking sims out on the market for many years.  Then about a year ago I bought Euro Truck Sim 2.  Very quickly found that I enjoyed the realism in the driving experience and really appreciated the Dev Group's work on improving and adding more maps and trucks to the game.  So when American Truck Simulator was announced I didn't hesitate.  SCS has not let me down at all with this newest version of their work.  Many people will complain about lack of truck choices and map size at the moment.  Please put it into perspective,  It takes time to get licenses to show the actual different makes of trucks in this game.  Most companies want their equipment painted in the best possible light so SCS has to make sure to do their best work on every truck, not just looks but function and capabilities.  As for the map some are saying that the highway driving doesn't seem long enough but please realize when the full USA is complete it will take an estimated 1 hr or more of real time to go coast to coast.  This is because of the sheer size of our country.  At this point I have zero complaints with the game and am just patiently waiting for the new updates that will come.  I do have some things I would like to see in the American version of this game but will post it to Dev's.P.S.  I am a real life OTR Trucker so if I can enjoy it then you can too.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												 I have over 100 hrs on ETS2, so I thought I'd write about my experiences with ATS.I live in Canada, so playing ETS2 was fun, but I had no clue whether or not what I was seeing was realistic or authentic. Now, since Canada and the US have very similar city layouts and stores, I was able to judge more ffectively whether or not what I was seeing was convincing. I was delivering a load and saw I was taking it to a grocery store. A big name grocery store, exactly like the ones I've seen accross the US and Canada. Something about this rather mundane experience seemed so immersive and realistic.The building of the store, the parking lot out front, and the loading dock in the back. Now to address the criticism of the lack of content. I do not fault them one bit. I don't want to steal the words of Daniel Hardcastle (Nerd3) so I'll summarize his explanation in this review, as he framed it in the most convincing manner I have heard yet. ETS2 has 2 previous games worth of content behind it, ETS and German Truck Simulator. This is a completely new venture, and the cities are much more fleshed out than in ETS2. So whereas only a few cities actually had many roads, now even smaller cities have a ton of roads and actual area you can drive around in, as opposed to seeing the rest in the distance.At the end of the day, it is NOT a revolutionary change from ETS2. But to anyone who complains of that, I have no idea what you were expecting. Overall, it's a good looking, reasonably priced and actively developing game and I can't be more excited for the future!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												I really want to leave a positive review for this game and recommend it to others.  I really do.  But after force re-starting my computer for the umpteenth time after trying to launch, I just can't.  This is my biggest gripe about the whole game.  Here are my specs:Intel i7 - 2600K 3.4 GHzRAM 16.0 GB64 bit x64 windows 10 (boy do I miss windows 7 tho)AMD Radeon HD 6900All drivers are up do date.The problem is this - roughly every third or fourth time I try to load a saved game, the game freezes.  I can still hear music, but I can't even ctrl-alt-del out of the game to force close it, it completely freezes my computer and forces me to do a hard reboot, which I hate.  Sometimes when I go back in the game after a re-boot it says there was an error and says reasons have to do with mods.  I have absolutely no mods on this game.  I have only the game I purchased and the updates SCS software did with the new truck.  If they ever fix this I will absolutely change my review to recommend this game, as when it works it is loads of fun.  I had never played ETS2 so I couldn't compare this to that, my gripes about in-game playing would be fines way too high and double if a cop sees you run a red light or hit someone (like it's more illegal if a cop sees you do it) but enforcement can now be turned off.  I do hate the stop lights in the middle of the interstate...and why they put spawn points for AI vehicles at a T junction to an interstate I'll never know.  The only way to actually get on the interstate from here is to pull out, slowly, in front of traffic and force them to stop.Also the wheels of the truck while turning only turn the full degrees while stopped, not sure what that's about.  When you hire drivers and they 'couldn't find a job, $950 in fuel costs', seems odd that they don't know how to use a phone or the internet.  If SCS wants to limit funds I think it would be more realistic to have a message say, 'XXX called in sick today and could not work'.For some reason, regardless if you are in NV or CA, you seem to be driving uphill both ways.  This could be just me.  For the pros:Graphics are amazing.  I like the progression to higher levels, more money per level, unlocks to truck upgrades and paint jobs.  Having driven thru CA and NV, the realism for the terrain and landmarks are great, I can't wait for other states to be added. TLDR:  I would recommend if I didn't have to force re-boot my computer every day.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												As a fan of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I really like American Truck Simulator after 20 hours of playing.Compared to ETS2, there are some new game elements such as roaming police cars (giving speeding tickets if they're near you) and different parking possibilities (harder spots for more XP or easier spots for less XP).However, by far the biggest difference is the world map. Although it isn't very large yet (only California and Nevada for now), it is beautifully designed. Both cities and remote areas (e.g. in Nevada) feel much more authentic compared to ETS2.Mostly the same gameplay, yet in a beautiful new world with the promise of many (paid) map expansions to come... Highly recommended for fellow ETS2 fans.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												So I decided that my Haulage company, Freddytrux, should start trading in the US of A. Well I must say that this English upstart, Freddytrux USA, has been finding trading conditions slightly difficult. Oh to be able to import a good old Swedish Volvo instead of the insipid Kenworth or Peterbilt trucks. Hopefully as Freddytrux USA grows then the options on the available trucks will become better.The rozzers, or as the locals call them, the cops, seem to be incredibly mean handing out all sorts of traffic offence fines or insistant demands to be weighed. (sorry officer, I need to cut down on the pork pies.) And then there's the rather strange affair of vehicles turning right on a red light, pray tell, what is that all about? I guess it's legal though, because no rozzers have issued a demand on Freddytrux USA's limited funds for it.The user interface will be familiar to ETS2 players, but I did get caught out on the delivery procedure a couple of times, as that is new to ATS, but that's my own fault for skipping the tutorial bit about it. I wanted to crack on and get my Kenworth rolling. The scenery looks kind of nice despite running the game on a toaster spec laptop, and surprisingly the game tends to run smoothly with only minimal lagging. I'm guessing that some creative licence has been used in much the same way as ETS2. So far only California and Nevada are covered with Arizona coming soon, LA to The Big Apple hauls could be a while yet.There are some improvements that could be made, more trucks to choose from and more states to drive through although my understanding is that these issues a currently being looked at. And how I would love to be able to import my cabover Volvo FH16 GlobetrotterXL from ETS2.ATS is still recommended by me though. It's as immersive as ETS2 with new trucks to drive and new roads to explore. Must run, I have a cargo of frozen fruit needed in LA. Never fear, Freddytrux USA is here.(30th Dec '16) Arizona is now included and has been for some time, now you can visit the Grand Canyon by truck, take a detour for some sightseeing. The Vovo FH16 Globetrotter XL is in too, that one is on the workshop as are a couple of other US and European types. Since I wrote my original review there have been several updates and the aforementioned Workshop support for a range of easy to add Mods of all manners.I still recommend ATS, Freddytrux USA is expanding, slowly for sure but expansion is coming along. Well I really should get on. "Gasolene" to the Americans, Petrol to me, is needed Tucson way. Once more unto the breach go Freddytrux USA. Why U-Haul when Freddytrucks can take the load.

The only way I could reasonably recommend this game to anyone is if they havent played ETS yet, that way they aren't as let down as I was

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												As a fan of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I really like American Truck Simulator after 20 hours of playing.Compared to ETS2, there are some new game elements such as roaming police cars (giving speeding tickets if they're near you) and different parking possibilities (harder spots for more XP or easier spots for less XP).However, by far the biggest difference is the world map. Although it isn't very large yet (only California and Nevada for now), it is beautifully designed. Both cities and remote areas (e.g. in Nevada) feel much more authentic compared to ETS2.Mostly the same gameplay, yet in a beautiful new world with the promise of many (paid) map expansions to come... Highly recommended for fellow ETS2 fans.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												 I have over 100 hrs on ETS2, so I thought I'd write about my experiences with ATS.I live in Canada, so playing ETS2 was fun, but I had no clue whether or not what I was seeing was realistic or authentic. Now, since Canada and the US have very similar city layouts and stores, I was able to judge more ffectively whether or not what I was seeing was convincing. I was delivering a load and saw I was taking it to a grocery store. A big name grocery store, exactly like the ones I've seen accross the US and Canada. Something about this rather mundane experience seemed so immersive and realistic.The building of the store, the parking lot out front, and the loading dock in the back. Now to address the criticism of the lack of content. I do not fault them one bit. I don't want to steal the words of Daniel Hardcastle (Nerd3) so I'll summarize his explanation in this review, as he framed it in the most convincing manner I have heard yet. ETS2 has 2 previous games worth of content behind it, ETS and German Truck Simulator. This is a completely new venture, and the cities are much more fleshed out than in ETS2. So whereas only a few cities actually had many roads, now even smaller cities have a ton of roads and actual area you can drive around in, as opposed to seeing the rest in the distance.At the end of the day, it is NOT a revolutionary change from ETS2. But to anyone who complains of that, I have no idea what you were expecting. Overall, it's a good looking, reasonably priced and actively developing game and I can't be more excited for the future!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												I really want to leave a positive review for this game and recommend it to others.  I really do.  But after force re-starting my computer for the umpteenth time after trying to launch, I just can't.  This is my biggest gripe about the whole game.  Here are my specs:Intel i7 - 2600K 3.4 GHzRAM 16.0 GB64 bit x64 windows 10 (boy do I miss windows 7 tho)AMD Radeon HD 6900All drivers are up do date.The problem is this - roughly every third or fourth time I try to load a saved game, the game freezes.  I can still hear music, but I can't even ctrl-alt-del out of the game to force close it, it completely freezes my computer and forces me to do a hard reboot, which I hate.  Sometimes when I go back in the game after a re-boot it says there was an error and says reasons have to do with mods.  I have absolutely no mods on this game.  I have only the game I purchased and the updates SCS software did with the new truck.  If they ever fix this I will absolutely change my review to recommend this game, as when it works it is loads of fun.  I had never played ETS2 so I couldn't compare this to that, my gripes about in-game playing would be fines way too high and double if a cop sees you run a red light or hit someone (like it's more illegal if a cop sees you do it) but enforcement can now be turned off.  I do hate the stop lights in the middle of the interstate...and why they put spawn points for AI vehicles at a T junction to an interstate I'll never know.  The only way to actually get on the interstate from here is to pull out, slowly, in front of traffic and force them to stop.Also the wheels of the truck while turning only turn the full degrees while stopped, not sure what that's about.  When you hire drivers and they 'couldn't find a job, $950 in fuel costs', seems odd that they don't know how to use a phone or the internet.  If SCS wants to limit funds I think it would be more realistic to have a message say, 'XXX called in sick today and could not work'.For some reason, regardless if you are in NV or CA, you seem to be driving uphill both ways.  This could be just me.  For the pros:Graphics are amazing.  I like the progression to higher levels, more money per level, unlocks to truck upgrades and paint jobs.  Having driven thru CA and NV, the realism for the terrain and landmarks are great, I can't wait for other states to be added. TLDR:  I would recommend if I didn't have to force re-boot my computer every day.
