content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												ATS  may only have two maps & two trucks , looking at the overal map that is currently blank more is in the pipe line.SCS have already stated that new maps will follow & for now they are free.There  are a few on going licencing issue's both with city names & Truck makes.SCS have a well proven record of bringing knew trucks to their games free as they gain the rights to use the name's.Though I am not sure about just how much of the map content will be free , & in that respect it could be like its older brother ETS2 where some of the maps were pay for DLC at a good price.SCS support is one of the best out there & as been since day one.I am sure this game will grow in very much the same way ETS 2 as over its life time.I most respects ATS as improved over ETS 2 both looks wise & playing wise .I agree that the time scaling needs tweaking to give a better feeling for the scale of driving in the USA.The weather looks better than ETS 2 the  detail looks better even if its based in a very dry part of the USA .The two truck look good drive ok after spend year playing ETS 2 driving these bigger long trucks & trailers takes some getting use to .That also reflects in the new parking system that gives you three options & an scaled amount of XP for the choice of trailer parking you decide to make.Though you are limited for load types & trailer types  as well as truck types , this balance can be adressed by the Large modding community that as grown along side SCS & it Truck game's Here you will find maps  given time , but for now even after only a few days since launch there are already  several truck types that can be added along with knew trailers  . cars . sounds & game tweaksThis as always been the strongest part for the game type & SCS have always supported modding & I hope its stays that way.For the low price you are paying here you get a good trucking based sim built on the same  quality that SCS have showns us in the past with all there Trucking game'sIts may be small but they have started out with Licenced content pritty much a first as far as know for one of their  game'sAs I seem to remember their first few  Euro based truck games shiped with unreal truck names & it took several versions of those games to get the licences for the rights to use those brands.So ATS will grow over the year now just like ETS 2 as into the game it is now.SCS will listen to players feed back & improve the game play and features , & I am sure the modders with do the same.Buy it .It a lot of fun & It will only get better.Pro Fair price for the size & content.SCS are one of the best devlopers around when it come's to support & developing their games.ATS should be no different when it comes to modding and already as several mods to download or in development.The game runs well out of the box even on older hardware like I am using.ConsLimited trucks types.Only two maps.Time scaling feels unbalanced.But nothing that I could makes the game not worth buying .If you like trucks or just want some relaxing driving then this is as good as it gets.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Now, I came into this game with the same mindset as most others. I figured it would be a reskin of ETS2. Boy was I wrong, however. American Truck Simulator has a completely different feel than ETS2. The menus may be the same, but the trucks are big, brash, and tower over all of the other cars unlike in ETS2. The trailers are much longer, giving it a new challenge that I didn't face in ETS2. The map may be small, but there are many intricate details that make it fun to drive on with every delivery. I highly reccommend this game to anybody new to the driving simulator scene, or a veteran looking for a new way to experience driving.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												So many people have written bad reviews for American Truck Simulator, and it's based around the price (which is a bargain) the content, and only having 2 trucks in the game.I find all of the above points for not buying the game, really quite silly. 1) The game is EXACTLY like Euro Truck Simulator 2 - its very similar in many ways.2) The game details is absolutely incredible. There are so many new things to see and do in the game, and the new parking choices are really nice to have.3) I'm absolutely delighted with the game as it is, and i cannot wait until I see more from SCS for American Truck Simulator.Seriously recommend it if you loved ETS2 - it's the same game, in America, with better detail and better options.11/10 - can't wait for more to come!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Coming from someone who played 400+ hours of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I personally feel this game is amazing. Sure, the scale is sort of small, and yes there isn't nearly as many roads as ETS2, but the cities and enviroment, and just level of detail make up for it. Don't get me wrong, American Truck Simulator is the same game as Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's a different map, different trucks, but the game is the same. However, in saying that, I feel American Truck Simulator is funner to play personally, and I haven't touched ETS2 since.You actually feel as if you ware driving through actual cities. The enviroments, I've driven down the same road 10 times, and still notice something new. American Trucks, in my opinion, are much funner to drive. While the map does skip some accuracy, it still feel similar. Driving through California feels like driving through California. I am a really happy camper, and plan on purchasing upcoming Map DLC to support these devs.FOR YOU LINUX USERS:I fully converted to Linux full time (no dual boot) in September 2015, and I must say, the Linux Version is remarkable. I have a GTX 980 and use Nvidia Proprietary Drivers (keep that in mind) and the performance is on par with the Windows Version. I even use a Logitech G27. No issues whatsoever. I'd give the SCS team a high five for this. Remarkable.My ONLY Complaint about this game, is still the lack of Force Feedback on Logitech G27 (and other wheels) under Linux. It's purely a Game Issue, as the Linux Beta for ETS2 had Force Feeback, then it was removed and never fixed. Force Feedback works flawlessly on every other game. If they would fix this, I would be so so grateful.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												You have to like the game for the mere fact that it is SCS Software and the game is still being developed which is why I can't really give a good or a bad review.Right now, the game has some bug issues that do need worked outPolice ticketing you: Ok the traffic is going much faster than I am. Say the speed limit is 55, and other traffic is going 70 including the cop, you'll get a ticket which makes no sense. They need to fix that.The GPS: It seems to be weirding out all of the sudden making it mark roads on the other side of the road. For instance, if you go on an off ramp, it will show it on the other side of the road as well to go on the other side of the road to get onto this ramp. Need to fix your GPS.Cars running into you: I've had this happen MANY times now when I am at a red light and a car will hit my truck causing me to have to pay for it. I've had cars come off of an on ramp and run right into my truck causing me to, again, pay for the fine. I've had cars in the passing lane run right into my truck for no apparent reason causing me to pay the fine. This starts♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off when you're trying to earn money and you're now racking up a repair bill.Customization of your truck: This game needs a bit more when it comes to customizing your ride. All though, this isn't a major issue or anything, this is something that would be just nice to have.Graphics: I run this game on full settings but the graphics seem a bit grainy for me. All though it isn't bad at all, it's just something they need to work on.Controls: I run this game with a keyboard, always have. The turning is great in this game. The braking is a bit weird from Euro Truck. But, all in all, it's great.Job: Considering this game is still in development I have not much to say other than it needs more to do in the game. So, still waiting for major updates as the map is extremely small compared to Euro Truck.The game engine: It seems they haven't done much improvements as far as the games engine goes for graphical settings. It seems to use the Euro Truck engine.I'll rewrite this review when they start adding more to the game so I can give a proper review. All in all, it is worth the money to me. Great game.My system specs: Processor: AMD 6300 FX (3.5 GHz 6 core) RAM: 8 GB DDR3 Corsair Vengeance Video: eVGA 750 Ti 2 GB FTW Game runs at a crisp 60 FPS with a few minor drops to 58 here and there.

												This game isn't perfect, but it's damn near close.The immersion of this game is quite awesome. The level of control over the settings and key bindings make it even more awesome. If you're like me and have a wheel ( I have a DFGT) it adds a different level of the game that you truly have to experience. A few gripes I have, as everyone has already been addressing: Right turn on red. Being able to make a right turn on red is a staple of driving culture here in the United States. Everyone does it. It's safe to do, provided you actually look to see if anyone is coming, and shaves precious seconds or even minutes off of your driving time... I'd like to see that implemented a little better in the game. Also...... Speed fines. Yes, it is well known that speeding tickets are a prime source of revenue generation for law enforcement here in the US, however speeding tickets for going less than 5 over are almost non-existant, at least in my neck of the woods anyway.To sum it all up, this game is worth every penny. It's fun. It's interesting. It's a good way to spend time. I can't wait to see more states implemented, especially the east coast. I want to see how West Virginia looks in the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												I want to preface this by saying it's not just a game, it's an investment. Yes, there's only 3 trucks (with another on the way) and 2 states (with Arizona on the way), but I knew this well in advance. In fact, the game was originally just going to be California.Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, this game is relaxing way to pass the time, see the country, and learn about it, albeit on a scaled down version. This game does a bit more than ETS 2 by recreating some locations and buildings. The cities are bigger, and some towns are so small they barely exist outside a gas station/rest area and a job site. Not every city has a garage and employment agency, so it won't be as easy to make money. Still plenty of truck customization options. Each truck has its own set of unique paintjobs too. Trailers can get longer, and on top of the longer cabs, you will have to figure out manuvering around corners. There's also multiple options for parking (and you can set it to always easy or hard in the Options). Police cars now roam the streets, so speed limits will be more enforced, and they're not as bad as they were in the beginning. Mod support has been immediate (and signs of going to Steam Workshop too).I'm going to keep on trucking, building up my company, leveling up to upgrade my truck, and waiting for new states to unlock and trucks to buy so I can go from sea to shining sea.

Posted: March 17, 2016
												I am going to be honest with a few stuff here:Negative Stuff:-The engine between ETS 2 and ATS is the same; the graphics, roads, trees, cars all look quiet the same.-Even the main menu/GPS is not changed.-The BOTS (cars other trucks) need to get a little bit smarter, when you pass to another direction, they get to crash on you; and you are to be blamed for that.-The only reason the game got published this quick is that it got leaked in the websites, forcing developers to publish it and not to lose money!I won't mention anything about the upcoming DLCs for NOW. Because SCS still can fix the prices on DLCs if they have read other people's reviews too.Positive Stuff:-The map is detailed.-The humans are doing action now. (Sweeping the floor etc.)-The roads are more detailed now.-Trucks still have a good simple understandable design.-There are now more frequent police cars, you get to have a higher fee if there is a police near by.-There are police waiting in a few rounds trying to catch people the that break the rules.-The lightning of trucks from ATS are much better than ETS 2.Overall the game still has a lot to improve, the game developers themselves made a huge mistake by leaking the game on the websites forcing them to publish the game and not to lose money. This also caused a lot of negative reviews and how the game was not even ready to be realesed. The SCS is currently working on making Arizona which will hopefully be published over in the next 2-3 months. The devs should also listen to comments of other people, they simply just listen to famous people that do not even understand what the game needs; this is a really big mistake done by them.Id give this game a rating 8/10 for now.Have a nice day!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												TLDR: If you think you might like it, you probably will. If you don't see the point, don't expect it to surprise you. There are problems, but I expect them to improve with DLC and patching.I'm not much into hard-sim games, but for some reason this one appealed. I couldn't even explain why.This game doubles up as a hardcore truck-driving simulator, and a casual time-sink. If you want to get a steering-wheel controller, manual shifter input and analogue pedals, play the whole game from the driver's camera perspective and grind out your hours as a big-rig stalwart, it's well set up for that. Slowly build your business, earn the right to take high-value cargo for long distance hauls, plan your fuel & rest stops, watch your speed and park your trailer perfectly every time for bonus XP.But if you just want to use your WASD & mouse, pick up a Quick Job and drive from point-to-point for ten minutes, bashing through the occasional stop-start idiot who clogs up the junction, ditching the trailer at the gate and logging off again... well, that's totally fine too. It's a sim. You can be as serious or casual as you like.Both are fun, in different ways, and the game does well at supporting both styles of play.POSITIVEI have one thing to say here, but it's a big one: this game is, on occasion, breathtakingly beatufiul. I have had moments when a sunrise vista has opened up before me, after a gruelling 15hr (well, 15m) night drive through a featureless desert, pushing the speed limit to try and hit my destination before blacking out from exhaustion, and the moment has given me *real feels!* Like, a wistful wanderlust, or a warm familiar feeling. In some small way, I felt what it was like to be a long-haul trucker.This can only be achieved by a number of things coming together. Distinct and recognisable landscapes; above-par atmospheric lighting & graphics, sufficient technical challenge to keep you focussed and slightly stressed for long periods of time, and a solid enough engine to make it all feel immersive. I was genuinely startled when some tumbleweeds blazed across the road in my headlights one night.That's only one positive, but it can't be overstated.NEGATIVEThere are bugs. It's a sim, so there are always limitations on realism, but the AI of police and other road users is occasionally crushingly stupid or arbitrary.There is also a limit on the game's size - two states (at launch) greatly scaled-down only gives you a few hours' driving before you've seen it all. The details are pretty good and I'm sure it'll be improved by DLC in future, but for now it's a big limitation.Sometimes, very rarely, using a Steam Controller, the control scheme will just break, and you'll go careening into a barrier at 55mph for no reason. Such immersion-breaking is criminal for a sim, and I hope Steam and/or the developers get on that ASAP. Today my controller suddenly started providing massive haptic feedback, contrary to my settings, so... yeah. New game, new technology. Fingers crossed.The biggest problem, though, is the strategic side of things. Upgrading your truck (beyond a bigger engine & improved gearbox) is very costly but basically pointless. It's a cosmetic change to something you pretty much never see. But then the only other thing you can spend your hard-earned cash on is growing the business, which... just brings in more money. I don't know what else you could expect from a truck sim, but it seems like a one-dimensional management game has been tacked on the side with little purpose.Once I realised the larger game offered little more than the (casual) Quick Job mode, the game lost a lot of its appeal. It was a cathartic ride up to that point, though, so I'll probably still dip in occasionally, and I'm happy to recommend it for the money. If the challenge of technical driving appeals to you, this is worth a look.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Well, folks.  Here we are.  The Hype is real and still is!I bought ATS as it is called by players because I loved ETS2 and wanted to play an American Truck game, like the old 18 WoS days.  So far, I'm not disappointed by the game one bit.  Yeah, you only get two trucks at the start, and I'm fine with that.  The reasoning for the lack of immediate content is actually a good one for once.  It is because rather than put fake brands in the game, SCS wants to get licenses first.  But, as said by Pavel Sebor himself, getting licenses from truck manufacurers that aren't used to being approached for licenses of their product is like the chicken vs egg debate.  So, they are going about it the right way at least.On to the gameplay.  Those of you that are familiar with ETS2 will have no problem getting used to the ATS Gameplay.  There are a lot of new things to compliment to already very good base gameplay that I hope will be making it's way to ETS2 soon as well.  Delivery Points are the biggest advancement in the gameplay system.  You can choose how difficult you want the delivery to be.  From a zero point quick drop to a 90 point drop that is so complex, even the most Veteran Driver will have a challenge are available for choosing.Weigh Stations are new to the game.  You can be randomly chosen to go to the Scale House for Inspection.  It's an interesting feature, but a bit of a waste of time and ruins fuel economy.  Hopefully, SCS will be able to do something to give this feature more meaning.After talking about weigh stations, we have no choice but to talk about the new police engine.  Now, the dreaded Rozzers are mobile and sneaky.  I got a Speeding Ticket for not being at 30 MPH right after the sign changed.  There needs to be a Reduced Speed Ahead sign, like in real life here in the States.So, lets break it down to the Pros and Cons.ProsFamiliar yet tweaked GameplayAmerican TrucksNevada included Scenery that will blow your mindEaster Eggs, yes, there a few, and no, I will not tell you what they areNo curves every 20 feet like ETS2ConsOnly two states at the beginningOnly two trucks at the beginning,  Not really a con, but may put some people offThe UI is completely Copy/Paste.  Would have loved to see the Route Adviser remodeled.  Maybe next time.Only 64-Bit Having looked at the facts and played a long time, I can give a solid 9 out of 10.  This game is definitely worth a buy.  It's continued development is something I look forward to.UPDATE:  W900 is out and it's not bad.  The sounds need a little tweaking still, but at least it's there.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Before I begin, I want everyone to know that I've been waiting on this game for years now. Ever since we were told they began development. I knew exactly what I was going to get, so I'm basing my review on that.____When you first see the game, it looks exactly like Euro Truck Simulator 2. The only differences include it being in the United States, having vehicles driven in the United States, trailers that are used in the United States, and a couple states in the United States.After you get past the $20 price tag and actually get in the game, it's exactly as it seems. Just a reskin of ETS2. But what was to be expected? It's the same engine used to rebuild ETS2 for a different region. That's what we were told we were going to receive and that's what we got. I am not at all upset that we only get 2 states at release with Arizona coming a little later for free and 2 trucks. I knew I was getting that and I paid the price for that.The developers wanted to go the correct route with the game and get licensing for the vehicles used so the lack of vehicles is okay. As time goes on, we'll get loads more. As far as states go, 3 might not seem like much. With the scale, it definitely seems lacking in content. But you have to remember. If they went to a more in-depth scale and added more content, then it'd take years for a single state to come out. I don't know about you, but I'd like to have 48 states before I turn 70 years old. :PAnd the game is called American Truck Simulator. American. The United States is only one of dozens upon dozens of countries in America. Canada and Mexico are 2 more countries in NORTH America. Meanwhile, there's still South America that has to be scaled in. By the time we get all of that(if we ever do, the plans could change), we'd have so much map, we wouldn't be able to explore it all in a reasonable amount of time. Sure, California and Nevada might not seem like much, but they are comparable to Great Britain and France in ETS2 when you talk about size. Now add the equivelent amount of states as there are countries in ETS2 and you have the United States completed. UK and France might not seem like much on ETS2, but when you travel from one to the other, and then all the way to Poland and then up to Sweden, you start to realize that even though the map is small now, it will be much bigger later on when we have more content to play.Not much of a regular review that you'd see on Steam, but these are my opinions on the game so far. It's a reskin of ETS2 and that's what we were told and what we paid for. No complaints here. Still a billion times better than most simulators out there.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												The ones who liked Euro Truck Simulator for its qualities will also like the American Truck Simulator.Technically, it is to 90% the same game, the difference in the 10% are the following:1) Instead of European Trucks you're driving the American ones of cause.2) You can design your own driving route now on the map just like e.g. in Google Maps on your smartphones with waypoints.3) Instead of just parking your trailer manually and autoparking it you now can chose between a medium/hard way to park it manually, an easy way to park it manually and the alrdy known autoparking. For the medium/hard way you get the most XP (40/90 XP-Points))4) The game world is filled with life to a higher degree, there are more peasants walking on the pedestrian walks, there are workers working on the delivery/reception sites, there are security men standing in front of supermarkets etc etc.5) There are more different delivery sites, instead of just delivering to company yards and building sited you can now also deliver to gas stations.6) The game is set in America (Cpt. Obvious strikes again).The game is available for a fair price of 20€, for which you get the US-States of California, Nevada and Arizona (That's still in the pipeline).But California and Nevada for themselves are alrdy highly detailed, there are about 10-15 cities in California and about 10 in Nevada, so, if you compare it with the Old 18 Wheels of Steel Games from SCS, where California had two cities, a huge increase!Arizona is coming for free too, what States in which Quantity the other DLC's will deliver is subject to the future, I don't know that.I think, that SCS, as they alrdy did with ETS2 and its DLC's, will deliver a reasonable amount of DLC's for a fair price and with a fair content in it.As I've read, relying on that this wasn't a joke, they plan to eventually map the whole of North- and Latin-America atleast down to the equator, but of cause this is a work for years to come.All in all, this game, just like his older brother ETS 2, is a shining juwel in the simulation genre and I can recommend it from the bottom of my heart.Update #01: Another positive thing: Just days after release they alrdy added the third truck the legendary Kenworth W900, a truck the community asked for. Another reason to recommend the game, because of the consumerfriendly policy of SCS, thumbs up!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I've spent enough time driving in this game to make a couple of comments. (1) - there are too many freakin' cop cars. Even for California and L.A.  One after another after another passes by as if OJ was on the loose. In the real world, in California, there are too many freakin' cop cars but not as many as depicted in ATS, not one after another, after another, with another sitting on the side of the road. It makes me paranoid.(2) - The traffic patterns prevent "safe" turning from a side road onto a main highway without a traffic light or other method of controlling main highway traffic. It is not fun to sit for an hour in game time waiting for a lull in the traffic in order to make a left turn onto the highway. One has to resort to "bullying" the oncoming traffic which is not a habit one would want to get into. While this may "suggest" the real world traffic of Cali and L.A., in the game world it is frustrating and not fun. Especially when you have four lanes of heavy traffic going in opposite directions and you are sitting at a stop sign with a heavy load. Fix it!(3) - The highway travel time scale is too short. I don't get the feeling that I've made a "trip" from L.A. to Las Vegas. By the time I get comfortable on the Freeway, find a radio station with some good tunes on it, I'm already there. Travel time is too short. I hope this can be fixed in the release game or in the mods to come.I am still recommending this game for the west coast USA highway scenery.At this time I am giving it 3 out of 5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												This game, while extremely similar to Euro Truck Simulator 2, fits even better into the mold of traditional American trucking. The actual truck designs are beautiful, and have incredible attention to detail. That being the case, they only have two truck models on offer right now, with a third one coming soon. Although this is due to licensing issues with truck manufacturers, it can be disheartening to players that aren't following the development process so closely. The locations are a similar case to the trucks. There are only two available at the time of this review, including California and Nevada. This is going to be expanded in the future, through DLC (The first state to be added in the future will be Arizona, free of charge). Same as the trucks, while there is a huge increase in polish since ETS2, with tons of detail in the town buildings and structures, having only two states, both being sunny and hot, can really leave a lot to be desired in the way of actual content. You will get lost in the Nevada desert (Not literally lol), you will want to drive around Las Vegas and the beaches of California, but that awe factor runs out after a couple of trips to these few locations, making me want more states to play with.As for right now, the game is pretty much ETS2 with a new, more suitable skin. Whether or not you should buy this over ETS2, or just stick with ETS2 if you've been playing that, is up to whether or not you enjoy the actual theme of American trucks and American locales to be trucking through. Keep in mind that you will have to deal with a lack of content in the beginning of this developmental cycle (with the possibilty of having to pay for future states as DLC). I personally think it is worth it, and I will look forward to any future additions to the game. Good job SCS Software.

												I have put 6 hours into this game so far and I find this game to be very good, however there are several problems I have with this game.Pros:-Game runs great on high settings-Lots of details put into difrent cities etc.-Trucks look amazing the way they are.-Map is pretty big.Cons:-It uses the same interface making it feel like its the same game.-There are only two states in the game (Califonia and Navada): Note- Yes I do know that these two states do have a lot in them but sence its called American Truck Simulator I figure they would have more before they launch the game.-There are only TWO truck brands to chose from -Gas stations and repair stations start to look the same. 												For me, this is well worth 14.99. It's just two trucks and two sates to start with, but Arizona and more trucks will be coming soon.I have Euro Truck Sim 2, but I generally prefer Trucks and Trailers, and Scania Truck Sim, as these two old sims concentrate on the challenge of manouevering and parking rather than the driving in between. - (don't get me wrong, I still enjoy ETS2 though).But I couldn't resist buying this - and somehow it is better than ETS2. The graphics, and atmosphere of driving along American freeways, just seems to suit the game better.I know others have complained about the slightly smaller scale, but that might be another reason why I prefer it to ETS2. The drive is long enough to enjoy, but not too long to get boring. And with the whole of USA planned, there is still plenty of scope for long drives.It's looking good, I just hope SCS are reasonable when they start selling the DLCs, I am prepared to pay but I will draw the line if I keep paying £15 for every 3 states. But they seem to have been good with previous releases, so I hope they will be so here.Recommended if you like the previous trucking incarnations & want more of the same, but with the real American flavour.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Well, folks.  Here we are.  The Hype is real and still is!I bought ATS as it is called by players because I loved ETS2 and wanted to play an American Truck game, like the old 18 WoS days.  So far, I'm not disappointed by the game one bit.  Yeah, you only get two trucks at the start, and I'm fine with that.  The reasoning for the lack of immediate content is actually a good one for once.  It is because rather than put fake brands in the game, SCS wants to get licenses first.  But, as said by Pavel Sebor himself, getting licenses from truck manufacurers that aren't used to being approached for licenses of their product is like the chicken vs egg debate.  So, they are going about it the right way at least.On to the gameplay.  Those of you that are familiar with ETS2 will have no problem getting used to the ATS Gameplay.  There are a lot of new things to compliment to already very good base gameplay that I hope will be making it's way to ETS2 soon as well.  Delivery Points are the biggest advancement in the gameplay system.  You can choose how difficult you want the delivery to be.  From a zero point quick drop to a 90 point drop that is so complex, even the most Veteran Driver will have a challenge are available for choosing.Weigh Stations are new to the game.  You can be randomly chosen to go to the Scale House for Inspection.  It's an interesting feature, but a bit of a waste of time and ruins fuel economy.  Hopefully, SCS will be able to do something to give this feature more meaning.After talking about weigh stations, we have no choice but to talk about the new police engine.  Now, the dreaded Rozzers are mobile and sneaky.  I got a Speeding Ticket for not being at 30 MPH right after the sign changed.  There needs to be a Reduced Speed Ahead sign, like in real life here in the States.So, lets break it down to the Pros and Cons.ProsFamiliar yet tweaked GameplayAmerican TrucksNevada included Scenery that will blow your mindEaster Eggs, yes, there a few, and no, I will not tell you what they areNo curves every 20 feet like ETS2ConsOnly two states at the beginningOnly two trucks at the beginning,  Not really a con, but may put some people offThe UI is completely Copy/Paste.  Would have loved to see the Route Adviser remodeled.  Maybe next time.Only 64-Bit Having looked at the facts and played a long time, I can give a solid 9 out of 10.  This game is definitely worth a buy.  It's continued development is something I look forward to.UPDATE:  W900 is out and it's not bad.  The sounds need a little tweaking still, but at least it's there.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												The ones who liked Euro Truck Simulator for its qualities will also like the American Truck Simulator.Technically, it is to 90% the same game, the difference in the 10% are the following:1) Instead of European Trucks you're driving the American ones of cause.2) You can design your own driving route now on the map just like e.g. in Google Maps on your smartphones with waypoints.3) Instead of just parking your trailer manually and autoparking it you now can chose between a medium/hard way to park it manually, an easy way to park it manually and the alrdy known autoparking. For the medium/hard way you get the most XP (40/90 XP-Points))4) The game world is filled with life to a higher degree, there are more peasants walking on the pedestrian walks, there are workers working on the delivery/reception sites, there are security men standing in front of supermarkets etc etc.5) There are more different delivery sites, instead of just delivering to company yards and building sited you can now also deliver to gas stations.6) The game is set in America (Cpt. Obvious strikes again).The game is available for a fair price of 20€, for which you get the US-States of California, Nevada and Arizona (That's still in the pipeline).But California and Nevada for themselves are alrdy highly detailed, there are about 10-15 cities in California and about 10 in Nevada, so, if you compare it with the Old 18 Wheels of Steel Games from SCS, where California had two cities, a huge increase!Arizona is coming for free too, what States in which Quantity the other DLC's will deliver is subject to the future, I don't know that.I think, that SCS, as they alrdy did with ETS2 and its DLC's, will deliver a reasonable amount of DLC's for a fair price and with a fair content in it.As I've read, relying on that this wasn't a joke, they plan to eventually map the whole of North- and Latin-America atleast down to the equator, but of cause this is a work for years to come.All in all, this game, just like his older brother ETS 2, is a shining juwel in the simulation genre and I can recommend it from the bottom of my heart.Update #01: Another positive thing: Just days after release they alrdy added the third truck the legendary Kenworth W900, a truck the community asked for. Another reason to recommend the game, because of the consumerfriendly policy of SCS, thumbs up!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I've spent enough time driving in this game to make a couple of comments. (1) - there are too many freakin' cop cars. Even for California and L.A.  One after another after another passes by as if OJ was on the loose. In the real world, in California, there are too many freakin' cop cars but not as many as depicted in ATS, not one after another, after another, with another sitting on the side of the road. It makes me paranoid.(2) - The traffic patterns prevent "safe" turning from a side road onto a main highway without a traffic light or other method of controlling main highway traffic. It is not fun to sit for an hour in game time waiting for a lull in the traffic in order to make a left turn onto the highway. One has to resort to "bullying" the oncoming traffic which is not a habit one would want to get into. While this may "suggest" the real world traffic of Cali and L.A., in the game world it is frustrating and not fun. Especially when you have four lanes of heavy traffic going in opposite directions and you are sitting at a stop sign with a heavy load. Fix it!(3) - The highway travel time scale is too short. I don't get the feeling that I've made a "trip" from L.A. to Las Vegas. By the time I get comfortable on the Freeway, find a radio station with some good tunes on it, I'm already there. Travel time is too short. I hope this can be fixed in the release game or in the mods to come.I am still recommending this game for the west coast USA highway scenery.At this time I am giving it 3 out of 5 stars.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I've never written a Steam review before, but really wanted to sing the praises of this game.I'm someone who loves to drive in real life, and who also comes from and lives in California. I'm a fan of EuroTruck Simulator 2 (and I also lived in the UK for 5 years), but felt a lot of the scenery and layout was very repetitive and would often uninstall after only a few play sessions, although I'd reinstall it once in awhile. Solid game tho, and the business tycoon style aspect was fun.In American Truck Simulator you really have the same game however I strongly feel they've done a fantastic job of skinning the game in such a way that really gives the feeling and spirit of the American Southwest very well. I know and have driven many times around the places in this game and while it's not 100% perfect or to scale, there's a ton of subtleties that this game gives to very much put you in something a lot like real life.The windmills off Highway 111 (down in what is effectly the Coachella Valley, where Palm Springs is), the tree barriers found off Highway 99 that runs along the eastern side of the San Juaqin Valley (which is very different to the feel of the 5 Freeway which runs down the west side of that huge valley), the way the roads and buildings change while you drive over the Sierra Nevada pass (past Truckee) and into Nevada itself. The way the roads work around Las Vegas. All of these examples and hundreds more really give you a strong sense of what it is to drive around this part of the world, with all of the other successful elements from EuroTruck Simulator 2, including the ability to customize your music, and even just use preexisting Internet Radio streams which are all highly appropriate, to managing your own company of trucks and drivers over time.Getting better in the game requires coming to learn what different areas of the map will throw at you to slow you down or trip you up, eg parts of a freeway being subject to harsh speed limits (and getting a huge speed fine if you miss it) or understanding that making a left onto a freeway from a country lane could take you an extra half an hour, or knowing when sharp grades are better driven around than attempted head on, all of these things are at play and create a real sense of accomplishment over time as you begin to master the routes.This is a very fun game that's just as good as its predecessor but I think a much more realistic and engaging experience than Euro 2. The only complaint I have is some minor AI issues that can occur around some intersections and a funny thing where some intersections have both stop lights and stop signs too which seem to confuse the AI (and also isn't how America traffic works either). It's a pretty minor problem though that may even disappear someday.Defininte recommend for anyone who liked the predecessors.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												If you like Euro Truck Sim 2 you'll probably enjoy this a lot. Although right now the map size is much smaller than ETS2. But for now driving across California had never felt so good. The map is decent and makes it feel akin to what driving in America would feel like. From the run down shops to the overabundant amount of self storage businesses. The sweet joy of make a trip is still there, but those long hauls aren't quite there yet since you can only travel between two states. Many of the mechanics mirror what was in ETS2, such as ranking and how the game is played. So players of ETS2 will feel right at home. I would recommend this if you particularly liked ETS2 a lot and just want a new scenery and are willing to wait for more states and trucks. This feels barebones in a way with content as there is only two states currently and not very many trucks. Down the line, or very soon we should be getting Arizona and more trucks. Even with the lack of content the game is still enjoyable to play and check out the new scenes.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I've never written a Steam review before, but really wanted to sing the praises of this game.I'm someone who loves to drive in real life, and who also comes from and lives in California. I'm a fan of EuroTruck Simulator 2 (and I also lived in the UK for 5 years), but felt a lot of the scenery and layout was very repetitive and would often uninstall after only a few play sessions, although I'd reinstall it once in awhile. Solid game tho, and the business tycoon style aspect was fun.In American Truck Simulator you really have the same game however I strongly feel they've done a fantastic job of skinning the game in such a way that really gives the feeling and spirit of the American Southwest very well. I know and have driven many times around the places in this game and while it's not 100% perfect or to scale, there's a ton of subtleties that this game gives to very much put you in something a lot like real life.The windmills off Highway 111 (down in what is effectly the Coachella Valley, where Palm Springs is), the tree barriers found off Highway 99 that runs along the eastern side of the San Juaqin Valley (which is very different to the feel of the 5 Freeway which runs down the west side of that huge valley), the way the roads and buildings change while you drive over the Sierra Nevada pass (past Truckee) and into Nevada itself. The way the roads work around Las Vegas. All of these examples and hundreds more really give you a strong sense of what it is to drive around this part of the world, with all of the other successful elements from EuroTruck Simulator 2, including the ability to customize your music, and even just use preexisting Internet Radio streams which are all highly appropriate, to managing your own company of trucks and drivers over time.Getting better in the game requires coming to learn what different areas of the map will throw at you to slow you down or trip you up, eg parts of a freeway being subject to harsh speed limits (and getting a huge speed fine if you miss it) or understanding that making a left onto a freeway from a country lane could take you an extra half an hour, or knowing when sharp grades are better driven around than attempted head on, all of these things are at play and create a real sense of accomplishment over time as you begin to master the routes.This is a very fun game that's just as good as its predecessor but I think a much more realistic and engaging experience than Euro 2. The only complaint I have is some minor AI issues that can occur around some intersections and a funny thing where some intersections have both stop lights and stop signs too which seem to confuse the AI (and also isn't how America traffic works either). It's a pretty minor problem though that may even disappear someday.Defininte recommend for anyone who liked the predecessors.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												American Truck Simulator is a big step up from Euro Truck Simulator 2 in a lot of areas, bringing updates to the graphics and gameplay, but does lack quite a bit of the content from Euro Truck Simulator 2.For starters, the map is way, way smaller, comprising only two states of the US, California and Nevada, with Arizona coming down the line. This is a big downgrade from Euro Truck Simulator 2, which spanned from the UK to Poland. However, in my opinion, the environment you're driving in in ATS is far more interesting than in ETS2. Where ETS only had vague hints of there being a city somewhere in the distance, having you drive through bland industrial areas which were virtually indistinguishable from one another, in ATS you actually get to drive through the actual cities, which have a lot of detail put into them, and all look very different. The roads outside the cities also put you in more interesting situations sometimes, and the roads differ from each other a lot, where in ETS they were pretty much all the exact same.The game only has 2 trucks right now, with another coming very soon. This, to me, is not much of a problem, as even in ETS I only ever used 1 or 2 trucks. The amount of trucks in ETS was actually a little overwhelming to me the first time, as I had no knowledge of trucks and didn't know where to start, so there only being 2 trucks actually was a little more welcoming to me this time around.Still, with that in mind, I have a hard time recommending this game over ETS2. If you haven't played ETS2 yet, get that game first. It's got a lot more to offer and a lot more to keep you going. However, if you have already played ETS2, have all the DLC and want more, then I'd recommend this to you. It's a lot more atmospheric and has got enough content to keep me going.

												I have played about 28 hours at this writing, and I am enjoying immensely. For the most part I do in fact feel like I am controlling a real transport truck. I am playing with mouse and keyboard because I don't have a steering wheel, but this game makes me what to go and purchase a good wheel to play it with.There are a few minor bugs, but they are few and far between, and they don't happen too often,The sound track is bacically your own person music library, or you can choose from any internet radio station and the game with search for them for you. content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Before I begin, I want everyone to know that I've been waiting on this game for years now. Ever since we were told they began development. I knew exactly what I was going to get, so I'm basing my review on that.____When you first see the game, it looks exactly like Euro Truck Simulator 2. The only differences include it being in the United States, having vehicles driven in the United States, trailers that are used in the United States, and a couple states in the United States.After you get past the $20 price tag and actually get in the game, it's exactly as it seems. Just a reskin of ETS2. But what was to be expected? It's the same engine used to rebuild ETS2 for a different region. That's what we were told we were going to receive and that's what we got. I am not at all upset that we only get 2 states at release with Arizona coming a little later for free and 2 trucks. I knew I was getting that and I paid the price for that.The developers wanted to go the correct route with the game and get licensing for the vehicles used so the lack of vehicles is okay. As time goes on, we'll get loads more. As far as states go, 3 might not seem like much. With the scale, it definitely seems lacking in content. But you have to remember. If they went to a more in-depth scale and added more content, then it'd take years for a single state to come out. I don't know about you, but I'd like to have 48 states before I turn 70 years old. :PAnd the game is called American Truck Simulator. American. The United States is only one of dozens upon dozens of countries in America. Canada and Mexico are 2 more countries in NORTH America. Meanwhile, there's still South America that has to be scaled in. By the time we get all of that(if we ever do, the plans could change), we'd have so much map, we wouldn't be able to explore it all in a reasonable amount of time. Sure, California and Nevada might not seem like much, but they are comparable to Great Britain and France in ETS2 when you talk about size. Now add the equivelent amount of states as there are countries in ETS2 and you have the United States completed. UK and France might not seem like much on ETS2, but when you travel from one to the other, and then all the way to Poland and then up to Sweden, you start to realize that even though the map is small now, it will be much bigger later on when we have more content to play.Not much of a regular review that you'd see on Steam, but these are my opinions on the game so far. It's a reskin of ETS2 and that's what we were told and what we paid for. No complaints here. Still a billion times better than most simulators out there.

												Oooooooh it's been a long time coming this and I for one I'm not disappointed. Yes, it is the full Euro Truck sim skin but the setting is so much more appealing. In Euro Truck (modless of course) Manchester is no different to Stockholm. It gets a little bit samey after a while, but the little diners, donut stands, sweeping desert vistas and iconic cities give this game a much more pleasing long haul in the truck even though there are only two states in the game currently. As for the trucks, there maybe only two brands at the moment but they both drive so much more satisfyingly than the Euro truck rosta. You have to take on board my comments as a casual gamer, hardcore virutal truckers will probably find this easy compared to the Euro Truck routes because I wouldnt say it's dumbed down at all, I just find the truck handling so much more responsive. I managed to completed five jobs without a traffic violation, speeding ticket or an AI Kamikaze pilot veering into my side. That's a massive bonus and I'd say generally the AI is much better from inital impressions.Gotta go now, I've got George Jones on the Internet Radio, my coffee in a travel mug, my Philadelphia Eagles Cap on and my best checked shirt pressed...got some miles to cover to get my own truck and I'm wasting time jabbering on here. Buy it, you can't possibly be dissapointed :) "Rubber Duck, got a smokey bear in the air, come back..." etc etc

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												It is hard to express the appeal.  Perhaps it is for the very reason that it isn't a ' kill everything that moves.  If it doesn't move, put it in your gun and kill.' I guess the closest way to describe it would be a classic transport tycoon game where you just happen to spend most of your time in the first person view of your best employee.  You can ignore the company builder component completely.  Or after you have spent some time building up your company you can devote much of your time to it.  I think players that do both will get the most from this game.Yes it's only 3 states and 2 trucks, but I feel at a $20 price point this is a great deal.  SCS has a solid reputation of adding to the base game for years after release, and not just paid DLC.  If you compare the base game of ETS2 now with when it was first released it is practically an entirely new game.  This game will grow for years and they will devote their time and energy into this game rather than quickly cash in and release a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥sequel.

												This game plays very similar to Euro Truck Simulator 2.  The largest downsides right now are simply lack of content (only 2 states to visit - only 2 brands of cabs to drive).  The graphics have improved since ETS2 and cities are much more detailed.  Traffic can be more dense in some areas making the driving more fun. content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												For me, this is well worth 14.99. It's just two trucks and two sates to start with, but Arizona and more trucks will be coming soon.I have Euro Truck Sim 2, but I generally prefer Trucks and Trailers, and Scania Truck Sim, as these two old sims concentrate on the challenge of manouevering and parking rather than the driving in between. - (don't get me wrong, I still enjoy ETS2 though).But I couldn't resist buying this - and somehow it is better than ETS2. The graphics, and atmosphere of driving along American freeways, just seems to suit the game better.I know others have complained about the slightly smaller scale, but that might be another reason why I prefer it to ETS2. The drive is long enough to enjoy, but not too long to get boring. And with the whole of USA planned, there is still plenty of scope for long drives.It's looking good, I just hope SCS are reasonable when they start selling the DLCs, I am prepared to pay but I will draw the line if I keep paying £15 for every 3 states. But they seem to have been good with previous releases, so I hope they will be so here.Recommended if you like the previous trucking incarnations & want more of the same, but with the real American flavour.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												When I saw this game coming out, I just knew I just had to get it because I loved Euro Truck Simulator 2 so much for its relaxing drives. When I saw the screenshots and teasers of this game, it gave off a different vibe. No more are you travelling along the moody highways of Belgium or Poland. Instead, the pictures gave off a vibe I never knew could be in a SCS game. It was colourful and very vibrant, really showing the spirit of the USA. Now after playing it for a while. I have to say I've really enjoyed this game. The cities are MUCH more detailed than in ETS and cities like Las Vegas or San Francisco has nice buildings and even the coast of places like Santa Cruz are really beautiful. The only main gripe of the game that most people have even thou I'm fine with it is that the game literally only came out with 2 States (California & Nevada) with Arizona DLC coming out soon. The map size is SIGNIFICANTLY smaller compared to ETS2 which had a really huge map. I believe the devs are working as hard as ever to pump out more content for this game and I'm really looking forward to what they have in store for us. Plus they mentioned that their main goal may be to reach the East coast! (Cross country drives? :>)Overall, if you like ETS and dont mind a more lively vibrant feel and colours, definitely pick this game up and just enjoy trucking :)8.6/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												My impressions of American Truck Simulator after about 5 hours in game.Good:Scenery is good compared to alot of sims out there.Sounds let you really feel the power of the truckroad system is good and makes more sense in some cases than the actual roads.Same solid gameplay of ETS2 fame.Neutral:The game itself is for all intent and purpose still Euro truck sim 2, just with american trucks and map.. so if your a fan of ETS2 its good, if not well this title probably wont be your cup of tea either.Only two trucks... but with quite a few chassis/body options: Personally I prefer this to 20 fake trucks.. you may find it limiting so I list it as a nuetral.Controls I don't have a steering wheel so I can only speak to keyboard.. but the truck don't seem to handle aswell as their ETS2 counterparts. Of course that could also just be my opinion so take it with a grain of salt.Environment; this is different from scenery to me because graphically its nice, but seriously there are more vehicle in america than 1950's cruisers, RV's, Semi's, and cops.Fines: Holy crap police presence. There is no escaping the fines in this game.. ETS2 gave you speed traps that once you learned where they were you could slow down for em. Here? every third car is a cop who can and will pull you over for 4mph over the speed limit. Nice because it forces you to treat it more like a sim... but a tad over done IMO.Bad:Smallish map, I get more is coming out.. I really do.. and I wish I didn't have to list this as a bad.. but when you can run any route before you've even maxed your distance stat.. well thats not beuno.AI; its been a plague on this series even in ETS2 and it didn't get any smarter here.. same stupid 4wheelers doing stupid things right into the side of your truck.TL/DRIf you are a diehard fan of truck games buy it, if you like sims buy it. If you want a finished US map with a 48 states and a total overhaul from ETS2.. well maybe wait awhile and catch it on sale after some more content has released.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												From the makers of Euro Truck Simulator, SCS presents to us American Truck Simulator. It's very similar to ETS however they have improved upon the game engine, graphics and the road layouts. Thankfully now junctions make sense and dont suddenly turn into a slip road forcing you to cut up traffic as you change lane at the last minute.Currently at launch there are only two counties you can drive in (Nevada and California) and from what i've read another county or two will be free to those who have already bought the game but after that it further counties will be charged DLC. I believe they have a similar business model as that of Train Simulator where the base game is fairly cheap but add-on DLC will be the same price as the base game, if not more. I don't mind paying for DLC for a quality game like this where i will invest a lot of time into it, but please don't be money hungry b******* like EA or Activision.If you enjoyed Euro Truck Sim, or any driving simulation games then this is a must buy. The Multiplayer mod works great and the MP community (at time of writing this review) is quite reasonable and friendly. Just waiting for the 12 year olds to buy this and race around America.... See you in game!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												ok so ATS. At first glance most will and appear to have said it looks like a very well done expansion pack for ETS2. While in some ways i do agree, overall i do not. This is another score for SCS. While there is not much going on overall (being that there is only 2 trucks and 2 states to drive in) there is something rather satisfying about driving a Kenworth or Peterbilt along North American Roads with precious cargo. The game is rather small right now. But so far i have throughly enjoyed the 68 hours i have played it so far. I am down now to two cities left to deliver cargo to and about 65% of all roads driven on.  One thing that is a bit disappointing is the lack of overall accessories and slots to drop stuff onto on the two trucks available (Kenworth T680 and the Peterbilt 579). Both trucks are nice to drive however. Plus the fact that truck and truck accessory mods from ETS2 are for the most part compatible with a few easy def file changes. Which has resulted in numerous truck mods and accessories being made available. For those that are familiar with ETS2 may find this game a little lacking. However it is still just as oddly engrossing as it's european cousin. ATS has the potential to be totally awesome once all of the USA is finally added as well as DLC's to add Canadian destinations and Mexican destinations will make this the most expansive game in SCS's library (considering the fact that once all of Canada is added it will add the 3rd largest physical country in the world with some of the worlds most dangerous trucking roads in the world). As well, the possabilities that can come from adding in Mexico is staggering.Great first release. i for one will be buying each and every DLC for this game. Good Job SCS.Keep on Truckin'

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This game is great.  Details are there, and some are more noticeable than the details in ETS2.  Only issues I see are the traffic fines are ridiculous, and the fact that in this point of time there are only two trucks and a small handful of upgrades.The roads may not be true to what they are in real life, but what do you expect?  A couple of roads on the map are steep.  There is a road that is really almost too tight to move through with a trailer attached to your rig.  The travel times and distances are shorter than in ETS2, but for a good reason.  It would've taken another year or two to make this game if they had made it in the same scale as ETS2, and to top that off it would take even longer to get the rest of the US done, as well as Canada and Mexico.   I think it's a fair compromise on scale.  Yeah, some of the stuff was carried over from ETS2, but think about it... the engine works, and works well, no reason to fix what isn't broken.  The environment is more immersive than ETS2 if you can get over the fact that the scale is smaller.Pros:  Graphics. (if your machine can handle it on ultra, mine can't but it still looks pretty good)          Details, details, details... like tumbleweeds.          Roads,          Steampunk paint jobs. (if you followed the page before they released them)Cons: Traffic tickets are way too high.          Map is smaller scale then ETS2.          Only two trucks and a few upgrades as of this review posting.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												So, things that are unrealistic in this hyper-realistic truck-driving simulator:*The traffic in LA, and Las Vegas is not anywhere near as bad as it is in real life. (This is a good thing)*The intersections of freeways/highways are logical and identical and sane, and not anything like reality. (Also a good thing)*The AI car drivers use their turn signals approx. 10x more often than actual CA drivers. (Thank you lord)*The roads are reasonable in the towns and not anywhere near as maze like as reality. (I've been in a lot of industrial parks in California, the one's in the game are so much saner)*Every single traffic light has a camera to catch you when you "accidentally" run a red light. (Annoying, but okay, I guess)*A lot of the major cities are far less impressive and picturesque because of the downscaling. Admittedly, there is stuff in the distance in towns to add depth, but you can't drive there, and I'm usually so busy paying attention to the speed limit I don't notice. (LA didn't bother me much, but Las Vegas was super disappointing compared to the real thing.)Things that are super realistic and awesome:*That moment, where it's 3am and you're driving around Las Vegas looking for a place to sleep and you're staring at your GPS and next thing you know you've plowed straight into the back of a car while going 50mph? Yeah, that was me.*The first time I drove into Primm in game, I was so amazed at how much it was exactly like the real thing that I missed my turn, over-compensated, drove straight into a wall, and caused about 5 car accidents. Seriously, the Primm in-game is identical to the real thing, it's a little creepy.In short, you'll either love this game, or hate it. I find that it's great to play when I've had a long day, I can just turn on some dance music and zone out and drive. That being said, if you don't enjoy the thought of having to follow the speed limit, and follow the basic laws of the road, this probably isn't for you. I'm really hoping and looking forward to future DLC that adds more states, because while I enjoy the fact that I know all these towns, it's a little uncanny.

												Pros:- Graphically better than ETS2Other than that, it's basically the same exact game.  The menus are litterally the same as in ETS2.  The game engine is exactly the same. THREE TRUCKS. -No offical MP. -Map scalling is terrible.  Wait until you try to merge onto the highway in heavy traffic.  The onramps litteraly spit you into traffic.  Did I say merge?  Sorry, just plow into traffic because there's no onramp.  The onramps just cut into traffic on an angle. Overall my biggest gripe is the slow development and lack of content.  If you're set on getting a truck sim game, I enjoy ATS the best.  ETS2 has a bigger map and more trucks, but I'm partial to the American trucks.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												As for those who have played Euro Truck Simulator 2, you will find this game to be very much similar. Truthfully, the only really noticeable differences would have to be the landscape(s), traffic, trucks, e.t.c. The performance and everything is slightly better, (in my case), and it was excellent to begin with in ETS2. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the ETS series, and for anyone thinking of trying out the series for the first time.As for the newcomers, keep in mind this is not a game designed for freeroaming, constantly popping in and out of any vehicle you want, or for professionally managing a business; it's a truck driving sim. You drive trucks under an employer until you make enough money to buy your own truck. From there on you haul various types of cargo to build your wealth. You then move on to expand your garage(s), buy more trucks, hire drivers, and make money. From a broad standpoint, yes it does simulate business, but that's not the primary goal of the game; it's for driving trucks.Summary summed up: if you want to drive anything you please any time or manage a business from a professional standpoint, this game is not what you're hunting. If you want to drive a semi, (and make money doing so), haul lots of different things, and design trucks for your employees to drive, this is what you want.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												This game may only be of interest to you if you are interested in American trucks but don't want to use the mods for Euro Truck Simulator.For a game that has only been recently released, the content included isn't as much as I expected. Driving with only three trucks and two states does get boring quite quickly. However, the developers are working on new trucks and more states for the game, however I feel that they should have postponed release until they received the licenses from the truck manufacturers and at least a few more states developed. At the time this review was written, a new state is in public beta testing stages, however this did come four months after the game's release.In-game, you cannot fault the gameplay. However if you have played Euro Truck Simulator 2 in the past, you may feel as if this is just a re-skin, since it shares the same base as Euro Truck Simulator 2. You may feel as if it's a deja vu, as you are seeing the same UI design as Euro Truck Simulator 2.However, this isn't all a bad thing. The gameplay from ETS2 has had a lot of work been put into it from its release in 2012, and every single feature that makes the game good can be found here. SCS Software, the developer, have stated that both games will receive any new feature they develop, so you can be assured that you aren't left out on updates to the game.Driving is a pleasure. Cruising through America was more relaxing than I thought it would be. It's obvious that SCS have put a lot of time and effort into the game's world. Though the lack of content hindered this pleasure a bit, I still got a few days of joy from it.In conclusion, I give it a 7/10. The gameplay of this game is magnificent, and you can never go wrong at a rather low price. However, this doesn't hide the fact that the lack of content hinders your continuous enjoyment from driving through beautiful American scenery. I recommend this, however I would say wait a bit until more content gets put into the game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												While I whole heartedly do recommend this game - I also recommend waiting to play it.There is so much more that's coming.  Right now there isn't a lot of America in the game, in the future there will be both free expanions and paid expansions that will end up covering a lot more of the US (hopefully *all* in time and then other parts of the Americas).While this is a great simulator that's surprisingly good, there's just so much more coming that you'd be doing yourself a huge disservice to not play the future versions where there will be all that extra content in the game.That isn't to say there isn't a full game here, there is, it's just going to be so much more in the future that if you play it now instead you'll end up missing out on too much (unless you are a long term player that keeps playing it).This is the start of a big new project, but that's the thing, it's only the start.  I purchased it now to support the game because I really wanted to have it and I very much enjoy it but I'm waiting until more is here to play - as hard as it is to wait.So yes I very  much recommend the game, and yet recommend waiting.It's surprisingly fun and deep, I never thought I'd like a truck driving simulator but I more than like it, I absolutely love it.Unfortunately if we write too much our reviews get cut off so I can't go into more details of the game after writing what I have.  In the future once more content is out I'll see if I can update this with a proper review that talks more about the game itself than waiting to play it.*Edit - I'm rating this based on MANY hours with the Euro 2 version which is the same game only in Europe - that's how I can be sure I love it even though it looks like my play time isn't that much on this version yet.

												I have to say that American Trucking Simulator is THE next best addition to Euro Truck Simulator 2.  Every bit of detail, and effort that this company put into that game is evident in American Truck Simulator.I have become diagnosed with chronic migraines and vertigo. Seeing highway 101 split into two very short fragments and Hwy 1 seems like they created their own road and put the Hwy 1 symbol on it. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I bought ETS2 for $3.74 on a Steam sale, I feel that I 'stole' that game. I am happy to pay $20 for this game even though at this point there is very little content. I know that SCS will be adding much more for free in the near future, this is simply an early launch version. I like that everything looks just like ETS2, the menus, UI, etc because I know where everything is and it is seamless to go from one game to the other, without trying to remember where such and such option is. I hate when companies feel the need to change the menus to a game just for the sake of doing it, usually for the worse.There are 2 trucks and 2 states so far. If I had doubts that there will be more than this, I would not recommend it for $20, but I know, we all know, that this is just the beginning of what will be a great game.I play with a Thrustmaster T150 wheel with the Pro pedals add on and 2 Thrustmaster TH8A shifters. Yes, you read that right, 2 of them. Everything works fine in this game. I have my shifting set up in H pattern with one of the shifters and the other one (which is my rally style handbrake) is my gear change shifter, to go beyond the first 6 gears. Unfortunately I can't program the game for the 7th gear on my shifter. Hopefully SCS will change this in the future.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Pros:~Amazing scenery - The world is really rich with colour, and personality. Every where you go you see detail far eclisping anything that ETS2 ever gave. ~Great scale - Some argue this, but obviously the map will be smaller. Sure it does not take long to traverse the states, but the transition of scenery really captures you're journey. ~Good value - Yes, the content is low, but so is the price. For only $20 its a fair price. ~Good sound - Much is recycled but it still sounds great.~Unique handling - The truck feel really different, at least in my experiance. Rather slower to get moving, and a bit twitchy. Not sure if I liked it at first but after adjusting the settings I think I am rather enjoying the new feel.Cons:~Little content - Only two trucks with a handful of iterations each. A few free ones are coming, but more could have been given.~Few States - Only two on launch. Arizona is promised soon and will be given free of charge; its hard to complain about that. Launching with a few more states however, would not have hurt. ~Derpy AI - AI constanting is getting in my way when I have the right of way at a light. These are nit picks however and I am sure they will be addressed soon. ~Re-used interface - Most, if not all the interface is the same from ETS2Verdict ---------------Sure much is re-used, but most fans knew that was coming. For 20 bucks I think SCS was really fair with how they priced it. With stunning new locations and a great attention to detail anyone who wants to drive through the countryside should jump on board. AI - 7Graphics - 9Sound/Music - 8Gameplay - 9Value - 7=====40/50

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Pros:~Amazing scenery - The world is really rich with colour, and personality. Every where you go you see detail far eclisping anything that ETS2 ever gave. ~Great scale - Some argue this, but obviously the map will be smaller. Sure it does not take long to traverse the states, but the transition of scenery really captures you're journey. ~Good value - Yes, the content is low, but so is the price. For only $20 its a fair price. ~Good sound - Much is recycled but it still sounds great.~Unique handling - The truck feel really different, at least in my experiance. Rather slower to get moving, and a bit twitchy. Not sure if I liked it at first but after adjusting the settings I think I am rather enjoying the new feel.Cons:~Little content - Only two trucks with a handful of iterations each. A few free ones are coming, but more could have been given.~Few States - Only two on launch. Arizona is promised soon and will be given free of charge; its hard to complain about that. Launching with a few more states however, would not have hurt. ~Derpy AI - AI constanting is getting in my way when I have the right of way at a light. These are nit picks however and I am sure they will be addressed soon. ~Re-used interface - Most, if not all the interface is the same from ETS2Verdict ---------------Sure much is re-used, but most fans knew that was coming. For 20 bucks I think SCS was really fair with how they priced it. With stunning new locations and a great attention to detail anyone who wants to drive through the countryside should jump on board. AI - 7Graphics - 9Sound/Music - 8Gameplay - 9Value - 7=====40/50

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Love this game. If you enjoy ETS2, this is the game for you. It is a little underwhelming, with only California, Nevada, and the Peterbilt 579 and Kenworth T680. This should change soon, with the state of Arizona being added soon as a free DLC, and the Peterbilt 389 and Kenworth W900 are on their way. The devs have shown us sneak peeks at a International Lonestar, Volvo VNL780, and a Freightliner in the works, and have stated that they will be supporting the game long-term. ATS is not as forgiving for new truck drivers as ETS2, so I would suggest you be extremely careful if this is your first trucking game, as the fines are horrendous. $1000 for speeding, $900 for hitting a car, and $700 for running a red-light. The cops are merciless, and when you only have $1500 to start with, it adds up quickly. I would highly recommend the game if you are like me and love details and eye-candy. The map is beautiful, very detailed with small additions such as skateboarders in parks and workmen at delivery points. The delivery points are much more varied and detailed compared to ETS2. This game does feel like a standalone DLC to ETS2 at this point, but I think that once more content is released it will begin to come into its own. While people are complaining that the whole map is only about the size of two ETS2 UKs, they have failed to note that the map is much more detailed than ETS2. In ETS2, every town looks pretty much the same, while in ATS, there is actually some fun in discovering new towns and cities, they actually look different from one another. I love this game and at $20, it's very reasonably priced, especially with more content to come.

												American Truck Simulator is probably the one of the most innovative trucking sims on the market, and the main reason for this is all of it's features. Here is a summary of those features:- Luxuriously detailed trucks (complete with working interiors) and trailers- Sumptuously and beautifully detailed American environments packed with traffic, pedestrians, other truckers, police, and interactive scenery- Stream tons of different online radio stations or import your own songs into the game for entertainment on the road- Modify virtually each and every aspect of your rigs with some of the deepest customization ever in a trucking sim: engines, chassis, retarders, decals, paint, grill guards, and more...

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												I'll admit I'm a bit biased, since I loved ETS2, but this game is great on its own.  Its a great game, the gameplay is smooth, its relaxing, yet at the same time, offers challenges such as time management on load delivery, building a company,  and as much realism in a sim that you could ask for depending on how you want to setup the settings on the game.  There are also little things in the game that catch your eyes, like cropdusters flying over winefields and spraying, the tons of different car skins that they have added that look similiar to popular American vehicle models (there is a station wagon that when I first saw it, I thought it was the Griswolds heading to Wally World :) )  and other fun things about the game that make it enjoyable.  You can add your own music to the library to listen to the radio, or you can tune in to internet radio stations if you need some music while you drive.  I'm interested to see what direction they go with expanding the map with more states beyond California, Nevada and Arizona, perhaps more truck models, etc.  The customization of your trucks is top notch, and with the huge amount of mods out there made by users, the game itself has a lot of things you can add to it to make it even more enjoyable.  Pick up a copy if you haven't, you'll be glad you did.
